      "pageContent": "[262] Â For a discussion of the difficulties entailed by Aristotleâ€™s silence, see\nLeroi (2014, p. 310-325) and Nussbaum (1978). For the more radical view that\nAristotleâ€™s teleology is in fact by principle opposed to the presuppositions of\necology, see Johnson, 2005, p. 209.\n\n\n\n[263] Â The History of Animals Â is a work of zoology, Parts of Animals a work of\ncomparative anatomy, Generation of Animals a study of reproductive physiology,\nand Motion of Animals Â is concerned with biomechanics.\n\n\n\n[264] Â Some ( e.g. Â Gonzalez, 2020, p. 149) suggest that the rarity of\necological speculation in these treatises should puzzle us if we suppose that\nAristotle did consider nature to be organized beyond individuals. We contend\nthat given the topic of these works, it is nothing surprising. What is puzzling\nis Aristotleâ€™s choice not to write an ecological treatise. As Leroi notes Â â€œ\nAristotle has the ingredients of community ecology in his hands but does not use\nthemâ€. Â  (2014, p. 319) Let us note, however, that it is much more surprising\nthat a so-called local teleologist would write the Politics , than it is that a\nglobal teleologist would fail to produce an ecological treatise.\n\n\n\n[265] Â  HA VIII 2, 591 b23-30 ; PA Â IV 13, 696 b24 -34.\n\n[266] Â  Ph. II 8, 198 b16- 199 a9.\n\n[267] Â  The passage from Physics II 8 concerns the relation of mechanical and\nteleological accounts. Aristotle argues against those who claim that the\npossibility to explain rain in terms of material necessity entails that it is\nnot for the sake of Â an end. He suggests that the opposition of material and\nteleological accounts is a mistake and that in truth, to determine whether\nsomething is a result Â of chance or the end Â of a goal-directed process, we must\nconsider the regularity of the event. Whether the event is a result ( e.g. rain\nin winter) or an end (rain in summer), Aristotle argues, the mechanical account\nstill holds. Given the purpose of his argument in that context, he does not\nprovide a detailed account of the instrumental role of rain in crop growth, but\nsimply mentions it in passing. The passages from PA and Â HA Â appear within the\ncontext of an investigation of the way of life of a specific animal. While it is\ntrue that Aristotleâ€™s comments in these (and other similar) passages may serve\nas circumstantial evidence of his general sympathy towards the idea that nature\nis well ordered beyond the level of individuals, this is not the question at\nhand in those contexts, thus they constitute a weak and inadequate foundation\nfor establishing Aristotleâ€™s view on the application of teleology beyond the\nlevel of organisms.\n\n[268] Â  Aristotle.   "text": "INSTRUMENTAL RELATIONS IN ARISTOTLEâ€™S INTRINSIC TELEOLOGY\n\n\n\n\n\nLAURENCE LAUZON\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nThesis submitted to the University of Ottawa in fulfillment of the requirements\nfor the Masters of Arts (M.A.) in Philosophy, with thesis\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDepartment of Philosophy\n\nFaculty of Arts\n\n\n\nUniversity of Ottawa\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nÂ© Laurence Lauzon, Ottawa, Canada, 2023\n\n\nABSTRACT\n\n\n\nThis thesis examines the scope of Aristotelian teleology. It challenges a\nnarrowly intrinsic interpretation which rests on a dichotomous conception that\nonly admits of two kinds of goal-directed movements, namely the actualization of\noneâ€™s own nature, or the artificial and arbitrary use of another substance. The\nthesis aims at overcoming this dichotomy by highlighting the fact that there are\nintermediary cases according to Aristotle, i.e. Â that the relation between agent\nand patient is not always strictly intrinsic or extrinsic. The first chapter\nexamines instrumental relations in crafts Â and the second chapter examines\ninstrumental relations in nature, both of which are shown to have their place\nwithin Aristotleâ€™s intrinsic view of teleology. Simply, the thesis argues that\nthe self-actualization of natural substances should be viewed as the focal point\nrather than the exclusive subject of teleological accounts.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTABLE OF CONTENT\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nINTRODUCTION\n\nOver the last century, a growing number of scholars [1] Â have been calling for a\nrenewed interpretation of Aristotleâ€™s teleology because, it is argued, it has\nbeen misunderstood both by its advocates and deterrents who have attributed to\nhim a view of teleology which is extrinsic Â in one or both of two senses: [2] Â \nfirst , in that the goal-directedness of natural substances has its source in an\nagent which is external to the natural world ( e.g. Â an intelligent designer\nwhose intentions Â for each natural substance is the cause of their respective\ntendency to realize some goal); and second Â in the sense that the purpose of\nnatural substances is the benefit of an external entity for whose good the\nintelligent designer has ordered the world (e.g. God, humans, or the whole\ncosmos). It is said, for instance, that medieval thinkers, in an effort to\nreconcile Aristotelian teleology with the biblical notion of God as creator and\nprovidential supervisor of the world, have attributed to Aristotle a view of\nteleology which entails an intelligent designer, [3] Â whereas modern mechanical\nphilosophers [4] Â and scientists [5] Â have turned away from Aristotelian\nphilosophy of nature on the account that the appeal to divine design to explain\nthe natural order is unjustified and unscientific. [6]"
}

[36m[llm/end][39m [[90m1:chain:RefineDocumentsChain > 2:chain:LLMChain > [1m3:llm:Ollama[22m[39m] [13.31s] Exiting LLM run with output: {
  "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "This thesis examines Aristotle's concept of teleology and challenges a narrow interpretation that only acknowledges two types of goal-directed movements: the actualization of one's own nature or the artificial use of another substance. The author argues that there are intermediary cases according to Aristotle, where the relation between agent and patient is not strictly intrinsic or extrinsic. The thesis explores instrumental relations in crafts and nature, showing how they fit within Aristotle's intrinsic view of teleology. The author contends that the self-actualization of natural substances should be viewed as the focal point rather than the exclusive subject of teleological accounts.\n\nThe introduction notes a growing number of scholars have called for a renewed interpretation of Aristotle's teleology due to misunderstandings by both advocates and detractors. Medieval thinkers attributed an extrinsic view of teleology to Aristotle, while modern mechanical philosophers and scientists turned away from Aristotelian philosophy of nature due to the unjustified appeal to divine design to explain the natural order.\n\nIn summary, the thesis challenges a narrow interpretation of Aristotle's teleology and explores instrumental relations in crafts and nature within his intrinsic view of teleology, arguing that the self-actualization of natural substances should be the focal point rather than the exclusive subject of teleological accounts."
      }
    ]
  ]
}
[36m[llm/end][39m [[90m1:chain:LLMChain > [1m2:llm:Ollama[22m[39m] [13.31s] Exiting LLM run with output: {
  "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "This thesis examines Aristotle's concept of teleology and challenges a narrow interpretation that only acknowledges two types of goal-directed movements: the actualization of one's own nature or the artificial use of another substance. The author argues that there are intermediary cases according to Aristotle, where the relation between agent and patient is not strictly intrinsic or extrinsic. The thesis explores instrumental relations in crafts and nature, showing how they fit within Aristotle's intrinsic view of teleology. The author contends that the self-actualization of natural substances should be viewed as the focal point rather than the exclusive subject of teleological accounts.\n\nThe introduction notes a growing number of scholars have called for a renewed interpretation of Aristotle's teleology due to misunderstandings by both advocates and detractors. Medieval thinkers attributed an extrinsic view of teleology to Aristotle, while modern mechanical philosophers and scientists turned away from Aristotelian philosophy of nature due to the unjustified appeal to divine design to explain the natural order.\n\nIn summary, the thesis challenges a narrow interpretation of Aristotle's teleology and explores instrumental relations in crafts and nature within his intrinsic view of teleology, arguing that the self-actualization of natural substances should be the focal point rather than the exclusive subject of teleological accounts."
      }
    ]
  ]

[36m[chain/end][39m [[90m1:chain:RefineDocumentsChain > [1m2:chain:LLMChain[22m[39m] [13.31s] Exiting Chain run with output: {
  "text": "This thesis examines Aristotle's concept of teleology and challenges a narrow interpretation that only acknowledges two types of goal-directed movements: the actualization of one's own nature or the artificial use of another substance. The author argues that there are intermediary cases according to Aristotle, where the relation between agent and patient is not strictly intrinsic or extrinsic. The thesis explores instrumental relations in crafts and nature, showing how they fit within Aristotle's intrinsic view of teleology. The author contends that the self-actualization of natural substances should be viewed as the focal point rather than the exclusive subject of teleological accounts.\n\nThe introduction notes a growing number of scholars have called for a renewed interpretation of Aristotle's teleology due to misunderstandings by both advocates and detractors. Medieval thinkers attributed an extrinsic view of teleology to Aristotle, while modern mechanical philosophers and scientists turned away from Aristotelian philosophy of nature due to the unjustified appeal to divine design to explain the natural order.\n\nIn summary, the thesis challenges a narrow interpretation of Aristotle's teleology and explores instrumental relations in crafts and nature within his intrinsic view of teleology, arguing that the self-actualization of natural substances should be the focal point rather than the exclusive subject of teleological accounts."
}

  "text": "This thesis examines Aristotle's concept of teleology and challenges a narrow interpretation that only acknowledges two types of goal-directed movements: the actualization of one's own nature or the artificial use of another substance. The author argues that there are intermediary cases according to Aristotle, where the relation between agent and patient is not strictly intrinsic or extrinsic. The thesis explores instrumental relations in crafts and nature, showing how they fit within Aristotle's intrinsic view of teleology. The author contends that the self-actualization of natural substances should be viewed as the focal point rather than the exclusive subject of teleological accounts.\n\nThe introduction notes a growing number of scholars have called for a renewed interpretation of Aristotle's teleology due to misunderstandings by both advocates and detractors. Medieval thinkers attributed an extrinsic view of teleology to Aristotle, while modern mechanical philosophers and scientists turned away from Aristotelian philosophy of nature due to the unjustified appeal to divine design to explain the natural order.\n\nIn summary, the thesis challenges a narrow interpretation of Aristotle's teleology and explores instrumental relations in crafts and nature within his intrinsic view of teleology, arguing that the self-actualization of natural substances should be the focal point rather than the exclusive subject of teleological accounts."
}

The author explores instrumental relations in crafts and nature within Aristotle's intrinsic view of teleology, emphasizing the self-actualization of natural substances as the focal point rather than the exclusive subject of teleological accounts. Scholars have recently argued that an extrinsic view of teleology is un-Aristotelian, as it reverses the Aristotelian understanding of nature and the arts, and psychologizes purposes. In contrast, Aristotle deliberately distanced himself from his predecessors who appealed to a divine artist to explain the order and beauty of nature.   "text": "The rediscovery of Aristotleâ€™s intrinsic teleology usually emphasizes one of\nfour corrections to the extrinsic interpretation. (1) First, it is argued that\nends are species specific on Aristotleâ€™s account, [12] Â and that the\ndirectionality of natural substances is not towards a uniform purpose such as\nâ€˜serving humanityâ€™. Rather, nature is specifically differentiated and each kind\nof being [13] Â has an end which is â€œbetter thus (not without qualification, but\nwith reference to the substance in each case)â€ Â  ( Ph. Â II 7 198b7-8) . [14] Â \nThis principle is expressed in both ethics [15] Â in the form of what is commonly\ncalled the ergon Â argument, [16] Â which states that the good of each kind of\nthing corresponds to its specific function. For instance, while the excellence\nproper to the heart is the ability to pump blood, that of a kidney resides in\nits ability to filter it. Since a substanceâ€™s function is intimately related to\nits nature, it follows that the good is as diversified as being . Thus, it is\nargued, Aristotle is not concerned with explaining the purpose of animals\ngenerally in the sense of providing a reason for the existence of various animal\nspecies; but rather with explaining how the internal constitution and\nfunctioning of parts contributes to the actualization of a specific mature\nÂ organism. [17] Â (1.1) Consequently, some scholars emphasize the fact that\nAristotle is not a global teleologist, at least not in a strong sense [18]\nÂ which entails that all natural substances aim at some general or common good\n[19] Â or that there is an ultimate Good which is desired over and above the\nrespective ends of natural substances. [20] Â In short, Aristotleâ€™s teleology is\ncontrasted with extrinsic accounts on the basis that it rests on an immanent\nrather than a transcendent view of the good as a cause. (2) Consequently, the\nachievement of the end of a given natural substance is said to be inherently\nvaluable on Aristotleâ€™s account. The goodness of natural substances does not\nhave instrumental value i.e. Â it is not an expression of their usefulness to\nGod, Man, or the cosmos. This, it is argued, is a point of contrast with\nartificial teleology, [21] Â  for Â in the craft paradigm, value is measured in\nrelation to something external ( e.g. it is â€˜betterâ€™ for the knife to be sharp,\nnot Â because cutting is good for the knife itself, but rather in relation to the\nartisant who makes or uses the knife); consequently those who make natural\nsubstances into a product of divine craftsmanship tend to conceive of natural\nsubstances as instrumental Â in the realization of a divine plan, thus depriving\nthem of inherent value."

Since a substanceâ€™s function is intimately related to\nits nature, it follows that the good is as diversified as being . Thus, it is\nargued, Aristotle is not concerned with explaining the purpose of animals\ngenerally in the sense of providing a reason for the existence of various animal\nspecies; but rather with explaining how the internal constitution and\nfunctioning of parts contributes to the actualization of a specific mature\nÂ organism. [17] Â (1.1) Consequently, some scholars emphasize the fact that\nAristotle is not a global teleologist, at least not in a strong sense [18]\nÂ which entails that all natural substances aim at some general or common good\n[19] Â or that there is an ultimate Good which is desired over and above the\nrespective ends of natural substances. [20] Â In short, Aristotleâ€™s teleology is\ncontrasted with extrinsic accounts on the basis that it rests on an immanent\nrather than a transcendent view of the good as a cause. (2) Consequently, the\nachievement of the end of a given natural substance is said to be inherently\nvaluable on Aristotleâ€™s account. The goodness of natural substances does not\nhave instrumental value i.e. Â it is not an expression of their usefulness to\nGod, Man, or the cosmos. This, it is argued, is a point of contrast with\nartificial teleology, [21] Â  for Â in the craft paradigm, value is measured in\nrelation to something external ( e.g. it is â€˜betterâ€™ for the knife to be sharp,\nnot Â because cutting is good for the knife itself, but rather in relation to the\nartisant who makes or uses the knife); consequently those who make natural\nsubstances into a product of divine craftsmanship tend to conceive of natural\nsubstances as instrumental Â in the realization of a divine plan, thus depriving\nthem of inherent value.\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"
  ]
}

  "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe author challenges a narrow interpretation of Aristotle's teleology, arguing that there are intermediary cases where the relation between agent and patient is not strictly intrinsic or extrinsic. The article explores instrumental relations in crafts and nature within Aristotle's intrinsic view of teleology, emphasizing the self-actualization of natural substances as the focal point rather than the exclusive subject of teleological accounts. Scholars have recently argued that an extrinsic view of teleology is un-Aristotelian, as it reverses the Aristotelian understanding of nature and the arts, and psychologizes purposes. In contrast, Aristotle deliberately distanced himself from his predecessors who appealed to a divine artist to explain the order and beauty of nature. The article highlights a third option, grounds goal-directedness in organic forces rather than artificial organization, which provides a more nuanced understanding of teleology.\n\nPlease let me know if this refined summary meets your requirements or if you would like me to make any further adjustments."
      }
    ]
  ]

  "text": "(3) Aristotleâ€™s teleology is also contrasted with extrinsic models with respect\nto the identification of the beneficiary of teleological change. [22] Â Since (1)\npurposes are species specific, i.e. since natural goal-directedness is a\ntendency proper to each kind of thing to actualize its nature, and since (2) the\nrealization of this end is inherently valuable on Aristotleâ€™s account; it\nfollows that (3) it would be a mistake to say that a natural substance strives\nto achieve its end for the sake of another entity. For instance, if a frog goes\nthrough specific developmental steps for the sake of Â actualizing its nature (\ni.e. Â realizing the state of affairs which is best - not absolutely, but for the\nkind of being that frogs are), and if this is inherently valuable, then the\nbeneficiary of this developmental process is the frog itself. If however â€“ as\nartificial teleologist assert â€“ Â (1) natural substances are ordered for the sake\nof the realization of a universal purpose, and if (2) their value is only\ninstrumental, Â then we should maintain that the beneficiary of the development\nof frogs is an external entity for whose good the cosmos has been designed. Â \n\n(4) Lastly, Aristotleâ€™s teleology is contrasted with extrinsic and artificial\naccounts with regards to the location of the cause of teleological motion. An\nintelligent designer is the external cause of the good order of the natural\nworld, similar to how an artisant is the external cause of its production. By\ncontrast, it is said that Aristotelian teleology locates the cause of the\nteleological motion or change within [23] Â natural substances. In short, since\nAristotle distinguishes nature from crafts with respect to the location of the\nprinciple of motion, [24] Â  and since he does not conceive of nature as a\nproduct of craft, it is argued that the principle of teleological change must be\nlocated within natural substances on his account. [25]\n\nThis brief summary makes it apparent that references to Aristotleâ€™s intrinsic\nÂ teleology can mean different things. Aristotleâ€™s teleology is considered\nintrinsic first , in the sense that it rests on an immanent Â  rather than\ntranscendent view of the good; second, Â in the sense that it takes the\nrealization of the respective telos of natural substances to be inherently\nÂ valuable; third Â because the beneficiary of teleological motion is the natural\nsubstance itself, not another (external) entity; and fourth, Â because it locates\nthe cause of teleological change within natural substances rather than in an\nexternal organizer.\n\n\n\n\nTHE NARROW VIEW"

Aristotle distinguishes nature from crafts regarding the location of the principle of motion, and he does not conceive of nature as a product of craft. Therefore, on Aristotle's account, the principle of teleological change must be located within natural substances themselves, rather than in an external organizer. Therefore, on Aristotle's account, the principle of teleological change must be located within natural substances themselves, rather than in an external organizer. This refined summary highlights the unique features of Aristotle's intrinsic view of teleology, including its immanent perspective on the good, its focus on the self-actualization of natural substances, and its location of the cause of teleological change within those substances themselves.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nTHE NARROW VIEW\n\nThe scholars mentioned above do not always explicitly distinguish these\ndifferent meanings, nor do they examine their relation thoroughly, and although\nthey manifest a desire to move past an inaccurate understanding of Aristotleâ€™s\nposition, they usually do not provide an exhaustive discussion of the\nimplications and presuppositions of his perspective. In most cases, their\ncontribution is limited by the fact that teleology is not the primary object of\ntheir inquiry. Nussbaum, for instance, in her first interpretative essay, [26]\nÂ is concerned mainly with answering the Democritean mechanistic view of nature,\nand only clarifies things related to the intrinsic nature of teleological\nexplanations in passing. The majority of scholars do not confine themselves to investigating the intrinsic nature of goal-directedness in Aristotle's philosophy, instead adopting a narrow view that emphasizes the contrast with extrinsic interpretations. This has led to an incomplete discussion of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology and a lack of consideration for more nuanced senses of final causes.\n\nIn particular, scholars tend to reject strong transcendent, global, instrumental, or external conceptions of final causes and infer that Aristotle's view rests on an immanent, local, inherently valuable, or internal conception. However, this approach does not adequately consider the full range of possibilities for Aristotle's intrinsic teleology.\n\nOverall, more research is needed to fully understand the intrinsic nature of goal-directedness in Aristotle's philosophy."

  "text": "THE TASK AHEAD\n\nWe consider that these scholars have successfully shown why the extrinsic and\nartificial interpretations of Aristotleâ€™s teleology are problematic. For this\nreason, their contribution is a positive advance on the road to the discovery of\nAristotleâ€™s teleology. The next natural step should be to investigate the\npresuppositions and implications of Aristotleâ€™s intrinsic teleology in a more\nsystematic way. To our knowledge, M.R. Johnson is the only scholar who has\nundertaken this task in his book Aristotle on Teleology. [40] Â Johnson argues\nfor an intrinsic interpretation of Aristotelian teleology which he develops in\nclose dialogue with the Aristotelian corpus. A virtue of his Â approach is that\nhe treats Aristotleâ€™s works as a unity with which one must engage as a whole.\n[41] Â Despite his exhaustive treatment of the question and the vital\nclarifications and textual references he provides, we contend that Johnsonâ€™s\ninterpretation cannot be the final word on the subject because it is too\nnarrowly intrinsic and contradicts important Aristotelian doctrines. Johnsonâ€™s\ninterpretation relies on an unbalanced view of hylomorphic compounds. In an\neffort to avoid extrinsic accounts of the internal functioning of natural\nsubstances, he undermines the role of the material cause, and consequently, the\nAristotelian view of the dual nature of hylomorphic compounds. His\ninterpretation also relies on a restricted view of the beneficiary of\nteleological change which results in a limited understanding of the way natural\nentities can relate to one another, and in the exclusion of natural systems (\ne.g. Â food chains) from the field of study of natural philosophy. His\ninterpretation also presupposes a view of the accidental which is too broad and\nextends to the regular and beneficial relationships of natural substances ( e.g.\nÂ the order of the food chain is just an accidental Â result of the respective\nactivities of natural substances on his account) thus violating the principle of\ncausal adequacy. [42] Â Finally, Johnson presents a strictly immanent and local\ninterpretation of Aristotleâ€™s teleology [43] Â which is not easily reconciled\nwith Aristotleâ€™s teachings on the unity of the good. [44] Â We will develop some\n[45] Â of these points in due time, for now let this be a sufficient overview of\nthe ways in which we consider Johnsonâ€™s interpretation to be narrowly intrinsic.\n\n\nOUR PROJECT"
}

Johnsonâ€™s\ninterpretation relies on an unbalanced view of hylomorphic compounds. In an\neffort to avoid extrinsic accounts of the internal functioning of natural\nsubstances, he undermines the role of the material cause, and consequently, the\nAristotelian view of the dual nature of hylomorphic compounds. His\ninterpretation also relies on a restricted view of the beneficiary of\nteleological change which results in a limited understanding of the way natural\nentities can relate to one another, and in the exclusion of natural systems (\ne.g. Â food chains) from the field of study of natural philosophy. His\ninterpretation also presupposes a view of the accidental which is too broad and\nextends to the regular and beneficial relationships of natural substances ( e.g.\nÂ the order of the food chain is just an accidental Â result of the respective\nactivities of natural substances on his account) thus violating the principle of\ncausal adequacy. [42] Â Finally, Johnson presents a strictly immanent and local\ninterpretation of Aristotleâ€™s teleology [43] Â which is not easily reconciled\nwith Aristotleâ€™s teachings on the unity of the good. [44] Â We will develop some\n[45] Â of these points in due time, for now let this be a sufficient overview of\nthe ways in which we consider Johnsonâ€™s interpretation to be narrowly intrinsic.\n\n\nOUR PROJECT"
}

  "prompts": [
    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars discussed in the article do not provide a comprehensive examination of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology, focusing instead on the limitations of extrinsic and artificial accounts. While Lennox and Gonzalez grant this question significant attention, their work is limited by the scope of their interest. The majority of scholars do not confine themselves to investigating the intrinsic nature of goal-directedness in Aristotle's philosophy, instead adopting a narrow view that emphasizes the contrast with extrinsic interpretations. This has led to an incomplete discussion of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology and a lack of consideration for more nuanced senses of final causes.\n\nIn particular, scholars tend to reject strong transcendent, global, instrumental, or external conceptions of final causes and infer that Aristotle's view rests on an immanent, local, inherently valuable, or internal conception. However, this approach does not adequately consider the full range of possibilities for Aristotle's intrinsic teleology.\n\nOverall, more research is needed to fully understand the intrinsic nature of goal-directedness in Aristotle's philosophy.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nTHE TASK AHEAD\n\nWe consider that these scholars have successfully shown why the extrinsic and\nartificial interpretations of Aristotleâ€™s teleology are problematic. For this\nreason, their contribution is a positive advance on the road to the discovery of\nAristotleâ€™s teleology. The next natural step should be to investigate the\npresuppositions and implications of Aristotleâ€™s intrinsic teleology in a more\nsystematic way. To our knowledge, M.R. Johnson is the only scholar who has\nundertaken this task in his book Aristotle on Teleology. [40] Â Johnson argues\nfor an intrinsic interpretation of Aristotelian teleology which he develops in\nclose dialogue with the Aristotelian corpus. A virtue of his Â approach is that\nhe treats Aristotleâ€™s works as a unity with which one must engage as a whole.\n[41] Â Despite his exhaustive treatment of the question and the vital\nclarifications and textual references he provides, we contend that Johnsonâ€™s\ninterpretation cannot be the final word on the subject because it is too\nnarrowly intrinsic and contradicts important Aristotelian doctrines. Johnsonâ€™s\ninterpretation relies on an unbalanced view of hylomorphic compounds. In an\neffort to avoid extrinsic accounts of the internal functioning of natural\nsubstances, he undermines the role of the material cause, and consequently, the\nAristotelian view of the dual nature of hylomorphic compounds. His\ninterpretation also relies on a restricted view of the beneficiary of\nteleological change which results in a limited understanding of the way natural\nentities can relate to one another, and in the exclusion of natural systems (\ne.g. Â food chains) from the field of study of natural philosophy. While some scholars have attempted to investigate Aristotle's intrinsic nature of goal-directedness, their work is limited by their narrow focus on an immanent, local, inherently valuable, or internal conception of final causes.   "existing_answer": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars discussed in the article have successfully shown the limitations of extrinsic and artificial accounts of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology. While some scholars have attempted to investigate Aristotle's intrinsic nature of goal-directedness, their work is limited by their narrow focus on an immanent, local, inherently valuable, or internal conception of final causes.   "text": "OUR PROJECT\n\nOur project is to contribute to the systematic investigation of Aristotleâ€™s\nintrinsic teleology which has been initiated by Johnson. [46] Â While we\ngenerally agree with the intrinsic interpretation outlined above, we seek to\nhighlight its limitations in order to come up with a view that preserves its\ntruth while overcoming its shortcomings. Given spatio-temporal constraints, our\nwork will necessarily be incomplete. In order to be exhaustive, we would need to\naddress the premises and implications of Aristotleâ€™s intrinsic teleology in all\nthe senses laid out above. We should (1) first establish what it means for\nAristotelian teleology to be grounded in inner (natural) principles. In light of\nthis, we should then (2) establish what can constitute the beneficiary of\nteleological change, [47] Â and (3) investigate Aristotleâ€™s view on the unity of\nthe good as a cause; both within nature, and the whole cosmos. Lastly, we should\nexplore (4) the fundamental place of activity ( energeia ) in Aristotelian\nteleology, and inquire into the explanatory role of the prime mover. In this\npaper, we will undertake only the first of these steps. Our research will\nconsist in an investigation of the foundations and ramifications of a view of\nteleology which is said to be intrinsic because it has its foundation in natural\n(inner) causes. More precisely, our purpose is to clarify the place of\ninstrumental relations within Aristotleâ€™s naturalistic perspective on teleology.\nThis is a point of contention because instrumental relations presuppose alterity\n, meaning that they involve two separate entities, one of which imposes a\npurpose which does not belong to the other intrinsically. Because this is not\neasily reconciled with the intrinsic conception of final causes, many scholars\nsimply exclude all instrumentalization processes from the scope of Aristotelian\nteleology. This simplistic solution rests on a dichotomous conception which only\nadmits of two kinds of goal-directed movements, namely the actualization of\noneâ€™s own nature, or the artificial and arbitrary use of another substance.\n\n\n\n\nTHE INTERNALITY OF NATURAL CAUSES"
}

    [
      {
        "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars in the article aim to contribute to the systematic investigation of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology, which was initiated by Johnson. While they generally agree with the intrinsic interpretation, they seek to highlight its limitations in order to develop a more comprehensive view. They identify four steps towards this goal: (1) establishing the meaning of Aristotelian teleology being grounded in inner (natural) principles; (2) determining the nature of the beneficiary of teleological change; (3) investigating Aristotle's view on the unity of the good as a cause, both within nature and the whole cosmos; and (4) exploring the fundamental place of activity (energeia) in Aristotelian teleology. The research will focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within Aristotle's naturalistic perspective on teleology, which is a point of contention as it involves two separate entities with different purposes. The scholars aim to overcome this limitation by developing a more nuanced understanding of goal-directed movements, including the actualization of one's own nature and the artificial and arbitrary use of another substance.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the need for further research on Aristotle's intrinsic teleology and the limitations of existing interpretations, with a focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within his philosophy."
      }
    ]
  ]

  "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars in the article aim to contribute to the systematic investigation of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology, which was initiated by Johnson. While they generally agree with the intrinsic interpretation, they seek to highlight its limitations in order to develop a more comprehensive view. They identify four steps towards this goal: (1) establishing the meaning of Aristotelian teleology being grounded in inner (natural) principles; (2) determining the nature of the beneficiary of teleological change; (3) investigating Aristotle's view on the unity of the good as a cause, both within nature and the whole cosmos; and (4) exploring the fundamental place of activity (energeia) in Aristotelian teleology. The research will focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within Aristotle's naturalistic perspective on teleology, which is a point of contention as it involves two separate entities with different purposes. The scholars aim to overcome this limitation by developing a more nuanced understanding of goal-directed movements, including the actualization of one's own nature and the artificial and arbitrary use of another substance.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the need for further research on Aristotle's intrinsic teleology and the limitations of existing interpretations, with a focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within his philosophy."
}

  "existing_answer": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars in the article aim to contribute to the systematic investigation of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology, which was initiated by Johnson. They identify four steps towards this goal: (1) establishing the meaning of Aristotelian teleology being grounded in inner (natural) principles; (2) determining the nature of the beneficiary of teleological change; (3) investigating Aristotle's view on the unity of the good as a cause, both within nature and the whole cosmos; and (4) exploring the fundamental place of activity (energeia) in Aristotelian teleology.   "text": "THE INTERNALITY OF NATURAL CAUSES\n\nThroughout our work, we will challenge the dichotomous conception of natural and\nartificial causes which, we will argue, gives rise to a mistaken view of the\ncontrast between Aristotleâ€™s natural teleology with the artificial accounts of\nhis predecessors. It is common [48] Â to establish the distinction between\nnatural and artificial schemes of explanation first, Â with regards to the\nlocation of the principle of organization, an d second Â with respect Â to the\nrole played by psychological attitudes such as intentions and desires. In short,\nthe common view is that (1) Aristotelian teleology grounds explanations in the\nnature of substances i.e. Â in an internal Â principle of organization, whereas\nartificial teleologists explain the order and beauty of the natural world with\nreference to an external Â organizer; and that (2) while Aristotle conceives\ngoal-directedness as a self-actualization process i.e. as the expression of the\nbeing of the substance which changes for the sake of something, artificial\nteleologists rather consider it to be an expression of divine intentions i.e. â€˜\npurposeâ€™ is understood psychologically, while for Aristotle it has an\nontological meaning.\n\nAlthough there is some truth to this way of presenting the contrast, it is\nimportant to establish in what sense it is true and to draw the right\nconclusions, for we notice that a failure to establish certain nuances sometimes\nlead to simplistic and problematic views of the opposition of craft and nature\nand to an impoverished understanding of both. Johnson for instance concludes\nthat (a) nature is to be understood exclusively Â in terms of internally caused\nself-actualization processes; and that (b) instrumentalization processes â€“ which\nhe confines to the domain of craft [49] Â â€“ remain outside the scope of genuine\nteleological explanations. This leads him to (a) undermine the hylomorphic\nconception of natural substances, and to (b) distort the Aristotelian view of\ncrafts by divorcing them from their ontological basis (and consequently,\nemphasizing their psychological dimension). We will challenge both these\nsuppositions (and the resulting restrictions of the scope of teleology)\nthroughout our work. Our first chapter will challenge the (b) exclusion of\nartificial goal-directed processes from the scope of Aristotelian teleology and\nour second chapter will contest the (a) strictly internalist view of natural\nchange."
}

While they generally agree with the intrinsic interpretation, they seek to highlight its limitations in order to develop a more comprehensive view. They identify four steps towards this goal: (1) establishing the meaning of Aristotelian teleology being grounded in inner (natural) principles; (2) determining the nature of the beneficiary of teleological change; (3) investigating Aristotle's view on the unity of the good as a cause, both within nature and the whole cosmos; and (4) exploring the fundamental place of activity (energeia) in Aristotelian teleology.     "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars in the article aim to contribute to the systematic investigation of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology, which was initiated by Johnson. While they generally agree with the intrinsic interpretation, they seek to highlight its limitations in order to develop a more comprehensive view. They identify four steps towards this goal: (1) establishing the meaning of Aristotelian teleology being grounded in inner (natural) principles; (2) determining the nature of the beneficiary of teleological change; (3) investigating Aristotle's view on the unity of the good as a cause, both within nature and the whole cosmos; and (4) exploring the fundamental place of activity (energeia) in Aristotelian teleology. The scholars aim to overcome this limitation by developing a more nuanced understanding of goal-directed movements, including the actualization of one's own nature and the artificial and arbitrary use of another substance.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the need for further research on Aristotle's intrinsic teleology and the limitations of existing interpretations, with a focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within his philosophy.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nTHE INTERNALITY OF NATURAL CAUSES\n\nThroughout our work, we will challenge the dichotomous conception of natural and\nartificial causes which, we will argue, gives rise to a mistaken view of the\ncontrast between Aristotleâ€™s natural teleology with the artificial accounts of\nhis predecessors.   "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars aim to advance the systematic investigation of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology by addressing its limitations. They identify four steps towards this goal: establishing the meaning of Aristotelian teleology grounded in inner (natural) principles; determining the nature of the beneficiary of teleological change; investigating Aristotle's view on the unity of the good as a cause, both within nature and the whole cosmos; and exploring the fundamental place of activity (energeia) in Aristotelian teleology. The research will focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within Aristotle's naturalistic perspective on teleology, which is a point of contention as it involves two separate entities with different purposes. The scholars aim to overcome this limitation by developing a more nuanced understanding of goal-directed movements, including the actualization of one's own nature and the artificial and arbitrary use of another substance.\n\nThe article challenges the common dichotomy between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. While Aristotle conceives goal-directedness as a self-actualization process, artificial teleologists understand it as an expression of divine intentions. The scholars argue that these distinctions are oversimplified and lead to problematic views of the opposition of craft and nature. They aim to establish the right nuances and conclusions to provide a more comprehensive understanding of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology and its relationship with instrumental relations."
      }
    ]
  ]

  "text": "Because of the exhaustive nature of Johnsonâ€™s work, he will be our primary\ninterlocutor. Let us therefore provide a more comprehensive account of his view\nin order to delineate the contrast with our own. Fundamentally, Johnsonâ€™s view\nrests on three premises; the priority of nature over the arts, the internality\nof natural causes, and the identification of internal and explanatory causes.\n[50] Â From these he concludes that Aristotleâ€™s natural teleology is rooted\nexclusively in internal causes and consequently excludes instrumental relations\nfrom its scope. In the course of our work, we will contest the third premise and\nchallenge the resulting limitations of the scope of Aristotelian teleology.\nJohnson rightly insists that the distinction between natural and artificial\ncauses lies in the location of the principle of motion. [51] Â He also does well\nto highlight the distinction between intrinsic and incidental causes; the former\nbeing explanatory and therefore relevant to scientific investigations, and the\nlatter not suitable for grounding a teleological (or any kind of scientific)\nexplanation. [52] Â However, we will argue that his account becomes problematic\nwhen [53] Â  he treats Â these two distinctions as coextensive, [54] Â and infers\nthat only internal causes are explanatory and can ground scientific\nexplanations. We find in Johnsonâ€™s work no satisfactory justification for\ntreating these distinctions as coextensive, yet the consequences he draws from\nthis are significant, namely that any good a natural substance may contribute to\nis incidental to it, and thus irrelevant to theoretical science. The result is a\npolarizing view of nature and the arts where nature is the domain of strictly\nintrinsic principles, whereas crafts is associated with extrinsic and incidental\ncauses. Â This antithetical view of nature and the arts is best illustrated by\nthe table he includes on top of p.203 Â where he compares the intrinsic and\ninternal final causes of a horse ( e.g. Â life and reproduction) with its\nincidental and external ends ( e.g. Â gambling and racing). While Johnson is\nright to insist that the latter have no place in the scientific explanation of\nhorses, we contend it is a mistake to suppose that all Â external goods to which\na horse may contribute are equally arbitrary and scientifically irrelevant. In\nsimple terms, it rests on the premise that there exists no middle ground between\nthe self-actualization and arbitrary use of a natural substance. [55]"
}

  "prompts": [
    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars aim to advance the systematic investigation of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology by addressing its limitations. They identify four steps towards this goal: establishing the meaning of Aristotelian teleology grounded in inner (natural) principles; determining the nature of the beneficiary of teleological change; investigating Aristotle's view on the unity of the good as a cause, both within nature and the whole cosmos; and exploring the fundamental place of activity (energeia) in Aristotelian teleology. The research will focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within Aristotle's naturalistic perspective on teleology, which is a point of contention as it involves two separate entities with different purposes. The scholars aim to overcome this limitation by developing a more nuanced understanding of goal-directed movements, including the actualization of one's own nature and the artificial and arbitrary use of another substance.\n\nThe article challenges the common dichotomy between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. While Aristotle conceives goal-directedness as a self-actualization process, artificial teleologists understand it as an expression of divine intentions. The scholars argue that these distinctions are oversimplified and lead to problematic views of the opposition of craft and nature. They aim to establish the right nuances and conclusions to provide a more comprehensive understanding of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology and its relationship with instrumental relations.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nBecause of the exhaustive nature of Johnsonâ€™s work, he will be our primary\ninterlocutor. Let us therefore provide a more comprehensive account of his view\nin order to delineate the contrast with our own. Fundamentally, Johnsonâ€™s view\nrests on three premises; the priority of nature over the arts, the internality\nof natural causes, and the identification of internal and explanatory causes.\n[50] Â From these he concludes that Aristotleâ€™s natural teleology is rooted\nexclusively in internal causes and consequently excludes instrumental relations\nfrom its scope. In the course of our work, we will contest the third premise and\nchallenge the resulting limitations of the scope of Aristotelian teleology.\nJohnson rightly insists that the distinction between natural and artificial\ncauses lies in the location of the principle of motion. [51] Â He also does well\nto highlight the distinction between intrinsic and incidental causes; the former\nbeing explanatory and therefore relevant to scientific investigations, and the\nlatter not suitable for grounding a teleological (or any kind of scientific)\nexplanation. [52] Â However, we will argue that his account becomes problematic\nwhen [53] Â  he treats Â these two distinctions as coextensive, [54] Â and infers\nthat only internal causes are explanatory and can ground scientific\nexplanations. We find in Johnsonâ€™s work no satisfactory justification for\ntreating these distinctions as coextensive, yet the consequences he draws from\nthis are significant, namely that any good a natural substance may contribute to\nis incidental to it, and thus irrelevant to theoretical science. The result is a\npolarizing view of nature and the arts where nature is the domain of strictly\nintrinsic principles, whereas crafts is associated with extrinsic and incidental\ncauses. Â This antithetical view of nature and the arts is best illustrated by\nthe table he includes on top of p.203 Â where he compares the intrinsic and\ninternal final causes of a horse ( e.g. Â life and reproduction) with its\nincidental and external ends ( e.g. Â gambling and racing). While Johnson is\nright to insist that the latter have no place in the scientific explanation of\nhorses, we contend it is a mistake to suppose that all Â external goods to which\na horse may contribute are equally arbitrary and scientifically irrelevant. In\nsimple terms, it rests on the premise that there exists no middle ground between\nthe self-actualization and arbitrary use of a natural substance. [55]\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"
  ]
}

They identify four steps towards this goal: establishing the meaning of Aristotelian teleology grounded in inner (natural) principles; determining the nature of the beneficiary of teleological change; investigating Aristotle's view on the unity of the good as a cause, both within nature and the whole cosmos; and exploring the fundamental place of activity (energeia) in Aristotelian teleology.       {
        "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars aim to advance the systematic investigation of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology by addressing its limitations. They identify four steps towards this goal: establishing the meaning of Aristotelian teleology grounded in inner (natural) principles; determining the nature of the beneficiary of teleological change; investigating Aristotle's view on the unity of the good as a cause, both within nature and the whole cosmos; and exploring the fundamental place of activity (energeia) in Aristotelian teleology. The research will focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within Aristotle's naturalistic perspective on teleology, which is a point of contention as it involves two separate entities with different purposes. The scholars aim to overcome this limitation by developing a more nuanced understanding of goal-directed movements, including the actualization of one's own nature and the artificial and arbitrary use of another substance.\n\nThe article challenges the common dichotomy between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. While Aristotle conceives goal-directedness as a self-actualization process, artificial teleologists understand it as an expression of divine intentions. The scholars argue that these distinctions are oversimplified and lead to problematic views of the opposition of craft and nature. They aim to establish the right nuances and conclusions to provide a more comprehensive understanding of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology and its relationship with instrumental relations.\n\nIn particular, the scholars contest Johnson's view that only internal causes are explanatory and can ground scientific explanations. They argue that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of a natural substance, and that external goods to which a horse may contribute are not equally arbitrary and scientifically irrelevant. The scholars aim to establish a more nuanced understanding of goal-directed movements, including the actualization of one's own nature and the artificial and arbitrary use of another substance."

    ]
  ]

  "text": "We will challenge this premise and Johnsonâ€™s defense of it in due time but\nfirst, let us consider Aristotleâ€™s own discussion of the internality of natural\ncauses and attempt to shed light on his view of their opposition to artificial\nones, for once we have a firmer grasp of Aristotleâ€™s perspective, we will be in\na better position to determine the limits of Johnsonâ€™s interpretation. Â  In the\nopening section of book II of the Physics , Aristotle defines nature as an inner\nprinciple of motion and rest. [56] Â This is often interpreted as meaning that\nthe distinction between natural and artificial change is grounded in the spatial\nlocation [57] Â of the principle of motion. For instance, while a puppy has\nwithin itself the cause of its development into a dog (its soul), the cause of a\nbed is outside the bed, in the builder. The soul, being in Â the dog, is an\ninternal, thus natural Â cause, whereas the builder is an external, thus\nartificial Â cause. Although there is some truth to this view, we will argue that\nit does not constitute the whole truth, for the internality of natural causes\nshould not be understood only in a physical sense. This is made manifest by the\nfact that, according to Aristotle, (1) some causes are physically internal yet\nnot natural, and (2) some natural changes have a cause which is located â€˜in\nother thingsâ€™.\n\nLet us first consider the rest of the opening passage of Physics II 1 which\nsuggests that physical internality does not, in and of itself, make a cause the\nnatural Â principle of the motion it initiates:\n\nnature is a cause of being moved and of being at rest in that to which it\nbelongs primarily, in virtue of itself and not accidentally. I say â€˜not\naccidentallyâ€™ because (for instance) a man who is a doctor might cure himself.\nNevertheless it is not insofar as he is a patient that he possesses the art of\nmedicine: it merely has happened that the same man is doctor and patient â€“ and\nthat is why these attributes are not always found together. So it is with all\nother artificial products. None of them has in itself the principle of its own\nproduction. But while in some cases (for instance houses and other products of\nmanual labour ) that principle is in something else external to the thing, in\nothers â€“ those which may cause a change in themselves accidentally â€“ it lies in\nthe things themselves (but not in virtue of what they are). ( Ph . II 1, 192 b\n24-34) [58] ."

The soul, being in Â the dog, is an\ninternal, thus natural Â cause, whereas the builder is an external, thus\nartificial Â cause. Although there is some truth to this view, we will argue that\nit does not constitute the whole truth, for the internality of natural causes\nshould not be understood only in a physical sense. This is made manifest by the\nfact that, according to Aristotle, (1) some causes are physically internal yet\nnot natural, and (2) some natural changes have a cause which is located â€˜in\nother thingsâ€™.\n\nLet us first consider the rest of the opening passage of Physics II 1 which\nsuggests that physical internality does not, in and of itself, make a cause the\nnatural Â principle of the motion it initiates:\n\nnature is a cause of being moved and of being at rest in that to which it\nbelongs primarily, in virtue of itself and not accidentally. I say â€˜not\naccidentallyâ€™ because (for instance) a man who is a doctor might cure himself.\nNevertheless it is not insofar as he is a patient that he possesses the art of\nmedicine: it merely has happened that the same man is doctor and patient â€“ and\nthat is why these attributes are not always found together. So it is with all\nother artificial products. None of them has in itself the principle of its own\nproduction. But while in some cases (for instance houses and other products of\nmanual labour ) that principle is in something else external to the thing, in\nothers â€“ those which may cause a change in themselves accidentally â€“ it lies in\nthe things themselves (but not in virtue of what they are). ( Ph . II 1, 192 b\n24-34) [58] .\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"
  ]
}

  "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars aim to advance the systematic investigation of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology by addressing its limitations. They identify four steps towards this goal: establishing the meaning of Aristotelian teleology grounded in inner (natural) principles; determining the nature of the beneficiary of teleological change; investigating Aristotle's view on the unity of the good as a cause, both within nature and the whole cosmos; and exploring the fundamental place of activity (energeia) in Aristotelian teleology. The research will focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within Aristotle's naturalistic perspective on teleology, which is a point of contention as it involves two separate entities with different purposes. The scholars aim to overcome this limitation by developing a more nuanced understanding of goal-directed movements, including the actualization of one's own nature and the artificial and arbitrary use of another substance.\n\nIn particular, the scholars challenge Johnson's view that only internal causes are explanatory and can ground scientific explanations. They argue that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of a natural substance, and that external goods to which a horse may contribute are not equally arbitrary and scientifically irrelevant. The scholars aim to establish a more nuanced understanding of goal-directed movements, including the actualization of one's own nature and the artificial and arbitrary use of another substance.\n\nAristotle's view on the internality of natural causes is discussed, with the scholars arguing that physical internality does not, in and of itself, make a cause the natural principle of the motion it initiates. They provide examples to illustrate this point, including a man who is both a doctor and a patient, and houses and other products of manual labor. The scholars aim to establish a more nuanced understanding of Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology and its relationship with instrumental relations.\n\nIn summary, the article challenges the common dichotomy between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world, and aims to advance the systematic investigation of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology by addressing its limitations. The scholars focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within Aristotle's naturalistic perspective on teleology, and challenge Johnson's view that only internal causes are explanatory and can ground scientific explanations."
      }
    ]
  ]
}

  "text": "Aristotle thus adds a criterion for the delimitation of natural causes; the\nprinciple must be internal in virtue of what it is (intrinsically). The doctor\nwho heals himself is not the natural cause of the process he initiates for the\nsame reason that a builder who happens to stand inside the house he builds is\nnot the natural cause of the house; in these and similar cases, being â€˜inâ€™ the\npatient is incidental to the agent. The builder is not in the house because Â he\nis a builder, nor does he build because Â he is in the house. In such a case, the\ninternality of the agent is as irrelevant as its color ; in short, the\ninternality of the builder is an incidental Â cause of the house. The distinction\nbetween intrinsic and incidental Â  causes is most clearly laid out in the fifth\nchapter of the second book of the Physics Â where it is established that i\nntrinsic causes are essentially ( in virtue of what they are ) related to the\nresult they produce (and are therefore causally relevant) whereas incidental\ncauses are accidentally connected to the effect â€œFor example, the intrinsic\ncause of a house is the builder, but coincidentally it is the pale or the\nmusical.â€ ( Ph . II 5, 196b25). [59] Â The builder is the intrinsic cause of the\nhouse because he is essentially related to the house qua Â builder and the art of\nbuilding (which makes him a builder) explains the production of the house. By\ncontrast, there is no necessary connection between being pale and the production\nof a house, thus the pale is an incidental (non-explanatory) cause of the house.\nAs attested by his choice of example, in this passage Aristotle is not opposing\nart to nature as a cause; rather, insofar as they are intrinsically related to\ntheir effect both are opposed to chance."
}

They challenge Johnson's view that only internal causes are explanatory and can ground scientific explanations, arguing that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of a natural substance. [36m[chain/end][39m [[90m[1m1:chain:LLMChain[22m[39m] [13.17s] Exiting Chain run with output: {
  "text": "In this article, the scholars aim to advance the systematic investigation of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology by addressing its limitations. They challenge Johnson's view that only internal causes are explanatory and can ground scientific explanations, arguing that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of a natural substance. The scholars focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within Aristotle's naturalistic perspective on teleology, providing examples to illustrate their point, such as a man who is both a doctor and a patient, and houses and other products of manual labor. They argue that being 'in' the patient is incidental to the agent, and that the internality of the builder is irrelevant in the case of the house. The scholars establish a more nuanced understanding of Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology and its relationship with instrumental relations.\n\nIn summary, the article challenges the common dichotomy between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world, and advances the systematic investigation of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology by addressing its limitations. The scholars focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within Aristotle's naturalistic perspective on teleology, and argue that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of a natural substance."
}

  "existing_answer": "In this article, the scholars aim to advance the systematic investigation of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology by addressing its limitations. They challenge Johnson's view that only internal causes are explanatory and can ground scientific explanations, arguing that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of a natural substance. The scholars focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within Aristotle's naturalistic perspective on teleology, providing examples to illustrate their point, such as a man who is both a doctor and a patient, and houses and other products of manual labor. They argue that being 'in' the patient is incidental to the agent, and that the internality of the builder is irrelevant in the case of the house. The scholars establish a more nuanced understanding of Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology and its relationship with instrumental relations.\n\nIn summary, the article challenges the common dichotomy between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world, and advances the systematic investigation of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology by addressing its limitations. The scholars focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within Aristotle's naturalistic perspective on teleology, and argue that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of a natural substance.",
  "text": "In the passage from Physics II 1 cited above, however, Aristotle is contrasting\nart and nature, and in that context, he is not simply affirming that natural\nprinciples are intrinsic in the general sense that they are causally relevant.\nIn addition to being essentially related to their effect, Aristotle establishes\nthat natural causes are intrinsically ( by virtue of what they are ) internal.\nIt is in this respect that they can be contrasted with artificial causes, since\nthe latter are either external, or they are within the patient but only\ncoincidentally. By contrast, it is not by chance that a natural cause is\ninternal. The soul for instance, cannot possibly exist outside the body and\nshape it from the outside; it is an internal cause by its very nature\n(intrinsically). But what does it mean for natural causes to be internal in\nvirtue of what they are ? Â  Why is the soul (and natural causes generally)\nnecessarily in Â the patient? Is the soul glued to the body with a very strong\ntype of glue i.e. Â is it just physically inseparable from the body? The soul,\nAristotle says on multiple occasions, [60] Â constitutes the formal, final, and\nefficient principle of the living body, which means the efficient and final\nprinciples are identified to the formal cause of the body. Thus the final and\nefficient principles of the living body are necessarily in it because of their\nidentity with its essence. In the second book of the treatise On the Soul ,\nAristotle defines the soul as â€œan actuality of the first kind of a natural\norganized bodyâ€ ( De An. Â II 1, 412b5) . [61] Â  Thus i t is clear that the\ninseparability of body and soul is not only physical, for the soul is â€œsubstance\nin the sense which corresponds to the account of a thing. That means that it is\nwhat it is to be for a body of the character just assigned.â€ ( De An. Â II 1,\n412b10 ). [62] Â In other words, the soul and the living body are not just\nnecessarily connected, they are one . [63] Â In this resides the contrast with\ncrafts, for an artist and its product, although they are essentially related,\nare nonetheless distinct entities. Generally then, a natural cause is\nintrinsically Â internal because agent and patient are in a sense [64] Â \nidentical ."
}

They challenge Johnson's view that only internal causes are explanatory and can ground scientific explanations, arguing that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of a natural substance. The scholars focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within Aristotle's naturalistic perspective on teleology, providing examples to illustrate their point, such as a man who is both a doctor and a patient, and houses and other products of manual labor. They argue that being 'in' the patient is incidental to the agent, and that the internality of the builder is irrelevant in the case of the house. The scholars focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within Aristotle's naturalistic perspective on teleology, and argue that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of a natural substance.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nIn the passage from Physics II 1 cited above, however, Aristotle is contrasting\nart and nature, and in that context, he is not simply affirming that natural\nprinciples are intrinsic in the general sense that they are causally relevant.\nIn addition to being essentially related to their effect, Aristotle establishes\nthat natural causes are intrinsically ( by virtue of what they are ) internal.\nIt is in this respect that they can be contrasted with artificial causes, since\nthe latter are either external, or they are within the patient but only\ncoincidentally. By contrast, it is not by chance that a natural cause is\ninternal. The soul for instance, cannot possibly exist outside the body and\nshape it from the outside; it is an internal cause by its very nature\n(intrinsically). [36m[llm/end][39m [[90m1:chain:RefineDocumentsChain > 26:chain:LLMChain > [1m27:llm:Ollama[22m[39m] [13.98s] Exiting LLM run with output: {
  "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars challenge the common dichotomy between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world, and advance the systematic investigation of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology by addressing its limitations. They focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within Aristotle's naturalistic perspective on teleology, arguing that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of a natural substance. The scholars establish that natural causes are intrinsically internal, meaning they are causally relevant and identical to the entity they are causing to exist. They illustrate this point with examples such as a man who is both a doctor and a patient, and houses and other products of manual labor. In contrast, artificial causes are either external or coincidental. The soul, for instance, cannot possibly exist outside the body and shape it from the outside; it is an internal cause by its very nature (intrinsically). The scholars emphasize that the connection between the agent and patient in natural causes is not just physical, but identity-based, meaning that the agent and patient are essentially the same entity. This contrasts with crafts, where the artist and product are distinct entities. By advancing this understanding of Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, the scholars aim to provide a more nuanced explanation of the order and beauty in the natural world."
      }
    ]
  ]
}

They focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within Aristotle's naturalistic perspective on teleology, arguing that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of a natural substance.   "existing_answer": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars challenge the common dichotomy between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world, and advance the systematic investigation of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology by addressing its limitations. They focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within Aristotle's naturalistic perspective on teleology, arguing that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of a natural substance.   "text": "If what we have said up to this point is correct, it should follow that the\ncause of a natural change cannot, in any circumstance, be physically external.\nYet in book VIII ch.4 of the Physics , Aristotle clearly asserts that some\nnatural motions can be initiated â€˜by something elseâ€™; â€œAnd the motion of things\nthat derive their motion from something else is in some cases natural, in others\nunnatural.â€ ( Ph. VIII 4, 254b20). [65] Â Consider for instance the case of\nelemental motion; the elements, although they are set in motion â€˜by something\nelseâ€™, are moved naturally , says Aristotle, when the motion is in accordance\nwith their inner inclination. â€œWhen fire and earth, then, are by force moved by\nsomething, they move contrary to nature, but they do so by nature when they are\nengaged in the activities that, in potentiality, are their own.â€ Â ( Ph . VIII,\n4, 255 a25-27) [66] Â Elemental motion can be natural even if it is initiated by\nan external cause according to Aristotle, for although the proximate efficient\ncause of the motion is physically external to the elements, they nonetheless\nhave within themselves [67] Â a (passive) principle, which is the explanatory\n(intrinsic) cause of their motion. In this, Aristotle says, elemental motion is\nanalogous to the fall of a heavy object; in a sense it is caused by the agent\nwho removes what was preventing it from falling but in truth, this agent â€œis the\naccidental cause of motion; and in the same way the rebounding ball is moved not\nby the wall but by the thrower.â€ ( Ph . VIII, 4, 255 b25) [68] ; in such a case,\nthe explanatory cause of the motion is â€œa source of motion â€“ not of moving\nsomething or of causing motion, but of suffering it.â€ ( Ph . VIII 4, 255 b30)\n[69] ; a principle which, in the case of elements, is internal Â (and not\nincidentally, for this natural tendency constitutes their essence). Therefore,\nalthough they are in a sense moved by something else, the explanatory cause of\ntheir motion is an intrinsically Â internal principle."
}

    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars challenge the common dichotomy between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world, and advance the systematic investigation of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology by addressing its limitations. They focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within Aristotle's naturalistic perspective on teleology, arguing that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of a natural substance.
