By advancing this understanding of Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, the scholars aim to provide a more nuanced explanation of the order and beauty in the natural world.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nIf what we have said up to this point is correct, it should follow that the\ncause of a natural change cannot, in any circumstance, be physically external.\nYet in book VIII ch.4 of the Physics , Aristotle clearly asserts that some\nnatural motions can be initiated â€˜by something elseâ€™; â€œAnd the motion of things\nthat derive their motion from something else is in some cases natural, in others\nunnatural.â€ ( Ph. VIII 4, 254b20). [65] Â Consider for instance the case of\nelemental motion; the elements, although they are set in motion â€˜by something\nelseâ€™, are moved naturally , says Aristotle, when the motion is in accordance\nwith their inner inclination. â€œWhen fire and earth, then, are by force moved by\nsomething, they move contrary to nature, but they do so by nature when they are\nengaged in the activities that, in potentiality, are their own.â€ Â ( Ph . VIII,\n4, 255 a25-27) [66] Â Elemental motion can be natural even if it is initiated by\nan external cause according to Aristotle, for although the proximate efficient\ncause of the motion is physically external to the elements, they nonetheless\nhave within themselves [67] Â a (passive) principle, which is the explanatory\n(intrinsic) cause of their motion. In this, Aristotle says, elemental motion is\nanalogous to the fall of a heavy object; in a sense it is caused by the agent\nwho removes what was preventing it from falling but in truth, this agent â€œis the\naccidental cause of motion; and in the same way the rebounding ball is moved not\nby the wall but by the thrower.â€ ( Ph . VIII, 4, 255 b25) [68] ; in such a case,\nthe explanatory cause of the motion is â€œa source of motion â€“ not of moving\nsomething or of causing motion, but of suffering it.â€ ( Ph . VIII 4, 255 b30)\n[69] ; a principle which, in the case of elements, is internal Â (and not\nincidentally, for this natural tendency constitutes their essence). Therefore,\nalthough they are in a sense moved by something else, the explanatory cause of\ntheir motion is an intrinsically Â internal principle.\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"
  ]
}
[32m[llm/start][39m [[90m1:chain:LLMChain > [1m2:llm:Ollama[22m[39m] Entering LLM run with input: {
  "prompts": [
    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars challenge the common dichotomy between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world, and advance the systematic investigation of Aristotle's intrinsic teleology by addressing its limitations. They focus on clarifying the role of instrumental relations within Aristotle's naturalistic perspective on teleology, arguing that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of a natural substance. The scholars establish that natural causes are intrinsically internal, meaning they are causally relevant and identical to the entity they are causing to exist. They illustrate this point with examples such as a man who is both a doctor and a patient, and houses and other products of manual labor. In contrast, artificial causes are either external or coincidental. The soul, for instance, cannot possibly exist outside the body and shape it from the outside; it is an internal cause by its very nature (intrinsically). The scholars emphasize that the connection between the agent and patient in natural causes is not just physical, but identity-based, meaning that the agent and patient are essentially the same entity. This contrasts with crafts, where the artist and product are distinct entities. By advancing this understanding of Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, the scholars aim to provide a more nuanced explanation of the order and beauty in the natural world.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nIf what we have said up to this point is correct, it should follow that the\ncause of a natural change cannot, in any circumstance, be physically external.\nYet in book VIII ch.4 of the Physics , Aristotle clearly asserts that some\nnatural motions can be initiated â€˜by something elseâ€™; â€œAnd the motion of things\nthat derive their motion from something else is in some cases natural, in others\nunnatural.â€ ( Ph. VIII 4, 254b20). VIII,\n4, 255 a25-27) [66] Â Elemental motion can be natural even if it is initiated by\nan external cause according to Aristotle, for although the proximate efficient\ncause of the motion is physically external to the elements, they nonetheless\nhave within themselves [67] Â a (passive) principle, which is the explanatory\n(intrinsic) cause of their motion. In this, Aristotle says, elemental motion is\nanalogous to the fall of a heavy object; in a sense it is caused by the agent\nwho removes what was preventing it from falling but in truth, this agent â€œis the\naccidental cause of motion; and in the same way the rebounding ball is moved not\nby the wall but by the thrower.â€ ( Ph . Therefore,\nalthough they are in a sense moved by something else, the explanatory cause of\ntheir motion is an intrinsically Â internal principle.\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"

The scholars emphasize that natural causes are intrinsically internal, meaning they are causally relevant and identical to the entity they are causing to exist. This is illustrated with examples such as a man who is both a doctor and a patient, and houses and other products of manual labor. In contrast, artificial causes are either external or coincidental. Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology highlights that the connection between the agent and patient in natural causes is not just physical, but identity-based, meaning the agent and patient are essentially the same entity. The passive principle present in the elements thus corresponds to a first\ndegree of actuality. In short, elemental\nmotion is natural because the external mover is only an incidental cause of the\nmotion.\n\nLet us also note that even in the case of living things, Aristotle thinks many\nnatural functions have their source in a physically external principle.       {
        "text": "Based on the new context provided, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars challenge the traditional distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They argue that Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology must be systematically investigated to provide a more nuanced explanation. The scholars emphasize that natural causes are intrinsically internal, meaning they are causally relevant and identical to the entity they are causing to exist. This is illustrated with examples such as a man who is both a doctor and a patient, and houses and other products of manual labor. In contrast, artificial causes are either external or coincidental. Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology highlights that the connection between the agent and patient in natural causes is not just physical, but identity-based, meaning the agent and patient are essentially the same entity. The scholars also emphasize that elemental motion can be natural even if it is initiated by an external cause, as the explanatory cause of the motion is an intrinsically internal principle.\n\nIn addition, the scholars note that even in the case of living things, Aristotle thinks many natural functions have their source in a physically external principle. Respiration, increase and decrease (development and deterioration), and other such natural activities are said to have their source in external environmental factors. The generation of animals and plants is also externally caused because the parent is numerically distinct from the offspring.\n\nOverall, the refined summary highlights the key points raised in the article, including the challenge to the common dichotomy between natural and artificial causes, the emphasis on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, and the highlighting of the identity-based connection between the agent and patient in natural causes."
      }

  ]

[36m[chain/end][39m [[90m1:chain:RefineDocumentsChain > [1m30:chain:LLMChain[22m[39m] [16.53s] Exiting Chain run with output: {
  "text": "Based on the new context provided, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars challenge the traditional distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They argue that Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology must be systematically investigated to provide a more nuanced explanation. The scholars emphasize that natural causes are intrinsically internal, meaning they are causally relevant and identical to the entity they are causing to exist. This is illustrated with examples such as a man who is both a doctor and a patient, and houses and other products of manual labor. In contrast, artificial causes are either external or coincidental. Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology highlights that the connection between the agent and patient in natural causes is not just physical, but identity-based, meaning the agent and patient are essentially the same entity. The scholars also emphasize that elemental motion can be natural even if it is initiated by an external cause, as the explanatory cause of the motion is an intrinsically internal principle.\n\nIn addition, the scholars note that even in the case of living things, Aristotle thinks many natural functions have their source in a physically external principle. Respiration, increase and decrease (development and deterioration), and other such natural activities are said to have their source in external environmental factors. The generation of animals and plants is also externally caused because the parent is numerically distinct from the offspring.\n\nOverall, the refined summary highlights the key points raised in the article, including the challenge to the common dichotomy between natural and artificial causes, the emphasis on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, and the highlighting of the identity-based connection between the agent and patient in natural causes."
}

  "text": "Based on the new context provided, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars challenge the traditional distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. The scholars emphasize that natural causes are intrinsically internal, meaning they are causally relevant and identical to the entity they are causing to exist. Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology highlights that the connection between the agent and patient in natural causes is not just physical, but identity-based, meaning the agent and patient are essentially the same entity.   "text": "In what way exactly is it not possible for the coming to be of the parts to be\ndue to something external? For there is a way in which it is possible, and\nanother way in which it is not. Now, whether we speak of the seed, or of what\nthe seed comes from, makes no difference, insofar as the seed has within it the\nmovement with which that other moved it. And it is possible for this to have\nmoved that, and that this other, and for it to be like those wondrous automata.\nFor their parts somehow contain a capacity when at rest, and when something\nexternal has moved the first of them immediately the contiguous one becomes so\nactively . As, then, in the case of these automata the external thing is in a\ncertain way moving them, not by making contact with any part now, but by having\nmade contact with one, it is likewise in the case of what the seed came from, or\nthat which produced the seed, it moves by having once made contact, not by\nmaking contact still. In another way, however, it is the internal movement that\ndoes this, as building does the house . ( GA Â II 1, 734 b5-10) [75]"
}

Now, whether we speak of the seed, or of what\nthe seed comes from, makes no difference, insofar as the seed has within it the\nmovement with which that other moved it.         "text": "Based on the new context provided, I have further refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars challenge the traditional distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They argue that Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology must be systematically investigated to provide a more nuanced explanation. The identity-based connection between the agent and patient in natural causes is emphasized, where the agent and patient are essentially the same entity. Even in cases of living things, Aristotle thinks many natural functions have their source in an external principle, such as environmental factors that initiate elemental motion. The scholars highlight the difference between internal movement, which is like building a house, and external movement, which is more akin to moving wondrous automata.\n\nThe passage from Aristotle's \"De Anima\" II 1, 734 b5-10 is cited, where he describes how the parts of an entity can contain a capacity for movement even when at rest, and how external contact can initiate this movement. The scholars argue that while external contact can move the entity, it is the internal movement that ultimately builds the house.\n\nOverall, the refined summary highlights the key points raised in the article, including the challenge to the common dichotomy between natural and artificial causes, the emphasis on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, and the distinction between internal and external movement."

  "existing_answer": "Based on the new context provided, I have further refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars challenge the traditional distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world.   "text": "The meaning of the last sentence becomes clear if we bear in mind the passage\nfrom Physics II 5 cited above, which establishes the contrast between\nexplanatory and incidental causes. In that passage, the art of building was said\nto be the explanatory cause of the house by contrast with the pale and the\nmusical. Thus it is plausible to think that when he says â€œit is the internal\nmovement that does this, as building does the hous eâ€ , he is identifying the\ninternal movement with the builder (the intrinsic cause of the house), thus\nimplicitly comparing the parent (external mover) to the pale or musical (the\nincidental cause of the house). The outcome of the argument is therefore that\nthe parent (external mover) is only an incidental cause of the generation of\nparts; whereas the principle of motion which is in Â the semen is the explanatory\ncause of the process. This aligns with what we have said about elemental motion.\nThe generation of parts is natural even if the parent is external because the\nexplanatory cause is by virtue of what it is Â in the semen. The semen, like the\nelements (and also like the parts of the automaton) â€œsomehow contain a capacity\nwhen at restâ€ , a capacity which we have said corresponds to a first degree of\nactuality. The difference between the case of the movement of automata and that\nof natural generation or elemental motion lies in the relation which holds\nbetween the passive and active principles. [76] Â A potentiality is somehow\ncontained in the parts of the automaton, but this is the result of the\norganizing activity of an external agent. Later in the passage from the\nGeneration of Animals , Aristotle says that â€œwhatever comes to be by nature or\nby craft comes to be due to something actively being, from something potentially\nbeing, of the relevant sort.â€ ( GA Â II 1, 734 b25) [77] Â By â€˜principles of the\nrelevant sortâ€™ he means explanatory principles, by contrast with irrelevant\n(incidental) â€œcausesâ€. While it is possible to identify explanatory (â€˜relevantâ€™)\ncauses in both art and nature, the difference lies in the fact that in nature,\nthe active and passive principles are one and the same whereas in craft they are\ndifferent. A form is already present in the semen, which is potentially Â an\norganism, whereas the form of the machine is different from and external to the\nmetal which is potentially Â the automa ton (for it resides in the soul of the\nengineer). In other words, in nature the passive principle already contains\nwithin itself a certain capacity - which corresponds to a first degree of\nactuality , thus the active and passive principles are one . Â The potentiality\nof the semen is therefore akin to that of the sleeping scientist, whereas that\nof metal is akin to the capacity of the ignorant man."
}

The outcome of the argument is therefore that\nthe parent (external mover) is only an incidental cause of the generation of\nparts; whereas the principle of motion which is in Â the semen is the explanatory\ncause of the process. This aligns with what we have said about elemental motion.\nThe generation of parts is natural even if the parent is external because the\nexplanatory cause is by virtue of what it is Â in the semen. The semen, like the\nelements (and also like the parts of the automaton) â€œsomehow contain a capacity\nwhen at restâ€ , a capacity which we have said corresponds to a first degree of\nactuality. The difference between the case of the movement of automata and that\nof natural generation or elemental motion lies in the relation which holds\nbetween the passive and active principles. [76] Â A potentiality is somehow\ncontained in the parts of the automaton, but this is the result of the\norganizing activity of an external agent. Later in the passage from the\nGeneration of Animals , Aristotle says that â€œwhatever comes to be by nature or\nby craft comes to be due to something actively being, from something potentially\nbeing, of the relevant sort.â€ ( GA Â II 1, 734 b25) [77] Â By â€˜principles of the\nrelevant sortâ€™ he means explanatory principles, by contrast with irrelevant\n(incidental) â€œcausesâ€. While it is possible to identify explanatory (â€˜relevantâ€™)\ncauses in both art and nature, the difference lies in the fact that in nature,\nthe active and passive principles are one and the same whereas in craft they are\ndifferent. A form is already present in the semen, which is potentially Â an\norganism, whereas the form of the machine is different from and external to the\nmetal which is potentially Â the automa ton (for it resides in the soul of the\nengineer). In other words, in nature the passive principle already contains\nwithin itself a certain capacity - which corresponds to a first degree of\nactuality , thus the active and passive principles are one . Â The potentiality\nof the semen is therefore akin to that of the sleeping scientist, whereas that\nof metal is akin to the capacity of the ignorant man.\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"
  ]
}

    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: Based on the new context provided, I have further refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars challenge the traditional distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They argue that Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology must be systematically investigated to provide a more nuanced explanation. The identity-based connection between the agent and patient in natural causes is emphasized, where the agent and patient are essentially the same entity. Even in cases of living things, Aristotle thinks many natural functions have their source in an external principle, such as environmental factors that initiate elemental motion. The scholars highlight the difference between internal movement, which is like building a house, and external movement, which is more akin to moving wondrous automata.\n\nThe passage from Aristotle's \"De Anima\" II 1, 734 b5-10 is cited, where he describes how the parts of an entity can contain a capacity for movement even when at rest, and how external contact can initiate this movement. The scholars argue that while external contact can move the entity, it is the internal movement that ultimately builds the house.\n\nOverall, the refined summary highlights the key points raised in the article, including the challenge to the common dichotomy between natural and artificial causes, the emphasis on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, and the distinction between internal and external movement.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nThe meaning of the last sentence becomes clear if we bear in mind the passage\nfrom Physics II 5 cited above, which establishes the contrast between\nexplanatory and incidental causes. They argue that Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology must be systematically investigated to provide a more nuanced explanation. The identity-based connection between the agent and patient in natural causes is emphasized, where the agent and patient are essentially the same entity. Even in cases of living things, Aristotle thinks many natural functions have their source in an external principle, such as environmental factors that initiate elemental motion. However, the scholars argue that while external contact can move the entity, it is the internal movement that ultimately builds the house.   "text": "We can now go back to the passage from Physics Â II 1 where nature is defined as\nan inner principle of motion and state with clarity what it means. The\ninternality of natural causes has to be understood both physically and\nessentially, for as we have said, natural causes are intrinsically internal. Let\nus reemphasize the fact that natural causes can be described as intrinsic in two\nways. First, generally, in the sense that they are by virtue of what they are\nÂ related to the result they produce. In this respect, they are like artificial\ncauses and unlike chance (and other incidental causes). Second, natural causes\nare said to be by virtue of what they are , internal to the patient in which\nthey produce a change. This second qualification indicates a deeper unity of\nmover and moved . It is in this respect that natural principles can be\ncontrasted with artificial causes, for the latter can be internal only\nincidentally. In short, agent-patient relations in craft are intrinsic only in\nthe first sense, whereas in nature, the relation is intrinsic in both senses.\nThus when qualifying natural causes as â€˜intrinsicâ€™, it is important to specify\nwhich of these senses we have in mind, for their confusion may lead to unclarity\nregarding the differentiation of natural, artificial, and incidental causes. In\norder to avoid confusion, we have adopted the term explanatory Â to refer to the\ngeneral sense in which both natural and artificial causes are contrasted with\nincidental causes because they are intrinsically (in virtue of what they are )\nrelated to their effects. We reserve the term intrinsic Â specifically for the\nrelation which holds between a natural principle and its effect.\n\nOn our interpretation therefore, we may distinguish natural, artificial, and\nincidental causes with regards to three types of relations, namely (1) an\nexplanatory or incidental relation (2) a physical relation of internality or\nexternality, and (3) an intrinsic or extrinsic essential relation (see the table\nbelow).\n\n\n\nExplanatory / Incidental\n\nIntrinsic / Extrinsic\n\nInternal/ External\n\nChance\n\nIncidental\n\nExtrinsic\n\nEither\n\nArt\n\nExplanatory\n\nExtrinsic\n\nEither\n\nNature\n\nExplanatory\n\nIntrinsic\n\nInternal*\n\n\n\nNote that the physical location of causes is not, in and of itself, a\ndetermining factor in differentiating causes. Indeed as established above, some\nnatural processes may involve external causes (*so long as they correspond to a\nprinciple intrinsic to the patient [78] ), and some artificial causes may happen\nto be within the patient.\n\n\n\n\nJOHNSONâ€™S INTERPRETATION"
}

In\norder to avoid confusion, we have adopted the term explanatory Â to refer to the\ngeneral sense in which both natural and artificial causes are contrasted with\nincidental causes because they are intrinsically (in virtue of what they are )\nrelated to their effects. We reserve the term intrinsic Â specifically for the\nrelation which holds between a natural principle and its effect.\n\nOn our interpretation therefore, we may distinguish natural, artificial, and\nincidental causes with regards to three types of relations, namely (1) an\nexplanatory or incidental relation (2) a physical relation of internality or\nexternality, and (3) an intrinsic or extrinsic essential relation (see the table\nbelow).\n\n\n\nExplanatory / Incidental\n\nIntrinsic / Extrinsic\n\nInternal/ External\n\nChance\n\nIncidental\n\nExtrinsic\n\nEither\n\nArt\n\nExplanatory\n\nExtrinsic\n\nEither\n\nNature\n\nExplanatory\n\nIntrinsic\n\nInternal*\n\n\n\nNote that the physical location of causes is not, in and of itself, a\ndetermining factor in differentiating causes. Indeed as established above, some\nnatural processes may involve external causes (*so long as they correspond to a\nprinciple intrinsic to the patient [78] ), and some artificial causes may happen\nto be within the patient.\n\n\n\n\nJOHNSONâ€™S INTERPRETATION\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"
  ]
}
[36m[llm/end][39m [[90m1:chain:RefineDocumentsChain > 36:chain:LLMChain > [1m37:llm:Ollama[22m[39m] [16.89s] Exiting LLM run with output: {
  "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "Based on the new context provided, I have further refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars challenge the traditional distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They argue that Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology must be systematically investigated to provide a more nuanced explanation. The identity-based connection between the agent and patient in natural causes is emphasized, where the agent and patient are essentially the same entity. The scholars highlight the difference between internal movement, which is like building a house, and external movement, which is more akin to moving wondrous automata. They reference Aristotle's statements in \"De Anima\" II 1 and \"Generation of Animals\" II 1, where he describes how the parts of an entity can contain a capacity for movement even when at rest, and how external contact can initiate this movement. The scholars emphasize that while external contact can move the entity, it is the internal movement that ultimately builds the house.\n\nIn order to differentiate between natural, artificial, and incidental causes, the scholars propose a distinction between an explanatory or incidental relation, an intrinsic or extrinsic essential relation, and a physical relation of internality or externality. They note that the physical location of causes is not a determining factor in differentiating causes, as some natural processes may involve external causes (as long as they correspond to a principle intrinsic to the patient), and some artificial causes may happen to be within the patient.\n\nOverall, the refined summary highlights the key points raised in the article, including the challenge to the common dichotomy between natural and artificial causes, the emphasis on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, and the distinction between internal and external movement."
      }
    ]
  ]
}

  "text": "JOHNSONâ€™S INTERPRETATION\n\nLet us now return to Johnsonâ€™s perspective and attempt a more detailed account\nof its shortcomings. First, it may be useful to include a comparative table in\norder to illustrate the contrast between his view and our own. Notice that the\nfirst two columns are merged into one, for as we have said, Johnson treats the\ntwo distinctions as coextensive. Note also that the physical location of causes\ndoes play a role in the differentiation of causes on his account.\n\nIntrinsic / Incidental\n\nInternal/ External\n\nChance\n\nIncidental\n\nExternal\n\nArt\n\nIncidental\n\nExternal\n\nNature\n\nIntrinsic\n\nInternal\n\n\n\n\nWe have said above that Johnson correctly establishes the internal and\nexplanatory [79] Â character of natural causes, but then proceeds to use the\nterms interchangeably, and we are now in a position to examine and challenge\nthis last step. In section 2.7 of his book, Johnson contrasts explanatory causes\nwith incidental ones. In addressing the difficulty of delineating between the\ntwo, he claims that â€œthe solution is to come up with a means of distinguishing\nbetween uses of an eye that are natural from those that are incidentalâ€ [80] Â \nthus Â contrasting natural and incidental causes, seemingly forgetting that\nAristotleâ€™s own illustration of explanatory causes (cited by Johnson himself on\nthe previous page) is taken from the domain of craft. A charitable reading of\nJohnsonâ€™s comment could suppose that he uses â€˜naturalâ€™ loosely, in the sense of\nâ€˜essentialâ€™ and not specifically in opposition to craft i.e. that he means Â to\nsay that the solution is to come up with a means of distinguishing between uses\nof an eye which are essentially related to eyeness from those which are merely\nincidental. However, what he says elsewhere indicates that he does mean to\noppose natural and incidental Â  causes and consequently, explanatory and\nartificial ones. [81] Â Johnsonâ€™s reason for identifying internal and explanatory\ncauses is most clearly laid out on p.202-203, where he cites a passage from De\nAnima Â which establishes that self-movers cannot be moved by something else\nintrinsically, and that similarly, a process which is for the sake of an\nintrinsic final cause cannot occur for the sake of Â an external good.\n\nAn animal may be pushed along by force but something that has been moved by\nitself included in its substance cannot be moved by something else except\ncoincidentally - just as what is intrinsically good because of itself cannot be\ngood because of something else or for the sake of something else. ( De An. Â I 3,\n406 b8) [82]\n\n\n\nFrom this, Johnson infers that, since natural substances have intrinsic\npurposes, any other good they contribute to is incidental to them. On this view,\ninternal, natural, and explanatory causes are equivalent i.e. to have a nature\nis to have an internal cause, and this is the same as to say an explanatory\ncause; whereas all external causes are incidental, and thus scientifically\nirrelevant."
}

  "text": "Based on the provided context, I have further refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They argue that Johnson's perspective on intrinsic teleology must be systematically investigated to provide a more nuanced explanation. The scholars highlight the difference between internal movement, which is like building a house, and external movement, which is more akin to moving wondrous automata. They reference Aristotle's statements in \"De Anima\" II 1 and \"Generation of Animals\" II 1, where he describes how the parts of an entity can contain a capacity for movement even when at rest, and how external contact can initiate this movement. The scholars emphasize that while external contact can move the entity, it is the internal movement that ultimately builds the house.\n\nIn order to differentiate between natural, artificial, and incidental causes, the scholars propose a distinction between an explanatory or incidental relation, an intrinsic or extrinsic essential relation, and a physical relation of internality or externality. They note that the physical location of causes is not a determining factor in differentiating causes, as some natural processes may involve external causes (as long as they correspond to a principle intrinsic to the patient), and some artificial causes may happen to be within the patient.\n\nOverall, the refined summary highlights the key points raised in the article, including the challenge to Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes, the emphasis on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, and the distinction between internal and external movement."
}

The scholars highlight the difference between internal movement, which is like building a house, and external movement, which is more akin to moving wondrous automata. They reference Aristotle's statements in \"De Anima\" II 1 and \"Generation of Animals\" II 1, where he describes how the parts of an entity can contain a capacity for movement even when at rest, and how external contact can initiate this movement. Â The\nfirst part of the analogy establishes that the external efficient cause of an\nanimalâ€™s locomotion is necessarily incidental because animals are by nature\nself-movers in this respect . Recall however, that Aristotle says elsewhere that\nsome animal motions (in fact all but locomotion) require the intervention of an\nexternal force. [83] Â Thus when he says that self-movers cannot be moved\nintrinsically by external agents, it is clear that he has in mind only the\nrestricted sense in which animals move themselves (locally), and that it would\nbe a mistake to interpret him as asserting that any change which is externally\ncaused ( e.g. Â respiration) is incidental to animals.\n\nBearing this in mind, Â if we now consider the second part of the analogy which\nconcerns final causes, it becomes apparent that Aristotleâ€™s claim that â€œwhat is\nintrinsically good because of itself cannot be good because of something else or\nfor the sake of something else â€ Â  does Â not entail, as Johnson argues, that a\nnatural substance can never Â  be said to act for the sake of Â another substance\nexcept incidentally. Rather, we should understand this affirmation in the\nlimited sense that the self-actualization of natural substances, because it is\nfor the sake of Â an intrinsic final cause, does not have instrumental value. For\ninstance, we should say that the growth of a horse, because it is for the sake\nof an intrinsic purpose (the actualization of its form), cannot be explained\nwith reference to an external good. However, the fact that its growth is not for\nthe sake of an external good does not exclude the possibility that other aspects\nof its natural life ( e.g. Â some features of its feeding habits) Â may be\nexplained with reference to an end which does not, strictly speaking, belong to\nthe horse intrinsically ( e.g. Â the good order of the ecosystem it inhabits).\nConsequently, we contend Â  that the De Anima Â passage which Johnson cites in\nsupport for his identification of internal and explanatory causes does not in\nfact exclude the possibility that some Â external causes may be scientifically\nrelevant, and therefore does not give ground to his implicit premise that there\nexists no middle ground between the Â self-actualization and arbitrary use of\nnatural substances. [84]"

They argue that Johnson's perspective on intrinsic teleology must be systematically investigated to provide a more nuanced explanation. The scholars highlight the difference between internal movement, which is like building a house, and external movement, which is more akin to moving wondrous automata. They reference Aristotle's statements in \"De Anima\" II 1 and \"Generation of Animals\" II 1, where he describes how the parts of an entity can contain a capacity for movement even when at rest, and how external contact can initiate this movement. The scholars emphasize that while external contact can move the entity, it is the internal movement that ultimately builds the house.\n\nIn order to differentiate between natural, artificial, and incidental causes, the scholars propose a distinction between an explanatory or incidental relation, an intrinsic or extrinsic essential relation, and a physical relation of internality or externality. Â The\nfirst part of the analogy establishes that the external efficient cause of an\nanimalâ€™s locomotion is necessarily incidental because animals are by nature\nself-movers in this respect . Recall however, that Aristotle says elsewhere that\nsome animal motions (in fact all but locomotion) require the intervention of an\nexternal force. [83] Â Thus when he says that self-movers cannot be moved\nintrinsically by external agents, it is clear that he has in mind only the\nrestricted sense in which animals move themselves (locally), and that it would\nbe a mistake to interpret him as asserting that any change which is externally\ncaused ( e.g. Â respiration) is incidental to animals.\n\nBearing this in mind, Â if we now consider the second part of the analogy which\nconcerns final causes, it becomes apparent that Aristotleâ€™s claim that â€œwhat is\nintrinsically good because of itself cannot be good because of something else or\nfor the sake of something else â€ Â  does Â not entail, as Johnson argues, that a\nnatural substance can never Â  be said to act for the sake of Â another substance\nexcept incidentally. Rather, we should understand this affirmation in the\nlimited sense that the self-actualization of natural substances, because it is\nfor the sake of Â an intrinsic final cause, does not have instrumental value. For\ninstance, we should say that the growth of a horse, because it is for the sake\nof an intrinsic purpose (the actualization of its form), cannot be explained\nwith reference to an external good. However, the fact that its growth is not for\nthe sake of an external good does not exclude the possibility that other aspects\nof its natural life ( e.g. Â some features of its feeding habits) Â may be\nexplained with reference to an end which does not, strictly speaking, belong to\nthe horse intrinsically ( e.g. Â the good order of the ecosystem it inhabits).\nConsequently, we contend Â  that the De Anima Â passage which Johnson cites in\nsupport for his identification of internal and explanatory causes does not in\nfact exclude the possibility that some Â external causes may be scientifically\nrelevant, and therefore does not give ground to his implicit premise that there\nexists no middle ground between the Â self-actualization and arbitrary use of\nnatural substances.   "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "The scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They argue that Johnson's perspective on intrinsic teleology must be systematically investigated to provide a more nuanced explanation. The scholars highlight the difference between internal movement, which is like building a house, and external movement, which is more akin to moving wondrous automata. They reference Aristotle's statements in \"De Anima\" II 1 and \"Generation of Animals\" II 1, where he describes how the parts of an entity can contain a capacity for movement even when at rest, and how external contact can initiate this movement. The scholars emphasize that while external contact can move the entity, it is the internal movement that ultimately builds the house.\n\nTo differentiate between natural, artificial, and incidental causes, the scholars propose a distinction between an explanatory or incidental relation, an intrinsic or extrinsic essential relation, and a physical relation of internality or externality. They note that the physical location of causes is not a determining factor in differentiating causes, as some natural processes may involve external causes (as long as they correspond to a principle intrinsic to the patient), and some artificial causes may happen to be within the patient.\n\nThe scholars also address a portion of the article where Johnson argues that Aristotle's claim that \"what is intrinsically good because of itself cannot be good because of something else or for the sake of something else\" does not entail that a natural substance can never be said to act for the sake of another substance except incidentally. The scholars argue that while the self-actualization of natural substances, because it is for the sake of an intrinsic final cause, does not have instrumental value, other aspects of its natural life may be explained with reference to an end which does not, strictly speaking, belong to the substance (e.g. the good order of the ecosystem it inhabits). Therefore, they contend that the De Anima passage does not give ground to Johnson's implicit premise that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of natural substances.\n\nIn summary, the scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes and propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. They also differentiate between different types of causes and argue that while internal movement is essential for building the house, external contact can initiate movement but ultimately it is the internal movement that builds the house."
      }
    ]
  ]
}

  "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "The scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They argue that Johnson's perspective on intrinsic teleology must be systematically investigated to provide a more nuanced explanation. The scholars highlight the difference between internal movement, which is like building a house, and external movement, which is more akin to moving wondrous automata. They reference Aristotle's statements in \"De Anima\" II 1 and \"Generation of Animals\" II 1, where he describes how the parts of an entity can contain a capacity for movement even when at rest, and how external contact can initiate this movement. The scholars emphasize that while external contact can move the entity, it is the internal movement that ultimately builds the house.\n\nTo differentiate between natural, artificial, and incidental causes, the scholars propose a distinction between an explanatory or incidental relation, an intrinsic or extrinsic essential relation, and a physical relation of internality or externality. They note that the physical location of causes is not a determining factor in differentiating causes, as some natural processes may involve external causes (as long as they correspond to a principle intrinsic to the patient), and some artificial causes may happen to be within the patient.\n\nThe scholars also address a portion of the article where Johnson argues that Aristotle's claim that \"what is intrinsically good because of itself cannot be good because of something else or for the sake of something else\" does not entail that a natural substance can never be said to act for the sake of another substance except incidentally. The scholars argue that while the self-actualization of natural substances, because it is for the sake of an intrinsic final cause, does not have instrumental value, other aspects of its natural life may be explained with reference to an end which does not, strictly speaking, belong to the substance (e.g. the good order of the ecosystem it inhabits). Therefore, they contend that the De Anima passage does not give ground to Johnson's implicit premise that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of natural substances.\n\nIn summary, the scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes and propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. They also differentiate between different types of causes and argue that while internal movement is essential for building the house, external contact can initiate movement but ultimately it is the internal movement that builds the house."
      }
    ]
  ]

[36m[chain/end][39m [[90m1:chain:RefineDocumentsChain > [1m40:chain:LLMChain[22m[39m] [22.33s] Exiting Chain run with output: {
  "text": "The scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They argue that Johnson's perspective on intrinsic teleology must be systematically investigated to provide a more nuanced explanation. The scholars highlight the difference between internal movement, which is like building a house, and external movement, which is more akin to moving wondrous automata. They reference Aristotle's statements in \"De Anima\" II 1 and \"Generation of Animals\" II 1, where he describes how the parts of an entity can contain a capacity for movement even when at rest, and how external contact can initiate this movement. The scholars emphasize that while external contact can move the entity, it is the internal movement that ultimately builds the house.\n\nTo differentiate between natural, artificial, and incidental causes, the scholars propose a distinction between an explanatory or incidental relation, an intrinsic or extrinsic essential relation, and a physical relation of internality or externality. They note that the physical location of causes is not a determining factor in differentiating causes, as some natural processes may involve external causes (as long as they correspond to a principle intrinsic to the patient), and some artificial causes may happen to be within the patient.\n\nThe scholars also address a portion of the article where Johnson argues that Aristotle's claim that \"what is intrinsically good because of itself cannot be good because of something else or for the sake of something else\" does not entail that a natural substance can never be said to act for the sake of another substance except incidentally. The scholars argue that while the self-actualization of natural substances, because it is for the sake of an intrinsic final cause, does not have instrumental value, other aspects of its natural life may be explained with reference to an end which does not, strictly speaking, belong to the substance (e.g. the good order of the ecosystem it inhabits). Therefore, they contend that the De Anima passage does not give ground to Johnson's implicit premise that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of natural substances.\n\nIn summary, the scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes and propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. They also differentiate between different types of causes and argue that while internal movement is essential for building the house, external contact can initiate movement but ultimately it is the internal movement that builds the house."
}
[36m[chain/end][39m [[90m[1m1:chain:LLMChain[22m[39m] [22.33s] Exiting Chain run with output: {
  "text": "The scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They argue that Johnson's perspective on intrinsic teleology must be systematically investigated to provide a more nuanced explanation. The scholars highlight the difference between internal movement, which is like building a house, and external movement, which is more akin to moving wondrous automata. They reference Aristotle's statements in \"De Anima\" II 1 and \"Generation of Animals\" II 1, where he describes how the parts of an entity can contain a capacity for movement even when at rest, and how external contact can initiate this movement. The scholars emphasize that while external contact can move the entity, it is the internal movement that ultimately builds the house.\n\nTo differentiate between natural, artificial, and incidental causes, the scholars propose a distinction between an explanatory or incidental relation, an intrinsic or extrinsic essential relation, and a physical relation of internality or externality. They note that the physical location of causes is not a determining factor in differentiating causes, as some natural processes may involve external causes (as long as they correspond to a principle intrinsic to the patient), and some artificial causes may happen to be within the patient.\n\nThe scholars also address a portion of the article where Johnson argues that Aristotle's claim that \"what is intrinsically good because of itself cannot be good because of something else or for the sake of something else\" does not entail that a natural substance can never be said to act for the sake of another substance except incidentally. The scholars argue that while the self-actualization of natural substances, because it is for the sake of an intrinsic final cause, does not have instrumental value, other aspects of its natural life may be explained with reference to an end which does not, strictly speaking, belong to the substance (e.g. the good order of the ecosystem it inhabits). Therefore, they contend that the De Anima passage does not give ground to Johnson's implicit premise that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of natural substances.\n\nIn summary, the scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes and propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. They also differentiate between different types of causes and argue that while internal movement is essential for building the house, external contact can initiate movement but ultimately it is the internal movement that builds the house."
}

They argue that Johnson's perspective on intrinsic teleology must be systematically investigated to provide a more nuanced explanation. The scholars highlight the difference between internal movement, which is like building a house, and external movement, which is more akin to moving wondrous automata. They reference Aristotle's statements in \"De Anima\" II 1 and \"Generation of Animals\" II 1, where he describes how the parts of an entity can contain a capacity for movement even when at rest, and how external contact can initiate this movement. The scholars emphasize that while external contact can move the entity, it is the internal movement that ultimately builds the house.\n\nTo differentiate between natural, artificial, and incidental causes, the scholars propose a distinction between an explanatory or incidental relation, an intrinsic or extrinsic essential relation, and a physical relation of internality or externality. They note that the physical location of causes is not a determining factor in differentiating causes, as some natural processes may involve external causes (as long as they correspond to a principle intrinsic to the patient), and some artificial causes may happen to be within the patient.\n\nThe scholars also address a portion of the article where Johnson argues that Aristotle's claim that \"what is intrinsically good because of itself cannot be good because of something else or for the sake of something else\" does not entail that a natural substance can never be said to act for the sake of another substance except incidentally. The scholars argue that while the self-actualization of natural substances, because it is for the sake of an intrinsic final cause, does not have instrumental value, other aspects of its natural life may be explained with reference to an end which does not, strictly speaking, belong to the substance (e.g. the good order of the ecosystem it inhabits). Therefore, they contend that the De Anima passage does not give ground to Johnson's implicit premise that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of natural substances.\n\nIn summary, the scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes and propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. They also differentiate between different types of causes and argue that while internal movement is essential for building the house, external contact can initiate movement but ultimately it is the internal movement that builds the house.",
  "text": "Thus far, we have challenged an interpretation [85] Â of the internality of\nnatural causes and of their opposition to artificial ones which, we contend,\ndoes not capture the nuances of Aristotleâ€™s perspective. In what follows, we\nwill contest two reductions of the scope of teleology which follow naturally\nfrom the dichotomous interpretation examined above. We will argue for a broader\nview of the scope of Aristotleâ€™s teleology which encompasses instrumentalization\nprocesses in both craft (chapter one) and nature (chapter two). We will then\nconclude with an overview of the consequences of our work for future research.\nWe will emphasize the fact that our perspective helps us to reframe some of the\nquestions outlined above in a more fruitful way.\n\n\nCHAPTER ONE\n\nCraft\n\n\n\nIn our first chapter, w e will investigate Aristotleâ€™s view of the relation of\nnature ( physis ) and the arts ( techne ) and clarify the nature of his\nobjections to the artificial Â teleological accounts of his predecessors. This\nwill allow us to develop a more accurate view of his primarily natural\nconception of goal-directedness. Through this, we will emphasize his\nnon-psychological understanding of purposes ( telos )."
}
[32m[chain/start][39m [[90m[1m1:chain:LLMChain[22m[39m] Entering Chain run with input: {
  "existing_answer": "The scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They argue that Johnson's perspective on intrinsic teleology must be systematically investigated to provide a more nuanced explanation. The scholars highlight the difference between internal movement, which is like building a house, and external movement, which is more akin to moving wondrous automata. They reference Aristotle's statements in \"De Anima\" II 1 and \"Generation of Animals\" II 1, where he describes how the parts of an entity can contain a capacity for movement even when at rest, and how external contact can initiate this movement. The scholars emphasize that while external contact can move the entity, it is the internal movement that ultimately builds the house.\n\nTo differentiate between natural, artificial, and incidental causes, the scholars propose a distinction between an explanatory or incidental relation, an intrinsic or extrinsic essential relation, and a physical relation of internality or externality. They note that the physical location of causes is not a determining factor in differentiating causes, as some natural processes may involve external causes (as long as they correspond to a principle intrinsic to the patient), and some artificial causes may happen to be within the patient.\n\nThe scholars also address a portion of the article where Johnson argues that Aristotle's claim that \"what is intrinsically good because of itself cannot be good because of something else or for the sake of something else\" does not entail that a natural substance can never be said to act for the sake of another substance except incidentally. The scholars argue that while the self-actualization of natural substances, because it is for the sake of an intrinsic final cause, does not have instrumental value, other aspects of its natural life may be explained with reference to an end which does not, strictly speaking, belong to the substance (e.g. the good order of the ecosystem it inhabits). Therefore, they contend that the De Anima passage does not give ground to Johnson's implicit premise that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of natural substances.\n\nIn summary, the scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes and propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. They also differentiate between different types of causes and argue that while internal movement is essential for building the house, external contact can initiate movement but ultimately it is the internal movement that builds the house.",
  "text": "Thus far, we have challenged an interpretation [85] Â of the internality of\nnatural causes and of their opposition to artificial ones which, we contend,\ndoes not capture the nuances of Aristotleâ€™s perspective. In what follows, we\nwill contest two reductions of the scope of teleology which follow naturally\nfrom the dichotomous interpretation examined above. We will argue for a broader\nview of the scope of Aristotleâ€™s teleology which encompasses instrumentalization\nprocesses in both craft (chapter one) and nature (chapter two). We will then\nconclude with an overview of the consequences of our work for future research.\nWe will emphasize the fact that our perspective helps us to reframe some of the\nquestions outlined above in a more fruitful way.\n\n\nCHAPTER ONE\n\nCraft\n\n\n\nIn our first chapter, w e will investigate Aristotleâ€™s view of the relation of\nnature ( physis ) and the arts ( techne ) and clarify the nature of his\nobjections to the artificial Â teleological accounts of his predecessors. This\nwill allow us to develop a more accurate view of his primarily natural\nconception of goal-directedness. Through this, we will emphasize his\nnon-psychological understanding of purposes ( telos )."
}

  "prompts": [
    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: The scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They argue that Johnson's perspective on intrinsic teleology must be systematically investigated to provide a more nuanced explanation. The scholars highlight the difference between internal movement, which is like building a house, and external movement, which is more akin to moving wondrous automata. They reference Aristotle's statements in \"De Anima\" II 1 and \"Generation of Animals\" II 1, where he describes how the parts of an entity can contain a capacity for movement even when at rest, and how external contact can initiate this movement. The scholars emphasize that while external contact can move the entity, it is the internal movement that ultimately builds the house.\n\nTo differentiate between natural, artificial, and incidental causes, the scholars propose a distinction between an explanatory or incidental relation, an intrinsic or extrinsic essential relation, and a physical relation of internality or externality. They note that the physical location of causes is not a determining factor in differentiating causes, as some natural processes may involve external causes (as long as they correspond to a principle intrinsic to the patient), and some artificial causes may happen to be within the patient.\n\nThe scholars also address a portion of the article where Johnson argues that Aristotle's claim that \"what is intrinsically good because of itself cannot be good because of something else or for the sake of something else\" does not entail that a natural substance can never be said to act for the sake of another substance except incidentally. The scholars argue that while the self-actualization of natural substances, because it is for the sake of an intrinsic final cause, does not have instrumental value, other aspects of its natural life may be explained with reference to an end which does not, strictly speaking, belong to the substance (e.g. the good order of the ecosystem it inhabits). Therefore, they contend that the De Anima passage does not give ground to Johnson's implicit premise that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of natural substances.\n\nIn summary, the scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes and propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. They also differentiate between different types of causes and argue that while internal movement is essential for building the house, external contact can initiate movement but ultimately it is the internal movement that builds the house.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nThus far, we have challenged an interpretation [85] Â of the internality of\nnatural causes and of their opposition to artificial ones which, we contend,\ndoes not capture the nuances of Aristotleâ€™s perspective. We will then\nconclude with an overview of the consequences of our work for future research.\nWe will emphasize the fact that our perspective helps us to reframe some of the\nquestions outlined above in a more fruitful way.\n\n\nCHAPTER ONE\n\nCraft\n\n\n\nIn our first chapter, w e will investigate Aristotleâ€™s view of the relation of\nnature ( physis ) and the arts ( techne ) and clarify the nature of his\nobjections to the artificial Â teleological accounts of his predecessors.   "prompts": [
    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: The scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They argue that Johnson's perspective on intrinsic teleology must be systematically investigated to provide a more nuanced explanation. The scholars highlight the difference between internal movement, which is like building a house, and external movement, which is more akin to moving wondrous automata. They reference Aristotle's statements in \"De Anima\" II 1 and \"Generation of Animals\" II 1, where he describes how the parts of an entity can contain a capacity for movement even when at rest, and how external contact can initiate this movement. The scholars emphasize that while external contact can move the entity, it is the internal movement that ultimately builds the house.\n\nTo differentiate between natural, artificial, and incidental causes, the scholars propose a distinction between an explanatory or incidental relation, an intrinsic or extrinsic essential relation, and a physical relation of internality or externality. They note that the physical location of causes is not a determining factor in differentiating causes, as some natural processes may involve external causes (as long as they correspond to a principle intrinsic to the patient), and some artificial causes may happen to be within the patient.\n\nThe scholars also address a portion of the article where Johnson argues that Aristotle's claim that \"what is intrinsically good because of itself cannot be good because of something else or for the sake of something else\" does not entail that a natural substance can never be said to act for the sake of another substance except incidentally. The scholars argue that while the self-actualization of natural substances, because it is for the sake of an intrinsic final cause, does not have instrumental value, other aspects of its natural life may be explained with reference to an end which does not, strictly speaking, belong to the substance (e.g. the good order of the ecosystem it inhabits). Therefore, they contend that the De Anima passage does not give ground to Johnson's implicit premise that there exists no middle ground between the self-actualization and arbitrary use of natural substances.\n\nIn summary, the scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes and propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. They also differentiate between different types of causes and argue that while internal movement is essential for building the house, external contact can initiate movement but ultimately it is the internal movement that builds the house.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nThus far, we have challenged an interpretation [85] Â of the internality of\nnatural causes and of their opposition to artificial ones which, we contend,\ndoes not capture the nuances of Aristotleâ€™s perspective.   "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "In this article, scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, differentiating between internal movement, external contact, and instrumentalization processes in both craft and nature. The scholars argue that while internal movement is essential for building the house, external contact can initiate movement but ultimately it is the internal movement that builds the house. They also address a portion of Johnson's article where he argues that Aristotle's claim that \"what is intrinsically good because of itself cannot be good because of something else or for the sake of something else\" does not entail that a natural substance can never be said to act for the sake of another substance except incidentally. The scholars contend that while the self-actualization of natural substances may not have instrumental value, other aspects of its natural life may be explained with reference to an end which does not strictly speaking belong to the substance.\n\nIn the next chapter, the scholars will investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, and clarify the nature of his objections to artificial teleological accounts of his predecessors. This will allow them to develop a more accurate view of his primarily natural conception of goal-directedness, and emphasize his non-psychological understanding of purposes."
      }
    ]
  ]

They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, differentiating between internal movement, external contact, and instrumentalization processes in both craft and nature. The scholars argue that while internal movement is essential for building the house, external contact can initiate movement but ultimately it is the internal movement that builds the house. They also address a portion of Johnson's article where he argues that Aristotle's claim that \"what is intrinsically good because of itself cannot be good because of something else or for the sake of something else\" does not entail that a natural substance can never be said to act for the sake of another substance except incidentally. The scholars contend that while the self-actualization of natural substances may not have instrumental value, other aspects of its natural life may be explained with reference to an end which does not strictly speaking belong to the substance.\n\nIn the next chapter, the scholars will investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, and clarify the nature of his objections to artificial teleological accounts of his predecessors. This will allow them to develop a more accurate view of his primarily natural conception of goal-directedness, and emphasize his non-psychological understanding of purposes."

  "text": "In this article, scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, differentiating between internal movement, external contact, and instrumentalization processes in both craft and nature. The scholars argue that while internal movement is essential for building the house, external contact can initiate movement but ultimately it is the internal movement that builds the house. They also address a portion of Johnson's article where he argues that Aristotle's claim that \"what is intrinsically good because of itself cannot be good because of something else or for the sake of something else\" does not entail that a natural substance can never be said to act for the sake of another substance except incidentally. The scholars contend that while the self-actualization of natural substances may not have instrumental value, other aspects of its natural life may be explained with reference to an end which does not strictly speaking belong to the substance.\n\nIn the next chapter, the scholars will investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, and clarify the nature of his objections to artificial teleological accounts of his predecessors. This will allow them to develop a more accurate view of his primarily natural conception of goal-directedness, and emphasize his non-psychological understanding of purposes."

  "text": "In this article, scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, differentiating between internal movement, external contact, and instrumentalization processes in both craft and nature. The scholars argue that while internal movement is essential for building the house, external contact can initiate movement but ultimately it is the internal movement that builds the house. They also address a portion of Johnson's article where he argues that Aristotle's claim that \"what is intrinsically good because of itself cannot be good because of something else or for the sake of something else\" does not entail that a natural substance can never be said to act for the sake of another substance except incidentally. The scholars contend that while the self-actualization of natural substances may not have instrumental value, other aspects of its natural life may be explained with reference to an end which does not strictly speaking belong to the substance.\n\nIn the next chapter, the scholars will investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, and clarify the nature of his objections to artificial teleological accounts of his predecessors. This will allow them to develop a more accurate view of his primarily natural conception of goal-directedness, and emphasize his non-psychological understanding of purposes."

  "existing_answer": "In this article, scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, differentiating between internal movement, external contact, and instrumentalization processes in both craft and nature. The scholars argue that while internal movement is essential for building the house, external contact can initiate movement but ultimately it is the internal movement that builds the house. They also address a portion of Johnson's article where he argues that Aristotle's claim that \"what is intrinsically good because of itself cannot be good because of something else or for the sake of something else\" does not entail that a natural substance can never be said to act for the sake of another substance except incidentally. The scholars contend that while the self-actualization of natural substances may not have instrumental value, other aspects of its natural life may be explained with reference to an end which does not strictly speaking belong to the substance.\n\nIn the next chapter, the scholars will investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, and clarify the nature of his objections to artificial teleological accounts of his predecessors. This will allow them to develop a more accurate view of his primarily natural conception of goal-directedness, and emphasize his non-psychological understanding of purposes.",
  "text": "If Johnson and like-minded scholars are right that Aristotelian teleology (and\nscience generally) Â is strictly concerned with intrinsic and natural causes, it\nis Â curious that Aristotle so Â frequently relies on craft analogies to teach us\nabout teleological change. [86] Â Indeed, Â if Aristotle considered all external\ncauses to be incidental, it is surprising that he considered craft-based\nexamples to be so enlightening. We have indicated above that a common way to\ncontrast natural and artificial teleology rests on a sharp demarcation between\nnatural processes of self-actualization (which are for the sake of an end in an\nontological sense) and artificial instrumentalization processes (which are for\nthe sake of a goal in a psychological sense). [87] Â In this view, craft\nanalogies can be useful insofar as artificial processes manifest a likeness to\ngenuine (natural) goal-directedness, but accounts of their pedagogical value are\noften [88] Â accompanied by a warning that the comparison must not be taken too\nseriously, with a special emphasis on the fact that the analogy is not meant to\nestablish that natural processes are the result of intentions or desires. This,\nit is argued, would constitute a dangerous overstretch of the analogy. [89] Â  In\nthis view, while it may at first [90] Â  be useful for natural philosophers to\nconsider cases of artificial goal-directedness in order to familiarize\nthemselves with means-end relations, they should then leave these considerations\nbehind as they move on to investigate natural goal-directedness. In short, this\nview presupposes that genuine teleological accounts do not, in truth, apply to\nthe domain of craft. Because the scholars who adopt this view usually do not\nconsider artificial causes to be genuine explanatory causes, the heuristic value\nof craft analogies rests on fairly superficial [91] Â similarities and it makes\nit questionable why Aristotle would so consistently rely on them all throughout\nthe corpus (and not just at the very beginning of the Physics Â for instance).\n[92] Â In short, Aristotle's consistent use of craft analogies suggests that it\nrests on a more fundamental symmetry [93] Â of natural and artificial causes than\ntheir view allows.\n\nIn what follows we will challenge the dichotomous view of nature and the arts\nand try to provide a more accurate account of the analogy which Aristotle\nestablishes between them. We will also clarify Aristotleâ€™s objection to\nartificial teleology which, we will argue, rests not Â on an exclusion of\nartificial processes from the scope of teleological explanations, but rather on\nhis view of their relation to natural ones. We will suggest that Aristotle\nconsidered the similarities between craft Â and nature to be Â very profound and\nthat reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper\ngrasp of their unity.\n\n\n\n\nCRAFT ANALOGIES"
}
