  "existing_answer": "In this article, scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, differentiating between internal movement, external contact, and instrumentalization processes in both craft and nature. The scholars argue that while internal movement is essential for building the house, external contact can initiate movement but ultimately it is the internal movement that builds the house. They also address a portion of Johnson's article where he argues that Aristotle's claim that \"what is intrinsically good because of itself cannot be good because of something else or for the sake of something else\" does not entail that a natural substance can never be said to act for the sake of another substance except incidentally. The scholars contend that while the self-actualization of natural substances may not have instrumental value, other aspects of its natural life may be explained with reference to an end which does not strictly speaking belong to the substance.\n\nIn the next chapter, the scholars will investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, and clarify the nature of his objections to artificial teleological accounts of his predecessors. This will allow them to develop a more accurate view of his primarily natural conception of goal-directedness, and emphasize his non-psychological understanding of purposes.",
  "text": "If Johnson and like-minded scholars are right that Aristotelian teleology (and\nscience generally) Â is strictly concerned with intrinsic and natural causes, it\nis Â curious that Aristotle so Â frequently relies on craft analogies to teach us\nabout teleological change. [86] Â Indeed, Â if Aristotle considered all external\ncauses to be incidental, it is surprising that he considered craft-based\nexamples to be so enlightening. We have indicated above that a common way to\ncontrast natural and artificial teleology rests on a sharp demarcation between\nnatural processes of self-actualization (which are for the sake of an end in an\nontological sense) and artificial instrumentalization processes (which are for\nthe sake of a goal in a psychological sense). [87] Â In this view, craft\nanalogies can be useful insofar as artificial processes manifest a likeness to\ngenuine (natural) goal-directedness, but accounts of their pedagogical value are\noften [88] Â accompanied by a warning that the comparison must not be taken too\nseriously, with a special emphasis on the fact that the analogy is not meant to\nestablish that natural processes are the result of intentions or desires. This,\nit is argued, would constitute a dangerous overstretch of the analogy. [89] Â  In\nthis view, while it may at first [90] Â  be useful for natural philosophers to\nconsider cases of artificial goal-directedness in order to familiarize\nthemselves with means-end relations, they should then leave these considerations\nbehind as they move on to investigate natural goal-directedness. In short, this\nview presupposes that genuine teleological accounts do not, in truth, apply to\nthe domain of craft. Because the scholars who adopt this view usually do not\nconsider artificial causes to be genuine explanatory causes, the heuristic value\nof craft analogies rests on fairly superficial [91] Â similarities and it makes\nit questionable why Aristotle would so consistently rely on them all throughout\nthe corpus (and not just at the very beginning of the Physics Â for instance).\n[92] Â In short, Aristotle's consistent use of craft analogies suggests that it\nrests on a more fundamental symmetry [93] Â of natural and artificial causes than\ntheir view allows.\n\nIn what follows we will challenge the dichotomous view of nature and the arts\nand try to provide a more accurate account of the analogy which Aristotle\nestablishes between them. We will also clarify Aristotleâ€™s objection to\nartificial teleology which, we will argue, rests not Â on an exclusion of\nartificial processes from the scope of teleological explanations, but rather on\nhis view of their relation to natural ones. We will suggest that Aristotle\nconsidered the similarities between craft Â and nature to be Â very profound and\nthat reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper\ngrasp of their unity.\n\n\n\n\nCRAFT ANALOGIES"

[32m[llm/start][39m [[90m1:chain:LLMChain > [1m2:llm:Ollama[22m[39m] Entering LLM run with input: {
  "prompts": [
    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: In this article, scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, differentiating between internal movement, external contact, and instrumentalization processes in both craft and nature. The scholars argue that while internal movement is essential for building the house, external contact can initiate movement but ultimately it is the internal movement that builds the house. They also address a portion of Johnson's article where he argues that Aristotle's claim that \"what is intrinsically good because of itself cannot be good because of something else or for the sake of something else\" does not entail that a natural substance can never be said to act for the sake of another substance except incidentally. The scholars contend that while the self-actualization of natural substances may not have instrumental value, other aspects of its natural life may be explained with reference to an end which does not strictly speaking belong to the substance.\n\nIn the next chapter, the scholars will investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, and clarify the nature of his objections to artificial teleological accounts of his predecessors. This will allow them to develop a more accurate view of his primarily natural conception of goal-directedness, and emphasize his non-psychological understanding of purposes.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nIf Johnson and like-minded scholars are right that Aristotelian teleology (and\nscience generally) Â is strictly concerned with intrinsic and natural causes, it\nis Â curious that Aristotle so Â frequently relies on craft analogies to teach us\nabout teleological change. [86] Â Indeed, Â if Aristotle considered all external\ncauses to be incidental, it is surprising that he considered craft-based\nexamples to be so enlightening. We have indicated above that a common way to\ncontrast natural and artificial teleology rests on a sharp demarcation between\nnatural processes of self-actualization (which are for the sake of an end in an\nontological sense) and artificial instrumentalization processes (which are for\nthe sake of a goal in a psychological sense). [87] Â In this view, craft\nanalogies can be useful insofar as artificial processes manifest a likeness to\ngenuine (natural) goal-directedness, but accounts of their pedagogical value are\noften [88] Â accompanied by a warning that the comparison must not be taken too\nseriously, with a special emphasis on the fact that the analogy is not meant to\nestablish that natural processes are the result of intentions or desires. This,\nit is argued, would constitute a dangerous overstretch of the analogy. [89] Â  In\nthis view, while it may at first [90] Â  be useful for natural philosophers to\nconsider cases of artificial goal-directedness in order to familiarize\nthemselves with means-end relations, they should then leave these considerations\nbehind as they move on to investigate natural goal-directedness. In short, this\nview presupposes that genuine teleological accounts do not, in truth, apply to\nthe domain of craft. Because the scholars who adopt this view usually do not\nconsider artificial causes to be genuine explanatory causes, the heuristic value\nof craft analogies rests on fairly superficial [91] Â similarities and it makes\nit questionable why Aristotle would so consistently rely on them all throughout\nthe corpus (and not just at the very beginning of the Physics Â for instance).\n[92] Â In short, Aristotle's consistent use of craft analogies suggests that it\nrests on a more fundamental symmetry [93] Â of natural and artificial causes than\ntheir view allows.\n\nIn what follows we will challenge the dichotomous view of nature and the arts\nand try to provide a more accurate account of the analogy which Aristotle\nestablishes between them. We will also clarify Aristotleâ€™s objection to\nartificial teleology which, we will argue, rests not Â on an exclusion of\nartificial processes from the scope of teleological explanations, but rather on\nhis view of their relation to natural ones. We will suggest that Aristotle\nconsidered the similarities between craft Â and nature to be Â very profound and\nthat reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper\ngrasp of their unity.\n\n\n\n\nCRAFT ANALOGIES\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"
  ]
}

  "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "In this article, scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, differentiating between internal movement, external contact, and instrumentalization processes in both craft and nature. The scholars argue that while internal movement is essential for building the house, external contact can initiate movement but ultimately it is the internal movement that builds the house. They also address Johnson's argument that Aristotle's claim that \"what is intrinsically good because of itself cannot be good because of something else or for the sake of something else\" does not entail that a natural substance can never be said to act for the sake of another substance except incidentally. The scholars contend that while the self-actualization of natural substances may not have instrumental value, other aspects of its natural life may be explained with reference to an end which does not strictly speaking belong to the substance.\n\nThe scholars also investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, and clarify the nature of his objections to artificial teleological accounts of his predecessors. They suggest that Aristotle considered the similarities between craft and nature to be very profound, and that reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper grasp of their unity.\n\nIn summary, the article challenges Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world, and proposes a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. The scholars also investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, and clarify the nature of his objections to artificial teleological accounts of his predecessors."
      }
    ]
  ]

They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, differentiating between internal movement, external contact, and instrumentalization processes in both craft and nature. The scholars argue that while internal movement is essential for building the house, external contact can initiate movement but ultimately it is the internal movement that builds the house. They also address Johnson's argument that Aristotle's claim that \"what is intrinsically good because of itself cannot be good because of something else or for the sake of something else\" does not entail that a natural substance can never be said to act for the sake of another substance except incidentally.   "text": "CRAFT ANALOGIES Â \n\nIn her article Nature and Craft in Aristotelian teleology, Sarah Broadie\nidentifies the points of analogy and dis-analogy between craft and nature. Her\ncontribution is significant because she addresses the question in a\ncomprehensive manner and develops her analysis well beyond the common and\nsimplistic view that the analogy is meant to establish that nature, like art, is\npurposeful. She notes that the goal-directedness of nature is in fact often\ntaken as an established starting point, and that the analogy rather serves to\nspecify what it means to say that natural substances are goal-directed. She\nnotes five points of analogy, [94] Â  i.e. Â five things which the craft analogy\nis meant to teach us about natural teleology, Â  t hree of which Â  are worth\nexamining for our present purposes.\n\nThe first [95] Â is the species-specific character Â of artificial goal-directed\nÂ processes . Broadie notes that c rafts, unlike many Â activities, mirror the\nspecific differentiation of the natural world. Accordingly, she thinks Â the\ncraft analogy serves to establish that natural substances , like craftsmen, are\nagents which direct a developmental process towards a specific Â form or\nstructure. Thus an important Â contribution of the craft analogy is that it\nallows us to grasp goal-directedness as a Â specifically differentiated rather\nthan uniform phenomena . As she puts it; â€œwithout the craft analogy, we should\nstill have teleological Â explanation, but not the Aristotelian concept of\nnatural substances.â€ [96] Â  In short, the craft analog y Â  teaches us that\ngoal-directedness is rooted in the specific nature Â  of the being which is\nactualized through a Â teleological Â process. In li ne with this, c onsider the\nfollowing craft analogy taken from the treatise on Respiration :\n\nT he arts t hemselves achieve these different results, for that by using fire as\nan instrument they soften, liquefy, and desiccate substances, and some they\ntemper. Individual natures work in the same way, and so they differ one from\nanother; so that it is ridiculous to judge by externals; for whether we regard\nthe heat as separating or refining, or whatever the effect of warming or burning\nis, the results will be different according to the different natures of the\nagencies which employ it. But while the crafts use the fire merely as an\ninstrument, nature uses it as a material as well. ( Resp. 485 a30-b5) [97]"
}

  "text": "The scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world, proposing a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. They argue that internal movement is essential for building the house, but external contact can initiate movement, and it is the internal movement that builds the house. The scholars also investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, clarifying the nature of his objections to artificial teleological accounts of his predecessors. They suggest that Aristotle considered the similarities between craft and nature to be very profound, and reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper grasp of their unity.\n\nIn the portion provided, Sarah Broadie identifies points of analogy and dis-analogy between craft and nature, specifically highlighting the species-specific character of artificial goal-directed processes. She argues that natural substances, like craftsmen, are agents which direct a developmental process towards a specific form or structure, and that goal-directedness is rooted in the specific nature of the being which is actualized through a teleological process. The scholars also provide an Aristotle quote from the treatise on Respiration, illustrating how the arts themselves achieve different results depending on the individual natures of the agencies which employ them, while nature uses fire as both an instrument and material."
}

  "text": "The scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world, proposing a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. They argue that internal movement is essential for building the house, but external contact can initiate movement, and it is the internal movement that builds the house. The scholars also investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, clarifying the nature of his objections to artificial teleological accounts of his predecessors. They suggest that Aristotle considered the similarities between craft and nature to be very profound, and reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper grasp of their unity.\n\nIn the portion provided, Sarah Broadie identifies points of analogy and dis-analogy between craft and nature, specifically highlighting the species-specific character of artificial goal-directed processes. The scholars also provide an Aristotle quote from the treatise on Respiration, illustrating how the arts themselves achieve different results depending on the individual natures of the agencies which employ them, while nature uses fire as both an instrument and material."

        "text": "The scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. The scholars investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, clarifying the nature of his objections to artificial teleological accounts of his predecessors. They suggest that Aristotle considered the similarities between craft and nature to be very profound, and reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper grasp of their unity.\n\nSarah Broadie identifies points of analogy and dis-analogy between craft and nature, specifically highlighting the species-specific character of artificial goal-directed processes. In contrast, the cognitive faculties which allow a craftsman to practice his art are essentially related to the production of a specific artifact. Broadie argues that Aristotle deliberately establishes the comparison with craft instead of other goal-directed activities because he wants to emphasize the explanatory character of natural causes.\n\nIn summary, the scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world, proposing a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. They investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, highlighting the similarities between craft and nature, and reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper grasp of their unity. Broadie identifies points of analogy and dis-analogy between craft and nature, emphasizing the species-specific character of artificial goal-directed processes, and argues that goal-directedness must be understood in relation to the nature of specific beings."

They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. The scholars investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, clarifying the nature of his objections to artificial teleological accounts of his predecessors. They suggest that Aristotle considered the similarities between craft and nature to be very profound, and reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper grasp of their unity.\n\nSarah Broadie identifies points of analogy and dis-analogy between craft and nature, specifically highlighting the species-specific character of artificial goal-directed processes. In contrast, the cognitive faculties which allow a craftsman to practice his art are essentially related to the production of a specific artifact. Broadie argues that Aristotle deliberately establishes the comparison with craft instead of other goal-directed activities because he wants to emphasize the explanatory character of natural causes.\n\nIn summary, the scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world, proposing a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. They investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, highlighting the similarities between craft and nature, and reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper grasp of their unity.   "text": "The scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. The scholars investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, clarifying the nature of his objections to artificial teleological accounts of his predecessors. They suggest that Aristotle considered the similarities between craft and nature to be very profound, and reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper grasp of their unity.\n\nSarah Broadie identifies points of analogy and dis-analogy between craft and nature, specifically highlighting the species-specific character of artificial goal-directed processes. She argues that natural substances, like craftsmen, are agents which direct a developmental process towards a specific form or structure, and that goal-directedness is rooted in the specific nature of the being which is actualized through a teleological process.\n\nThe scholars also provide an Aristotle quote from the treatise on Respiration, illustrating how the arts themselves achieve different results depending on the individual natures of the agencies which employ them, while nature uses fire as both an instrument and material. They emphasize that goal-directedness must be understood in relation to the nature of specific beings.\n\nThe second point of analogy highlighted by Broadie is that many goal-directed activities are incidental to the agent, such as gossiping, which does not belong to man in virtue of what he is. In contrast, the cognitive faculties which allow a craftsman to practice his art are essentially related to the production of a specific artifact. Broadie argues that Aristotle deliberately establishes the comparison with craft instead of other goal-directed activities because he wants to emphasize the explanatory character of natural causes.\n\nIn summary, the scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world, proposing a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. They investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, highlighting the similarities between craft and nature, and reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper grasp of their unity. Broadie identifies points of analogy and dis-analogy between craft and nature, emphasizing the species-specific character of artificial goal-directed processes, and argues that goal-directedness must be understood in relation to the nature of specific beings."

  "text": "The scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. The scholars investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, clarifying the nature of his objections to artificial teleological accounts of his predecessors. They suggest that Aristotle considered the similarities between craft and nature to be very profound, and reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper grasp of their unity.\n\nSarah Broadie identifies points of analogy and dis-analogy between craft and nature, specifically highlighting the species-specific character of artificial goal-directed processes. She argues that natural substances, like craftsmen, are agents which direct a developmental process towards a specific form or structure, and that goal-directedness is rooted in the specific nature of the being which is actualized through a teleological process.\n\nThe scholars also provide an Aristotle quote from the treatise on Respiration, illustrating how the arts themselves achieve different results depending on the individual natures of the agencies which employ them, while nature uses fire as both an instrument and material. They emphasize that goal-directedness must be understood in relation to the nature of specific beings.\n\nThe second point of analogy highlighted by Broadie is that many goal-directed activities are incidental to the agent, such as gossiping, which does not belong to man in virtue of what he is. In contrast, the cognitive faculties which allow a craftsman to practice his art are essentially related to the production of a specific artifact. Broadie argues that Aristotle deliberately establishes the comparison with craft instead of other goal-directed activities because he wants to emphasize the explanatory character of natural causes.\n\nIn summary, the scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world, proposing a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. They investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, highlighting the similarities between craft and nature, and reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper grasp of their unity. Broadie identifies points of analogy and dis-analogy between craft and nature, emphasizing the species-specific character of artificial goal-directed processes, and argues that goal-directedness must be understood in relation to the nature of specific beings."

  "existing_answer": "The scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world.   "text": "The third [100] Â  point Â of analogy Â is the secondary place of desires and\nintentions. This is a n important and somewhat controversial point. As noted\nabove, it is common to consider the place of deliberation to be a point of\ndis-analogy Â  between craft and nature, and to insist that the two must be\ndistinguished in this respect in order to avoid importing psychological views of\ngoal-directedness which lead to extrinsic and artificial views of nature. As\nBroadie rightly notes, [101] Â Aristotle in fact considers psychological\nattitudes such as intending or desiring Â  to Â  be Â secondary even in crafts .\nThis, she says, is part of what makes them Â helpful in understanding natural\ngoal-directedness. [102] Â  She notes, for instance, that according to Aristotle,\na builder qua builder is not said to build because of his intentions or desires,\nrather Â â€œa man builds because he is a builder, but the builder builds in virtue\nof the building craft.â€ Â  ( Ph. Â II 3, 195b22) [103] Â Thus she challenges a\nmisconception [104] Â of artificial goal-directedness which identifies the\npersonal motivations of the craftsman [105] Â with the final cause of his\nactivity. This is an important point which merits a more exhaustive discussion.\n\n\n\n\nA NON PSYCHOLOGICAL CONCEPTION OF PURPOSES\n\nIn Physics II 8, Aristotle seems to bridge a gap between nature and the arts by\nclaiming that in crafts, as in nature, goal directedness is not Â rooted in\ndeliberation. â€œIt is ridiculous for people not to believe that something is\ncoming about for the sake of something if they do not see that the moving cause\nhas deliberated . Yet craft too does not deliberate.â€ (Ph. II 8, 199b 26) [106]\nÂ  O f course, Aristotle is not denying that there is a place for deliberation in\nthe arts. Rather, he challenges the view Â that the presence of deliberation is\nwhat grounds the claim that artificial processes are Â  goal-directed . [107] Â To\nclarify the proper role of deliberation in the arts, let us remember that for\nAristotle, deliberation always concerns means, never ends . [108] Â  It follows\nthat even in craft Â the end is prior to, and therefore not grounded in\ndeliberation. This clarification might not satisfy those who wish to deny\ngoal-directedness to non-human nature ; t hey may still object that although\ndeliberation is posterior to purposes, these purposes are grounded in\npsychological attitudes such as intending or desiring â€“ and since these cannot\nbring about good results in and of themselves (without the deliberation and\nintervention of an agent) the question remains as to how nature can be said to\nact for the sake of something Â if it does not deliberate. In other words,\nclarifying the secondary role of deliberation does not address the fundamental\nmistake of those to whom the comments from Physics Â II 8 are directed; what\nneeds to be addressed is their psychological understanding of purposes Â  i.e.\nÂ the view that a purpose is â€˜something desiredâ€™. [109]"
}
[32m[chain/start][39m [[90m[1m1:chain:LLMChain[22m[39m] Entering Chain run with input: {
  "existing_answer": "The scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. The scholars investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, clarifying the nature of his objections to artificial teleological accounts of his predecessors. They suggest that Aristotle considered the similarities between craft and nature to be very profound, and reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper grasp of their unity.\n\nSarah Broadie identifies points of analogy and dis-analogy between craft and nature, specifically highlighting the species-specific character of artificial goal-directed processes. She argues that natural substances, like craftsmen, are agents which direct a developmental process towards a specific form or structure, and that goal-directedness is rooted in the specific nature of the being which is actualized through a teleological process.\n\nThe scholars also provide an Aristotle quote from the treatise on Respiration, illustrating how the arts themselves achieve different results depending on the individual natures of the agencies which employ them, while nature uses fire as both an instrument and material. They emphasize that goal-directedness must be understood in relation to the nature of specific beings.\n\nThe second point of analogy highlighted by Broadie is that many goal-directed activities are incidental to the agent, such as gossiping, which does not belong to man in virtue of what he is. In contrast, the cognitive faculties which allow a craftsman to practice his art are essentially related to the production of a specific artifact. Broadie argues that Aristotle deliberately establishes the comparison with craft instead of other goal-directed activities because he wants to emphasize the explanatory character of natural causes.\n\nIn summary, the scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world, proposing a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. They investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, highlighting the similarities between craft and nature, and reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper grasp of their unity. Broadie identifies points of analogy and dis-analogy between craft and nature, emphasizing the species-specific character of artificial goal-directed processes, and argues that goal-directedness must be understood in relation to the nature of specific beings.",
  "text": "The third [100] Â  point Â of analogy Â is the secondary place of desires and\nintentions. This is a n important and somewhat controversial point. As noted\nabove, it is common to consider the place of deliberation to be a point of\ndis-analogy Â  between craft and nature, and to insist that the two must be\ndistinguished in this respect in order to avoid importing psychological views of\ngoal-directedness which lead to extrinsic and artificial views of nature. As\nBroadie rightly notes, [101] Â Aristotle in fact considers psychological\nattitudes such as intending or desiring Â  to Â  be Â secondary even in crafts .\nThis, she says, is part of what makes them Â helpful in understanding natural\ngoal-directedness. [102] Â  She notes, for instance, that according to Aristotle,\na builder qua builder is not said to build because of his intentions or desires,\nrather Â â€œa man builds because he is a builder, but the builder builds in virtue\nof the building craft.â€ Â  ( Ph. Â II 3, 195b22) [103] Â Thus she challenges a\nmisconception [104] Â of artificial goal-directedness which identifies the\npersonal motivations of the craftsman [105] Â with the final cause of his\nactivity. This is an important point which merits a more exhaustive discussion.\n\n\n\n\nA NON PSYCHOLOGICAL CONCEPTION OF PURPOSES\n\nIn Physics II 8, Aristotle seems to bridge a gap between nature and the arts by\nclaiming that in crafts, as in nature, goal directedness is not Â rooted in\ndeliberation. â€œIt is ridiculous for people not to believe that something is\ncoming about for the sake of something if they do not see that the moving cause\nhas deliberated . Yet craft too does not deliberate.â€ (Ph. II 8, 199b 26) [106]\nÂ  O f course, Aristotle is not denying that there is a place for deliberation in\nthe arts. Rather, he challenges the view Â that the presence of deliberation is\nwhat grounds the claim that artificial processes are Â  goal-directed . [107] Â To\nclarify the proper role of deliberation in the arts, let us remember that for\nAristotle, deliberation always concerns means, never ends . [108] Â  It follows\nthat even in craft Â the end is prior to, and therefore not grounded in\ndeliberation. This clarification might not satisfy those who wish to deny\ngoal-directedness to non-human nature ; t hey may still object that although\ndeliberation is posterior to purposes, these purposes are grounded in\npsychological attitudes such as intending or desiring â€“ and since these cannot\nbring about good results in and of themselves (without the deliberation and\nintervention of an agent) the question remains as to how nature can be said to\nact for the sake of something Â if it does not deliberate. In other words,\nclarifying the secondary role of deliberation does not address the fundamental\nmistake of those to whom the comments from Physics Â II 8 are directed; what\nneeds to be addressed is their psychological understanding of purposes Â  i.e.\nÂ the view that a purpose is â€˜something desiredâ€™. [109]"

  "prompts": [
    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: The scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. The scholars investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, clarifying the nature of his objections to artificial teleological accounts of his predecessors. They suggest that Aristotle considered the similarities between craft and nature to be very profound, and reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper grasp of their unity.\n\nSarah Broadie identifies points of analogy and dis-analogy between craft and nature, specifically highlighting the species-specific character of artificial goal-directed processes. She argues that natural substances, like craftsmen, are agents which direct a developmental process towards a specific form or structure, and that goal-directedness is rooted in the specific nature of the being which is actualized through a teleological process.\n\nThe scholars also provide an Aristotle quote from the treatise on Respiration, illustrating how the arts themselves achieve different results depending on the individual natures of the agencies which employ them, while nature uses fire as both an instrument and material. They emphasize that goal-directedness must be understood in relation to the nature of specific beings.\n\nThe second point of analogy highlighted by Broadie is that many goal-directed activities are incidental to the agent, such as gossiping, which does not belong to man in virtue of what he is. In contrast, the cognitive faculties which allow a craftsman to practice his art are essentially related to the production of a specific artifact. Broadie argues that Aristotle deliberately establishes the comparison with craft instead of other goal-directed activities because he wants to emphasize the explanatory character of natural causes.\n\nIn summary, the scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world, proposing a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. They investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, highlighting the similarities between craft and nature, and reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper grasp of their unity. Broadie identifies points of analogy and dis-analogy between craft and nature, emphasizing the species-specific character of artificial goal-directed processes, and argues that goal-directedness must be understood in relation to the nature of specific beings.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nThe third [100] Â  point Â of analogy Â is the secondary place of desires and\nintentions. Yet craft too does not deliberate.â€ (Ph. II 8, 199b 26) [106]\nÂ  O f course, Aristotle is not denying that there is a place for deliberation in\nthe arts. Rather, he challenges the view Â that the presence of deliberation is\nwhat grounds the claim that artificial processes are Â  goal-directed .         "text": "In this article, scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world, proposing a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. They investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, highlighting the similarities between craft and nature, and reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper grasp of their unity. Broadie identifies points of analogy and dis-analogy between craft and nature, emphasizing the species-specific character of artificial goal-directed processes, and argues that goal-directedness must be understood in relation to the nature of specific beings. The third point of analogy is the secondary place of desires and intentions, where Aristotle considers psychological attitudes such as intending or desiring to be secondary even in crafts, and challenges a misconception of artificial goal-directedness which identifies the personal motivations of the craftsman with the final cause of his activity. The article clarifies the proper role of deliberation in the arts, emphasizing that even in craft, the end is prior to, and therefore not grounded in deliberation."

The article clarifies the proper role of deliberation in the arts, emphasizing that even in craft, the end is prior to, and therefore not grounded in deliberation."

In other words, it would be a mistake to think that the doctor\nchooses the end to be pursued in the sense that his choice explains or\ndetermines the end of the medical art. This is why, as weâ€™ll see below, one\ncannot invent [113] Â a new craft simply by deciding to pursue an arbitrary\nâ€œgoalâ€. According to the Aristotelian view of crafts, the artist neither creates\nthe material nor the formal principle of artifacts, [114] Â  his Â role is simply\nto deliberate on the best way to instantiate pre-existing forms in pre-existing\nmaterials. Thus the intentions of craftsmen are subordinated to, and cannot be\nunderstood apart from the specific forms of artifacts. In her discussion of the\ncraft analogy, Broadie [115] Â notes that Aristotle focuses on craft at the\nexpense of a myriad of human activities whose intentional character should make\nthem just as relevant if purposes were grounded in intentions. Â We have already\nexplored some of the reasons why Aristotle considers some intentional actions to\nbe better illustrations Â of teleological processes . We shall now go one step\nfurther and ask whether all intentional actions can even be said to be\npurposeful. Take for instance the extreme case of the behavior of mad people.\nTheir actions, although intentional, are â€˜senselessâ€™. Their intentional and\ndeliberate nature might make them appear Â goal-oriented, but most people would\nagre e that they are no more â€˜purposefulâ€™ than the severed member is â€˜a handâ€™.\nWe suggest it is the nature of their Â â€˜goalsâ€™ which makes these Â actions\nsenseless. Â  Because he is out of touch with reality the madmanâ€™s goals are not\nrooted in being, they are â€˜not real goalsâ€™. [116] Â To illustrate what we mean,\nlet us imagine that the madman Â set out to build a n object known by the name of\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"
  ]

  "prompts": [
    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: In this article, scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world, proposing a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. They investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, highlighting the similarities between craft and nature, and reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts allows for a deeper grasp of their unity. Broadie identifies points of analogy and dis-analogy between craft and nature, emphasizing the species-specific character of artificial goal-directed processes, and argues that goal-directedness must be understood in relation to the nature of specific beings. The third point of analogy is the secondary place of desires and intentions, where Aristotle considers psychological attitudes such as intending or desiring to be secondary even in crafts, and challenges a misconception of artificial goal-directedness which identifies the personal motivations of the craftsman with the final cause of his activity. The article clarifies the proper role of deliberation in the arts, emphasizing that even in craft, the end is prior to, and therefore not grounded in deliberation.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nIn what follows, we will argue that Aristotleâ€™s view is that intentions, far\nfrom being the cause of purposes, are in fact subordinated to them and cannot\nexist independently. In short, Aristotle considers purposes to be primarily\nrooted in the notion of the good, not in psychological attitudes such as\nintending or desiring. [110] Â Purposes are desired by conscious agents because\nthey are good , not the other way around, Â  and t eleological accounts in both\ncraft and nature are explanations of something happening because it is good, not\nbecause someone intended or desired it. Â  In book VII of the Metaphysics, [111]\nÂ Aristotle explains that h ealth, not the doctorâ€™s intention, constitutes the\nend of the medical art. [112] Â Thus Â even in artificial\nteleological accounts, purposes are grounded in being Â and should not be\npsychologized .       {
        "text": "In this article, scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. The authors investigate Aristotle's view of the relation of nature and arts, highlighting the similarities between craft and nature, and reestablishing the priority of nature over the arts. They also clarify the proper role of deliberation in the arts, emphasizing that even in craft, the end is prior to, and therefore not grounded in deliberation. The article argues that purposes are rooted in the notion of the good, not in psychological attitudes such as intending or desiring, and that teleological accounts in both craft and nature are explanations of something happening because it is good, not because someone intended or desired it. The authors also explore the idea that not all intentional actions can be considered purposeful, citing the example of mad people whose actions, although intentional, are senseless as they are not rooted in being. Overall, the article seeks to provide a more nuanced understanding of the relationship between nature and arts, and the role of deliberation in creative processes."
      }
    ]
  ]

  "text": "rooted in being, they are â€˜not real goalsâ€™. [116] Â To illustrate what we mean,\nlet us imagine that the madman Â set out to build a n object known by the name of\na vistemboir, [117] Â  whose shape and function are ambiguous and controversial.\nÂ  If intentions are primary and constitute a starting-point of\ngoal-directedness, there is no reason to deny that such a building project is\npurposeful. Those who have a psychological conception of purposes should say\nthat the shape which the madman intends to instantiate constitutes a goal, and\nthat there can be a teleological account of his deliberate actions, which are\nmeans to achieve this desired Â end. By contrast, Aristotle would say that\nregardless of his intentions and deliberative efforts, the madman is not acting\npurposefully because his goal is not grounded in being, and his actions do not\ncontribute to the actualization of a specific form. In short, given the\nsecondary place of desires and intentions in Aristotleâ€™s account, there can be\nno genuine intention in the absence of a real end. The upshot is that intentions\nand goal-directedness are indeed intimately related, but not because the former\nis a cause of the latter. On the contrary, the dependence runs in the opposite\ndirection. [118] Â  It follows that, according to Aristotle, those who grant that\nhuman actions are teleologically explicable only because they see an agent\ndeliberating have misunderstood what makes even these actions purposeful.\nAccording to Aristotle, t his misunderstanding is characteristic of both\nteleological deniers (those who think nature can only be purposeful if it\ndeliberates) and artificial teleologist s (those who explain the purposiveness\nof natural substances with reference to the intentions of a divine artist), both\nof whom fail Â to identify the proper cause of goal-directedness. [119]"

[116] Â To illustrate what we mean,\nlet us imagine that the madman Â set out to build a n object known by the name of\na vistemboir, [117] Â  whose shape and function are ambiguous and controversial.\nÂ  If intentions are primary and constitute a starting-point of\ngoal-directedness, there is no reason to deny that such a building project is\npurposeful. In short, given the\nsecondary place of desires and intentions in Aristotleâ€™s account, there can be\nno genuine intention in the absence of a real end. The upshot is that intentions\nand goal-directedness are indeed intimately related, but not because the former\nis a cause of the latter. [118] Â  It follows that, according to Aristotle, those who grant that\nhuman actions are teleologically explicable only because they see an agent\ndeliberating have misunderstood what makes even these actions purposeful.\nAccording to Aristotle, t his misunderstanding is characteristic of both\nteleological deniers (those who think nature can only be purposeful if it\ndeliberates) and artificial teleologist s (those who explain the purposiveness\nof natural substances with reference to the intentions of a divine artist), both\nof whom fail Â to identify the proper cause of goal-directedness.         "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, here is a refined summary:\n\nThe scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. The authors argue that purposes are rooted in the notion of the good, not in psychological attitudes such as intending or desiring. They also explore the idea that not all intentional actions can be considered purposeful, citing the example of mad people whose actions, although intentional, are senseless as they are not rooted in being. The article seeks to provide a more nuanced understanding of the relationship between nature and arts, and the role of deliberation in creative processes.\n\nIn this portion of the article, the authors argue that Aristotle's account of goal-directedness differs from traditional teleological accounts, which rely on intentions or desires as the primary cause of purposeful action. According to Aristotle, the dependence runs in the opposite direction: intentions and goal-directedness are indeed intimately related, but not because the former is a cause of the latter. Instead, it is the being of things that provides the ground for their goals and purposes. The authors suggest that those who grant that human actions are teleologically explicable only because they see an agent deliberating have misunderstood what makes even these actions purposeful.\n\nOverall, the article seeks to provide a more nuanced understanding of the relationship between nature and arts, and the role of deliberation in creative processes. By challenging traditional teleological accounts and emphasizing the importance of Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, the authors aim to offer a more comprehensive explanation of the order and beauty of the natural world."

According to Aristotle, the dependence runs in the opposite direction: intentions and goal-directedness are indeed intimately related, but not because the former is a cause of the latter.   "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, here is a refined summary:\n\nThe scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. The authors argue that purposes are rooted in the notion of the good, not in psychological attitudes such as intending or desiring. They also explore the idea that not all intentional actions can be considered purposeful, citing the example of mad people whose actions, although intentional, are senseless as they are not rooted in being. The article seeks to provide a more nuanced understanding of the relationship between nature and arts, and the role of deliberation in creative processes.\n\nIn this portion of the article, the authors argue that Aristotle's account of goal-directedness differs from traditional teleological accounts, which rely on intentions or desires as the primary cause of purposeful action. According to Aristotle, the dependence runs in the opposite direction: intentions and goal-directedness are indeed intimately related, but not because the former is a cause of the latter. Instead, it is the being of things that provides the ground for their goals and purposes. The authors suggest that those who grant that human actions are teleologically explicable only because they see an agent deliberating have misunderstood what makes even these actions purposeful.\n\nOverall, the article seeks to provide a more nuanced understanding of the relationship between nature and arts, and the role of deliberation in creative processes. By challenging traditional teleological accounts and emphasizing the importance of Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, the authors aim to offer a more comprehensive explanation of the order and beauty of the natural world."

  "existing_answer": "Based on the provided portion of the article, here is a refined summary:\n\nThe scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. The authors argue that purposes are rooted in the notion of the good, not in psychological attitudes such as intending or desiring. They also explore the idea that not all intentional actions can be considered purposeful, citing the example of mad people whose actions, although intentional, are senseless as they are not rooted in being. The article seeks to provide a more nuanced understanding of the relationship between nature and arts, and the role of deliberation in creative processes.\n\nIn this portion of the article, the authors argue that Aristotle's account of goal-directedness differs from traditional teleological accounts, which rely on intentions or desires as the primary cause of purposeful action. According to Aristotle, the dependence runs in the opposite direction: intentions and goal-directedness are indeed intimately related, but not because the former is a cause of the latter. Instead, it is the being of things that provides the ground for their goals and purposes. The authors suggest that those who grant that human actions are teleologically explicable only because they see an agent deliberating have misunderstood what makes even these actions purposeful.\n\nOverall, the article seeks to provide a more nuanced understanding of the relationship between nature and arts, and the role of deliberation in creative processes. By challenging traditional teleological accounts and emphasizing the importance of Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, the authors aim to offer a more comprehensive explanation of the order and beauty of the natural world.",
  "text": "THE MISTAKE OF ARTIFICIAL TELEOLOGISTS\n\nSimply, the mistake is to think that to answer the â€˜why questionâ€™, one must\ninvestigate the motives of the agent rather than the nature of the good result.\nIn this view, health is not a cause for the sake of which , except accidentally\n; p urposes are not causes in their own right, they are the secondary cause of a\ngood result insofar as they belong to/are attributes of the â€œ real Â causeâ€ (the\nefficient cau se). This is the mistake Aristotle attributes to his predecessors\nin book A of the Metaphysics :\n\nThat for whose sake actions and changes and movements take place, they assert to\nbe a cause in a way, but not in this way, i.e. not in the way in which it is its\nnature Â to be a cause. For those who speak of reason or friendship class these\ncauses as goods; they do not speak however, as if anything that exists either\nexisted or came into being for the sake of these, but as if movements started\nfrom these. In the same way, those who say the One or the existent is the good,\nsay that it is the cause of substance, but not that substance either is or comes\nto be for the sake of this. Therefore it turns out that in a sense they both say\nand do not say the good is a cause; for they do not call it a cause qua Â good\nbut only incidentally. Â ( Metaph . A 7, 988b 5-15 ) [120] Â  [121]"

They also explore the idea that not all intentional actions can be considered purposeful, citing the example of mad people whose actions, although intentional, are senseless as they are not rooted in being.   "prompts": [
    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: Based on the provided portion of the article, here is a refined summary:\n\nThe scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. The authors argue that purposes are rooted in the notion of the good, not in psychological attitudes such as intending or desiring. They also explore the idea that not all intentional actions can be considered purposeful, citing the example of mad people whose actions, although intentional, are senseless as they are not rooted in being. The article seeks to provide a more nuanced understanding of the relationship between nature and arts, and the role of deliberation in creative processes.\n\nIn this portion of the article, the authors argue that Aristotle's account of goal-directedness differs from traditional teleological accounts, which rely on intentions or desires as the primary cause of purposeful action. According to Aristotle, the dependence runs in the opposite direction: intentions and goal-directedness are indeed intimately related, but not because the former is a cause of the latter. Instead, it is the being of things that provides the ground for their goals and purposes. The authors suggest that those who grant that human actions are teleologically explicable only because they see an agent deliberating have misunderstood what makes even these actions purposeful.\n\nOverall, the article seeks to provide a more nuanced understanding of the relationship between nature and arts, and the role of deliberation in creative processes. By challenging traditional teleological accounts and emphasizing the importance of Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, the authors aim to offer a more comprehensive explanation of the order and beauty of the natural world.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nTHE MISTAKE OF ARTIFICIAL TELEOLOGISTS\n\nSimply, the mistake is to think that to answer the â€˜why questionâ€™, one must\ninvestigate the motives of the agent rather than the nature of the good result.\nIn this view, health is not a cause for the sake of which , except accidentally\n; p urposes are not causes in their own right, they are the secondary cause of a\ngood result insofar as they belong to/are attributes of the â€œ real Â causeâ€ (the\nefficient cau se).   "prompts": [
    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: Based on the provided portion of the article, here is a refined summary:\n\nThe scholars challenge Johnson's distinction between natural and artificial causes in explaining the order and beauty of the natural world. They propose a more nuanced explanation based on Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. The authors argue that purposes are rooted in the notion of the good, not in psychological attitudes such as intending or desiring. They also explore the idea that not all intentional actions can be considered purposeful, citing the example of mad people whose actions, although intentional, are senseless as they are not rooted in being. The article seeks to provide a more nuanced understanding of the relationship between nature and arts, and the role of deliberation in creative processes.\n\nIn this portion of the article, the authors argue that Aristotle's account of goal-directedness differs from traditional teleological accounts, which rely on intentions or desires as the primary cause of purposeful action. According to Aristotle, the dependence runs in the opposite direction: intentions and goal-directedness are indeed intimately related, but not because the former is a cause of the latter. Instead, it is the being of things that provides the ground for their goals and purposes. The authors suggest that those who grant that human actions are teleologically explicable only because they see an agent deliberating have misunderstood what makes even these actions purposeful.\n\nOverall, the article seeks to provide a more nuanced understanding of the relationship between nature and arts, and the role of deliberation in creative processes. By challenging traditional teleological accounts and emphasizing the importance of Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology, the authors aim to offer a more comprehensive explanation of the order and beauty of the natural world.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nTHE MISTAKE OF ARTIFICIAL TELEOLOGISTS\n\nSimply, the mistake is to think that to answer the â€˜why questionâ€™, one must\ninvestigate the motives of the agent rather than the nature of the good result.\nIn this view, health is not a cause for the sake of which , except accidentally\n; p urposes are not causes in their own right, they are the secondary cause of a\ngood result insofar as they belong to/are attributes of the â€œ real Â causeâ€ (the\nefficient cau se).   "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, here is a refined summary:\n\nThe authors argue that Aristotle's account of goal-directedness differs from traditional teleological accounts, which rely on intentions or desires as the primary cause of purposeful action. According to Aristotle, the being of things provides the ground for their goals and purposes, rather than the other way around. The authors suggest that those who grant that human actions are teleologically explicable only because they see an agent deliberating have misunderstood what makes even these actions purposeful. They also challenge traditional teleological accounts by highlighting Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology. The article aims to provide a more nuanced understanding of the relationship between nature and arts, and the role of deliberation in creative processes.\n\nIn this context, the authors are emphasizing the importance of Aristotle's notion of intrinsic teleology in understanding the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world. They argue that the being of things, rather than the intentions or desires of agents, provides the ground for their goals and purposes. By highlighting this distinction, the authors aim to offer a more comprehensive explanation of the order and beauty of the natural world."
      }
    ]
  ]
}

        "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, here is a refined summary:\n\nAristotle's account of goal-directedness differs from traditional teleological accounts, which rely on intentions or desires as the primary cause of purposeful action. According to Aristotle, the being of things provides the ground for their goals and purposes, rather than the other way around. He highlights the distinction between intrinsic teleology and artificial teleology, where the former relies on the nature of things itself to provide their goals and purposes, while the latter relies on external factors such as intentions or desires. Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology has implications for understanding the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world, and he challenges traditional teleological accounts by emphasizing the importance of relying on the essence of each discipline rather than external factors.\n\nIn the next portion of the article, Aristotle will likely explore the implications of his perspective on intrinsic teleology for our understanding of the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world, as well as the relationship between nature and arts in different contexts. He may also discuss the contrast between natural arts of acquisition, which are grounded in the essence of human communities, and unnatural arts of acquiring riches for the sake of accumulating wealth, which are not genuine instances of the acquisitive arts when their purposes are arbitrary and not borrowed from nature.\n\nOverall, Aristotle's emphasis on intrinsic teleology and the importance of relying on the essence of each discipline has significant implications for our understanding of purposefulness in the natural world and the relationship between nature and arts."

    ]

He highlights the distinction between intrinsic teleology and artificial teleology, where the former relies on the nature of things itself to provide their goals and purposes, while the latter relies on external factors such as intentions or desires. [36m[chain/end][39m [[90m1:chain:RefineDocumentsChain > [1m60:chain:LLMChain[22m[39m] [16.16s] Exiting Chain run with output: {
  "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, here is a refined summary:\n\nAristotle's account of goal-directedness differs from traditional teleological accounts, which rely on intentions or desires as the primary cause of purposeful action. According to Aristotle, the being of things provides the ground for their goals and purposes, rather than the other way around. He highlights the distinction between intrinsic teleology and artificial teleology, where the former relies on the nature of things itself to provide their goals and purposes, while the latter relies on external factors such as intentions or desires. Aristotle's perspective on intrinsic teleology has implications for understanding the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world, and he challenges traditional teleological accounts by emphasizing the importance of relying on the essence of each discipline rather than external factors.\n\nIn the next portion of the article, Aristotle will likely explore the implications of his perspective on intrinsic teleology for our understanding of the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world, as well as the relationship between nature and arts in different contexts. He may also discuss the contrast between natural arts of acquisition, which are grounded in the essence of human communities, and unnatural arts of acquiring riches for the sake of accumulating wealth, which are not genuine instances of the acquisitive arts when their purposes are arbitrary and not borrowed from nature.\n\nOverall, Aristotle's emphasis on intrinsic teleology and the importance of relying on the essence of each discipline has significant implications for our understanding of purposefulness in the natural world and the relationship between nature and arts."
}

Given\nour nature, we can benefit from food . Thus Â an art which aims at the\nacquisition of food is purposeful. The coinâ€™s value, on the other hand, is not\nrooted in any real natural need, its value is merely conventional. Coins qua\ncoin do not contribute to the actualization of our nature. By telling us that\ncoins are not true riches because they do not provide us with the necessities\nfor living a human life, Aristotle is implying that we cannot arbitrarily decide\nthat something has value and purposefully pursue it. In other words, he is here\nrestating the necessity for the purposes of arts to be rooted in the nature of\nspecific substances. Natural Â arts, on the other\nhand, are limited by the state of completion of natural substances ; the limit\nand end of genuine acquisitive arts for instance Â is determined by the state of\ncompletion of the natural entities which benefit from it ( e.g. the family or\nthe city). Consequently, craft s, as Aristotle conceives them, are an extension\nof nature, and there can be no genuine (natural) art which is divorced from\nnatural self-actualization processes.\n\n\n\n\nTHE ESSENCE OF ARTIFACTS"

He distinguishes between intrinsic teleology and artificial teleology, where the former relies on the essence of things to provide their goals and purposes, while the latter relies on external factors. Aristotle emphasizes the importance of relying on the essence of each discipline rather than external factors, which has significant implications for our understanding of purposefulness in the natural world and the relationship between nature and arts.   "text": "THE ESSENCE OF ARTIFACTS\n\nAlthough Johnson recognizes and discusses Aristotleâ€™s differentiation of natural\nand violent arts, [133] Â  we contend Â that his view does not in fact provide the\nresources to establish a solid basis for this distinction. Because he thinks\ninstrumentalization always involves the imposition of strictly extrinsic and\nincidental ends ( i.e. Â because he does not recognize a middle ground between\nself-actualization and arbitrary use) there is no substantial difference between\nthe natural and violent use of other substances on his account. As a result, he\ngrounds the distinction between natural and violent use in a value judgment with\nno genuine ontological basis. In short, an art is natural, or as he says\nâ€˜justifiableâ€™ if practiced for the sake of Â fulfilling a genuine need. Thus\naccording to him, we can distinguish between natural and violent\ninstrumentalization processes simply by examining the disposition Â of the agent\ni.e. Â without considering the nature of the goal. [134] Â Because all\ninstrumentalization processes are equally arbitrary on his account, there is no\ngenuine difference between the products of natural and violent crafts; a house\nhas no more being or unity than does a vistemboir . This is why he thinks we\nmust look to the intentions of the artist in order to establish the status of\nproductive arts. We, by contrast, have been arguing that the distinction is\nprimarily grounded in the nature of the end, and only secondarily in the\ndisposition of the artist. [135] Â In what follows, we will discuss the\nlimitations of Johnsonâ€™s view and address some questions raised by our own\nperspective."

    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: Based on the provided portion of the article, here is a refined summary:\n\nAristotle argues that the value and purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world are rooted in the nature of things themselves, rather than external factors such as intentions or desires. He distinguishes between intrinsic teleology and artificial teleology, where the former relies on the essence of things to provide their goals and purposes, while the latter relies on external factors. Aristotle emphasizes the importance of relying on the essence of each discipline rather than external factors, which has significant implications for our understanding of purposefulness in the natural world and the relationship between nature and arts. He also highlights the contrast between natural arts, which are grounded in the essence of human communities, and unnatural arts of acquiring riches for the sake of accumulating wealth, which are not genuine instances of the acquisitive arts when their purposes are arbitrary and not borrowed from nature.\n\nIn the next portion of the article, Aristotle is likely to explore the implications of his perspective on intrinsic teleology for our understanding of the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world, as well as the relationship between nature and arts in different contexts. He may also discuss the contrast between natural arts of acquisition, which are grounded in the essence of human communities, and unnatural arts of acquiring riches for the sake of accumulating wealth, which are not genuine instances of the acquisitive arts when their purposes are arbitrary and not borrowed from nature.\n\nOverall, Aristotle's emphasis on intrinsic teleology and the importance of relying on the essence of each discipline has significant implications for our understanding of purposefulness in the natural world and the relationship between nature and arts.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nTHE ESSENCE OF ARTIFACTS\n\nAlthough Johnson recognizes and discusses Aristotleâ€™s differentiation of natural\nand violent arts, [133] Â  we contend Â that his view does not in fact provide the\nresources to establish a solid basis for this distinction. Because he thinks\ninstrumentalization always involves the imposition of strictly extrinsic and\nincidental ends ( i.e. Â because he does not recognize a middle ground between\nself-actualization and arbitrary use) there is no substantial difference between\nthe natural and violent use of other substances on his account. As a result, he\ngrounds the distinction between natural and violent use in a value judgment with\nno genuine ontological basis. In short, an art is natural, or as he says\nâ€˜justifiableâ€™ if practiced for the sake of Â fulfilling a genuine need. Thus\naccording to him, we can distinguish between natural and violent\ninstrumentalization processes simply by examining the disposition Â of the agent\ni.e. Â without considering the nature of the goal. [134] Â Because all\ninstrumentalization processes are equally arbitrary on his account, there is no\ngenuine difference between the products of natural and violent crafts; a house\nhas no more being or unity than does a vistemboir . This is why he thinks we\nmust look to the intentions of the artist in order to establish the status of\nproductive arts. We, by contrast, have been arguing that the distinction is\nprimarily grounded in the nature of the end, and only secondarily in the\ndisposition of the artist. [135] Â In what follows, we will discuss the\nlimitations of Johnsonâ€™s view and address some questions raised by our own\nperspective.\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"
  ]

  "existing_answer": "Based on the provided portion of the article, here is a refined summary:\n\nAristotle distinguishes between intrinsic teleology and artificial teleology, where the former relies on the essence of things to provide their goals and purposes, while the latter relies on external factors. He emphasizes the importance of relying on the essence of each discipline rather than external factors, which has significant implications for our understanding of purposefulness in the natural world and the relationship between nature and arts. Aristotle also discusses the limitations of Johnson's view on intrinsic teleology and addresses questions raised by his own perspective.\n\nIn the next portion of the article, Aristotle is likely to explore the implications of his perspective on intrinsic teleology for our understanding of the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world, as well as the relationship between nature and arts in different contexts. He may also discuss the contrast between natural arts, which are grounded in the essence of human communities, and unnatural arts of acquiring riches for the sake of accumulating wealth, which are not genuine instances of the acquisitive arts when their purposes are arbitrary and not borrowed from nature.",
  "text": "The basis of the distinction between natural and violent art as we have\nportrayed it rests on the premise that a certain essential relation holds\nbetween substances and the product of natural crafts. The art of housebuilding\nfor instance, is natural because houses are in virtue of what they are Â related\nto human nature. The end of the building craft (the completed house) is\nessentially related to man for it allows him to actualize his nature fully by\nproviding shelter. Â Yet of course, the relation is not strictly intrinsic,\nbecause the house and the builder are distinct entities; thus we suggest that\ntheir relation is best described as quasi-extrinsic. By contrast, there can be\nno such relation between agent and patient in violent arts because unnatural\nends lack substantiality; they are like aggregates in that, although they may\nappear to be unified, they in fact are not â€˜somethingâ€™ but rather â€˜some thingsâ€™.\nIn the case of the vistemboir , there can be no essential relation between the\nâ€˜artistâ€™ and its â€˜productâ€™ for the simple reason that the latter has no essence,\nthus their relation is necessarily strictly Â extrinsic. This raises a question,\nfor if (natural) artifacts can be essentially related to natural substances,\nthen they must have an essence, at least in some limited sense. Â  W e know\nAristotle is cautious about attributing the status of substance to artifacts,\nand according to some, this is because he does not think that the products of\ncrafts have a nature. Johnson, for instance, says that artifacts can only be\nsaid to have a nature in the limited sense that they inherit properties which\nbelong to their material constituents. [136] Â In other words, on his account\nartifacts have no nature qua whole, which in turn means that they are no more\nthan the sum of their parts, and, as Johnson puts it :\n\nA ll functions of artifacts are ultimately incidental. That is why it is\npossible to construct for any artifact incidental functions that have an\nequivalent explanatory status to any purported â€˜essentialâ€™ function they might\nhave. For example, a chair can be used to prop open the door, or a pencil to\nscratch my ear. [137]\n\n\n\nJohnson thinks the functions we attribute to artifacts are equally incidental\nbecause, as we have said, he does not consider that they have a nature. He is\nright, of course, that artifacts do not have a nature in the fullest sense i.e.\nÂ they do not have an intrinsic principle of motion and rest - except in a\nderivative way, insofar as their constitutive elements possess such a nature\n[138] Â - but we contend that they do, qua artifact, have more than a shape,\nwhich means that they are not mere aggregates. The distinction between a form\nand a shape is stated with clarity in Metaphysics VII 17:"
}

Â Yet of course, the relation is not strictly intrinsic,\nbecause the house and the builder are distinct entities; thus we suggest that\ntheir relation is best described as quasi-extrinsic. This raises a question,\nfor if (natural) artifacts can be essentially related to natural substances,\nthen they must have an essence, at least in some limited sense. Â  W e know\nAristotle is cautious about attributing the status of substance to artifacts,\nand according to some, this is because he does not think that the products of\ncrafts have a nature. Johnson, for instance, says that artifacts can only be\nsaid to have a nature in the limited sense that they inherit properties which\nbelong to their material constituents.
