That is why it is\npossible to construct for any artifact incidental functions that have an\nequivalent explanatory status to any purported â€˜essentialâ€™ function they might\nhave. For example, a chair can be used to prop open the door, or a pencil to\nscratch my ear. [137]\n\n\n\nJohnson thinks the functions we attribute to artifacts are equally incidental\nbecause, as we have said, he does not consider that they have a nature. He is\nright, of course, that artifacts do not have a nature in the fullest sense i.e.\nÂ they do not have an intrinsic principle of motion and rest - except in a\nderivative way, insofar as their constitutive elements possess such a nature\n[138] Â - but we contend that they do, qua artifact, have more than a shape,\nwhich means that they are not mere aggregates. The distinction between a form\nand a shape is stated with clarity in Metaphysics VII 17:"

He may also discuss the contrast between natural arts, which are grounded in the essence of human communities, and unnatural arts of acquiring riches for the sake of accumulating wealth, which are not genuine instances of the acquisitive arts when their purposes are arbitrary and not borrowed from nature.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nThe basis of the distinction between natural and violent art as we have\nportrayed it rests on the premise that a certain essential relation holds\nbetween substances and the product of natural crafts. By contrast, there can be\nno such relation between agent and patient in violent arts because unnatural\nends lack substantiality; they are like aggregates in that, although they may\nappear to be unified, they in fact are not â€˜somethingâ€™ but rather â€˜some thingsâ€™.\nIn the case of the vistemboir , there can be no essential relation between the\nâ€˜artistâ€™ and its â€˜productâ€™ for the simple reason that the latter has no essence,\nthus their relation is necessarily strictly Â extrinsic. This raises a question,\nfor if (natural) artifacts can be essentially related to natural substances,\nthen they must have an essence, at least in some limited sense. Â  W e know\nAristotle is cautious about attributing the status of substance to artifacts,\nand according to some, this is because he does not think that the products of\ncrafts have a nature. Johnson, for instance, says that artifacts can only be\nsaid to have a nature in the limited sense that they inherit properties which\nbelong to their material constituents. [136] Â In other words, on his account\nartifacts have no nature qua whole, which in turn means that they are no more\nthan the sum of their parts, and, as Johnson puts it :\n\nA ll functions of artifacts are ultimately incidental. That is why it is\npossible to construct for any artifact incidental functions that have an\nequivalent explanatory status to any purported â€˜essentialâ€™ function they might\nhave. For example, a chair can be used to prop open the door, or a pencil to\nscratch my ear. He is\nright, of course, that artifacts do not have a nature in the fullest sense i.e.\nÂ they do not have an intrinsic principle of motion and rest - except in a\nderivative way, insofar as their constitutive elements possess such a nature\n[138] Â - but we contend that they do, qua artifact, have more than a shape,\nwhich means that they are not mere aggregates. Aristotle may also address questions raised by his own perspective, such as whether artifacts have a nature qua whole or only inherit properties from their material constituents. He may also expand on the distinction between a form and a shape, as mentioned in Metaphysics VII 17, and how it relates to the purposefulness of natural and artificial things."

He may also expand on the distinction between a form and a shape, as mentioned in Metaphysics VII 17, and how it relates to the purposefulness of natural and artificial things."

[36m[chain/end][39m [[90m[1m1:chain:LLMChain[22m[39m] [10.42s] Exiting Chain run with output: {
  "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, Aristotle is likely to explore the implications of his perspective on intrinsic teleology for our understanding of the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world, as well as the relationship between nature and arts in different contexts. He may discuss the contrast between natural arts, which are grounded in the essence of human communities, and unnatural arts of acquiring riches for the sake of accumulating wealth, which are not genuine instances of the acquisitive arts when their purposes are arbitrary and not borrowed from nature. Aristotle may also address questions raised by his own perspective, such as whether artifacts have a nature qua whole or only inherit properties from their material constituents. He may also expand on the distinction between a form and a shape, as mentioned in Metaphysics VII 17, and how it relates to the purposefulness of natural and artificial things."
}
[32m[chain/start][39m [[90m1:chain:RefineDocumentsChain > [1m68:chain:LLMChain[22m[39m] Entering Chain run with input: {
  "existing_answer": "Based on the provided portion of the article, Aristotle is likely to explore the implications of his perspective on intrinsic teleology for our understanding of the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world, as well as the relationship between nature and arts in different contexts. Aristotle may also address questions raised by his own perspective, such as whether artifacts have a nature qua whole or only inherit properties from their material constituents. He may also expand on the distinction between a form and a shape, as mentioned in Metaphysics VII 17, and how it relates to the purposefulness of natural and artificial things.",
  "text": "What is composed of something in such a way that the totality is one, not like a\nheap but like a syllable â€“ The syllable is not its phonetic elements, BA is not\nthe same as B and A, nor is flesh fire and earth. For when they â€“ for example,\nthe flesh and the syllable â€“ are dissolved they no longer exist, whereas the\nphonetic elements do exist, and so do the fire and the earth. The syllable,\nthen, is something â€“ not its phonetic elements alone, the sounded (=A) and the\nunsounded (=B), but also something else, and the flesh is not only fire and\nearth or the hot and the cold but also something else. ( Metaph. Â VII 17, 1041\nb11-17) [139]\n\n\n\nIn this passage, Aristotle presents what is sometimes called a â€˜top downâ€™ view\nof composition, where the compound (the whole) is something more than the sum of\nits parts. He then Â goes on to establish that this something Â is not an element\n(1041 b25-20) but rather â€œa cause in fact of this being flesh and this being a\nsyllableâ€ [140] Â  â€“ i.e. a formal principle. [141] Â The contrast between such a\nprinciple and a mere shape is suggested by the very first line of the passage,\n[142] Â where he distinguishes composite wholes Â and heaps. A whole, Aristotle\nsays, is composed in such a way that the totality is one , whereas a heap, it is\nimplied, is a plurality. A heap is nothing other than its constitutive elements\nbecause it lacks a formal principle which would make it this or that . Because\nit has a shape, a heap may appear Â unified but in truth, Aristotle thinks it\ndoes not, qua heap, have being or unity. A heap is not a genuine whole because\ncomposition (and unity) is the result of an organizing (formal) principle. The\nshape of a heap is not a cause of the arrangement of the elements, on the\ncontrary, it is a result Â of the respective motions of its â€œpartsâ€. Thus the\narrangement of heaps is a case of so-called bottom up composition, which\nAristotle does not consider to be genuine composition i.e. Â to result in being\nand unity. This being said, while we agree with Johnson that Aristotle does not\nconsider artifacts to have a nature in the fullest sense of the term, we want to\nargue that the status of artifacts constitutes a middle ground between genuine\nsubstances and mere heaps. We contend that we must adopt this view, first ,\nbecause treating artifacts as mere heaps undermines Â the distinction between\nnatural and violent arts, but also because it is strongly suggested by textual\nevidence. In the passage from Metaphysics Â VII 17 which we were just examining,\nfor instance, Â Aristotle relies on examples taken from both craft and nature:"
}

  "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, Aristotle presents a top-down view of composition, where the compound (the whole) is something more than the sum of its parts. He argues that the syllable and flesh are not just their phonetic elements, but also something else, which he refers to as a \"cause in fact\" or \"formal principle.\" This means that the whole has a unity and being that cannot be reduced to its individual parts alone. In contrast, a heap is just a plurality of elements without any underlying unifying principle.\n\nAristotle also distinguishes between composition and shape, where composition results from an organizing principle, while shape is a result of the respective motions of the elements. He suggests that artifacts constitute a middle ground between genuine substances and mere heaps, as they have a nature qua whole but are not inherently existing things like natural substances.\n\nThe article goes on to explore the implications of Aristotle's perspective on the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world and the relationship between nature and arts in different contexts."
      }
    ]
  ]

[32m[chain/start][39m [[90m1:chain:RefineDocumentsChain > [1m70:chain:LLMChain[22m[39m] Entering Chain run with input: {
  "existing_answer": "Based on the provided portion of the article, Aristotle presents a top-down view of composition, where the compound (the whole) is something more than the sum of its parts. He argues that the syllable and flesh are not just their phonetic elements, but also something else, which he refers to as a \"cause in fact\" or \"formal principle.\" This means that the whole has a unity and being that cannot be reduced to its individual parts alone. In contrast, a heap is just a plurality of elements without any underlying unifying principle.\n\nAristotle also distinguishes between composition and shape, where composition results from an organizing principle, while shape is a result of the respective motions of the elements. He suggests that artifacts constitute a middle ground between genuine substances and mere heaps, as they have a nature qua whole but are not inherently existing things like natural substances.\n\nThe article goes on to explore the implications of Aristotle's perspective on the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world and the relationship between nature and arts in different contexts.",
  "text": "the Â question is why the matter is some individual thing, e.g. why are these\nmaterials a house? Because that which was the essence of a house is present. And\nwhy is this individual thing, or this body in this state, a man? Therefore what\nwe seek is the cause, i.e. the form, by reason of which the matter is some\ndefinite thing; and this is the substance of the thing. Â ( Metaph . VII 17, 1041\nb5-7) [143]\n\n\n\nThis suggests that a house is indeed something , and not just some things i.e.\nÂ it has a formal principle which grounds its being and unity as a whole. It may\nbe added that the way in which Aristotle speaks of artifacts in different\ncontexts also suggests that he does not consider them to be a mere superposition\nof their material constituents. Consider the case of the automata which\nAristotle invokes in the Generation of Animals. [144] Â It is clear that\nAristotle considers it to have unity and being as a whole , for there is a\nspecific set of motions that belongs to the machine because of the way in which\nits parts are organized. Even in the case of simpler tools such as a saw, it is\nclear that it has capacities over and above those it inherits from its\nconstitutive elements. The hardness of the saw, and consequently its capacity to\ncut for instance, relies on, but is not completely explained by the nature of\niron, for if it was informed differently (say, if it was a ball, or a very thin\nsheet) iron may not exhibit these characters; thus we should say that it is the\ntool as a whole which possesses the hardness and the resulting capacity to cut\nin the specific way which serves the artisantâ€™s Â needs. [145] Â It is clear,\ntherefore, that artifacts, like natural substances, exhibit some features which\nare due to their material constituents, and others which are due to their form.\nThis means that unlike heaps, artifacts do have a formal principle and\nconsequently have being and Â unity qua artifact. Byrne [146] Â rightly emphasizes\nthe similarity between Aristotleâ€™s portrayal of the relation of material and\nformal principles in natural and artificial contexts; [147] Â and argues that, if\nAristotle considered artifacts to be mere heaps (with a shape rather than a\nform) he would not rely on examples taken from craft to teach us about\ncomposition. Indeed the constitution of heaps is, as we have said, a case of\nâ€˜bottom-upâ€™ composition which results in the mere appearance of being and unity.\nÂ In short, Aristotleâ€™s use of craft analogies in this context is yet another\nindication that Aristotle indeed considers artifacts to be more than aggregates."
}

  "prompts": [
    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: Based on the provided portion of the article, Aristotle presents a top-down view of composition, where the compound (the whole) is something more than the sum of its parts. He argues that the syllable and flesh are not just their phonetic elements, but also something else, which he refers to as a \"cause in fact\" or \"formal principle.\" This means that the whole has a unity and being that cannot be reduced to its individual parts alone. It may\nbe added that the way in which Aristotle speaks of artifacts in different\ncontexts also suggests that he does not consider them to be a mere superposition\nof their material constituents. Consider the case of the automata which\nAristotle invokes in the Generation of Animals. [144] Â It is clear that\nAristotle considers it to have unity and being as a whole , for there is a\nspecific set of motions that belongs to the machine because of the way in which\nits parts are organized. Even in the case of simpler tools such as a saw, it is\nclear that it has capacities over and above those it inherits from its\nconstitutive elements. The hardness of the saw, and consequently its capacity to\ncut for instance, relies on, but is not completely explained by the nature of\niron, for if it was informed differently (say, if it was a ball, or a very thin\nsheet) iron may not exhibit these characters; thus we should say that it is the\ntool as a whole which possesses the hardness and the resulting capacity to cut\nin the specific way which serves the artisantâ€™s Â needs. [145] Â It is clear,\ntherefore, that artifacts, like natural substances, exhibit some features which\nare due to their material constituents, and others which are due to their form.\nThis means that unlike heaps, artifacts do have a formal principle and\nconsequently have being and Â unity qua artifact. Byrne [146] Â rightly emphasizes\nthe similarity between Aristotleâ€™s portrayal of the relation of material and\nformal principles in natural and artificial contexts; [147] Â and argues that, if\nAristotle considered artifacts to be mere heaps (with a shape rather than a\nform) he would not rely on examples taken from craft to teach us about\ncomposition. Indeed the constitution of heaps is, as we have said, a case of\nâ€˜bottom-upâ€™ composition which results in the mere appearance of being and unity.\nÂ In short, Aristotleâ€™s use of craft analogies in this context is yet another\nindication that Aristotle indeed considers artifacts to be more than aggregates.\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"
  ]
}

  "prompts": [
    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: Based on the provided portion of the article, Aristotle presents a top-down view of composition, where the compound (the whole) is something more than the sum of its parts. He argues that the syllable and flesh are not just their phonetic elements, but also something else, which he refers to as a \"cause in fact\" or \"formal principle.\" This means that the whole has a unity and being that cannot be reduced to its individual parts alone. In contrast, a heap is just a plurality of elements without any underlying unifying principle.\n\nAristotle also distinguishes between composition and shape, where composition results from an organizing principle, while shape is a result of the respective motions of the elements. He suggests that artifacts constitute a middle ground between genuine substances and mere heaps, as they have a nature qua whole but are not inherently existing things like natural substances.\n\nThe article goes on to explore the implications of Aristotle's perspective on the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world and the relationship between nature and arts in different contexts.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nthe Â question is why the matter is some individual thing, e.g. why are these\nmaterials a house? Because that which was the essence of a house is present. And\nwhy is this individual thing, or this body in this state, a man? Therefore what\nwe seek is the cause, i.e. the form, by reason of which the matter is some\ndefinite thing; and this is the substance of the thing. Â ( Metaph . VII 17, 1041\nb5-7) [143]\n\n\n\nThis suggests that a house is indeed something , and not just some things i.e.\nÂ it has a formal principle which grounds its being and unity as a whole.         "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, Aristotle presents a top-down view of composition, where the compound (the whole) is something more than the sum of its parts. He argues that the syllable and flesh are not just their phonetic elements, but also something else, which he refers to as a \"cause in fact\" or \"formal principle.\" This means that the whole has a unity and being that cannot be reduced to its individual parts alone. In contrast, a heap is just a plurality of elements without any underlying unifying principle.\n\nAristotle also distinguishes between composition and shape, where composition results from an organizing principle, while shape is a result of the respective motions of the elements. He suggests that artifacts constitute a middle ground between genuine substances and mere heaps, as they have a nature qua whole but are not inherently existing things like natural substances.\n\nThe article goes on to explore the implications of Aristotle's perspective on the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world and the relationship between nature and arts in different contexts. Aristotle's use of craft analogies in this context is yet another indication that he considers artifacts to be more than aggregates, with a formal principle that gives them being and unity qua artifact.\n\nIn summary, Aristotle's philosophy of composition emphasizes the importance of form and organization in determining the nature and unity of a whole, rather than just the sum of its parts. He argues that artifacts, like natural substances, exhibit features due to their material constituents and others due to their form, making them more than mere aggregates."

  "text": "Now that we have established the distinction between aggregates and artifacts,\nwe must clarify the difference between the way in which natural and artificial\nwholes Â can be said to have an essence, for as we have said, Johnson is right to\ninsist that artifacts do not have a nature in the fullest sense. In other words,\nif we are to maintain that artifacts have more than a shape, we must clarify why\nAristotle is cautious about calling them substances. In short, we will argue\nthat the reason why Aristotle denies them the status of substance is not that\nartifacts have no essence, but rather that their essence is somehow incomplete,\nand constitute some sort of middle ground between natural forms and mere shapes.\nThis, we contend, is what is suggested by the passages which Johnson cites [148]\nÂ in discussing the status of artifacts. The context of these passages [149] Â is\na concern with the question of which entities â€“ if any â€“ may be said to exist\nseparately ( auto kath auto ). Aristotleâ€™s answer is that although it is hard to\ndeny with certainty the possibility that some natural forms may exist\nseparately, we can definitely rule out this possibility in the case of\nartificial forms because they lack substantiality; [150] Â  thus Â if they can be\nsaid to have a nature, it is a derived or secondary kind of nature, which is not\nself-sufficient and remains defined in relation to natural substances. The other\nside of this coin is that natural forms â€˜ are â€™ in a fuller sense. This suggests\na gradation in the being and unity of different entities, with, on one end of\nthe spectrum, heaps (whose shape grants them the mere appearance Â of being and\nunity) and on the other end, natural substances (whose form is a principle of\nthe kind of being and unity which makes them substances â€“ and as a result,\npossible candidates for separate existence). We suggest that artifacts fall\nsomewhere between those extremes because their formal principle causes being and\nunity in an incomplete way. The form of bodily organs should also occupy a\nmiddle position on this spectrum, for it would be a mistake to treat organs as\nmere heaps, surely they have some degree of integrity and to some extent they\ncan be said to have an essence on the basis of which we can differentiate them\nand their respective functions, yet their form is not complete and does not make\nthem into an autonomous self-subsisting whole. The Â way in which the form of\ninternal organs and external tools relate to the formal principle of natural\nsubstances is surely different, and we shall discuss this in more detail in our\nnext chapter when we turn to natural instrumental relations. For now let us\nfocus on distinguishing natural and artificial formal principles"
}

[36m[llm/end][39m [[90m1:chain:RefineDocumentsChain > 72:chain:LLMChain > [1m73:llm:Ollama[22m[39m] [18.26s] Exiting LLM run with output: {
  "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "In this article, Aristotle presents a top-down view of composition, where the compound (the whole) is more than the sum of its parts. He argues that the syllable and flesh are not just their phonetic elements, but also something else, which he refers to as a \"cause in fact\" or \"formal principle.\" This means that the whole has a unity and being that cannot be reduced to its individual parts alone. Aristotle distinguishes between composition and shape, where composition results from an organizing principle, while shape is a result of the respective motions of the elements. He suggests that artifacts constitute a middle ground between genuine substances and mere heaps, as they have a nature qua whole but are not inherently existing things like natural substances.\n\nAristotle's philosophy of composition emphasizes the importance of form and organization in determining the nature and unity of a whole, rather than just the sum of its parts. He argues that artifacts, like natural substances, exhibit features due to their material constituents and others due to their form, making them more than mere aggregates. However, Aristotle denies artifacts the status of substance because their essence is somehow incomplete, constituting a middle ground between natural forms and mere shapes.\n\nThe article goes on to explore the implications of Aristotle's perspective on the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world and the relationship between nature and arts in different contexts. The author suggests that Aristotle's use of craft analogies in this context is another indication that he considers artifacts to be more than mere aggregates, with a formal principle that gives them being and unity qua artifact.\n\nIn summary, Aristotle's philosophy of composition emphasizes the importance of form and organization in determining the nature and unity of a whole, while denying artifacts the status of substance due to their incomplete essence. This perspective has implications for understanding the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world and the relationship between nature and arts in different contexts."
      }
    ]
  ]
}
[36m[llm/end][39m [[90m1:chain:LLMChain > [1m2:llm:Ollama[22m[39m] [18.26s] Exiting LLM run with output: {
  "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "In this article, Aristotle presents a top-down view of composition, where the compound (the whole) is more than the sum of its parts. He argues that the syllable and flesh are not just their phonetic elements, but also something else, which he refers to as a \"cause in fact\" or \"formal principle.\" This means that the whole has a unity and being that cannot be reduced to its individual parts alone. Aristotle distinguishes between composition and shape, where composition results from an organizing principle, while shape is a result of the respective motions of the elements. He suggests that artifacts constitute a middle ground between genuine substances and mere heaps, as they have a nature qua whole but are not inherently existing things like natural substances.\n\nAristotle's philosophy of composition emphasizes the importance of form and organization in determining the nature and unity of a whole, rather than just the sum of its parts. He argues that artifacts, like natural substances, exhibit features due to their material constituents and others due to their form, making them more than mere aggregates. However, Aristotle denies artifacts the status of substance because their essence is somehow incomplete, constituting a middle ground between natural forms and mere shapes.\n\nThe article goes on to explore the implications of Aristotle's perspective on the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world and the relationship between nature and arts in different contexts. The author suggests that Aristotle's use of craft analogies in this context is another indication that he considers artifacts to be more than mere aggregates, with a formal principle that gives them being and unity qua artifact.\n\nIn summary, Aristotle's philosophy of composition emphasizes the importance of form and organization in determining the nature and unity of a whole, while denying artifacts the status of substance due to their incomplete essence. This perspective has implications for understanding the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world and the relationship between nature and arts in different contexts."
      }
    ]
  ]
}

Aristotle distinguishes between composition and shape, where composition results from an organizing principle, while shape is a result of the respective motions of the elements. He suggests that artifacts constitute a middle ground between genuine substances and mere heaps, as they have a nature qua whole but are not inherently existing things like natural substances.\n\nAristotle's philosophy of composition emphasizes the importance of form and organization in determining the nature and unity of a whole, rather than just the sum of its parts.   "text": "Artificial forms are subordinated to natural principles in many ways, the first\nand most commonly emphasized [151] Â being the dependence in formula; the\ndefinition of an artifact is derived and cannot be understood apart from that of\na natural substance whose self-actualization it serves or imitates. Beyond this\nlogical subordination, Aristotle suggests that artificial forms are\nâ€˜existentiallyâ€™ dependent upon natural substances because they lack something of\nthe actuality of natural forms. Consider for instance the following passage from\nDe Motu which compares natural and artificial principles:\n\nThe movements of animals can be compared with those of automatic puppets, which\nare set going on the occasion of a tiny movement (the strings are released, and\nthe pegs strike again one another); or with the toy wagon (for the child mounts\non it and moves it straight forward, and yet it is moved in a circle owing to\nits wheels being of unequal diameter â€“ the smaller acts like a center on the\nsame principle as cylinders.) Animals have parts of a similar kind, their\norgans, the sinewy tendons to wit and the bones; the bones are like the pegs and\nthe iron; the tendons are like the strings; for when these are slackened or\nreleased movement begins. However, in the puppets and the toy wagon there is no\nchange of quality since if the inner wheels became smaller and greater by turns\nthere would be the same circular movement set up. In an animal the same part has\nthe power of becoming now larger and now smaller and greater, and changing its\nform, as the parts increase by warmth and contract by cold and change their\nquality. ( De Motu 700 a1-15)"
}

    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: In this article, Aristotle presents a top-down view of composition, where the compound (the whole) is more than the sum of its parts. He argues that the syllable and flesh are not just their phonetic elements, but also something else, which he refers to as a \"cause in fact\" or \"formal principle.\" This means that the whole has a unity and being that cannot be reduced to its individual parts alone. Aristotle distinguishes between composition and shape, where composition results from an organizing principle, while shape is a result of the respective motions of the elements. He suggests that artifacts constitute a middle ground between genuine substances and mere heaps, as they have a nature qua whole but are not inherently existing things like natural substances.\n\nAristotle's philosophy of composition emphasizes the importance of form and organization in determining the nature and unity of a whole, rather than just the sum of its parts. However, Aristotle denies artifacts the status of substance because their essence is somehow incomplete, constituting a middle ground between natural forms and mere shapes.\n\nThe article goes on to explore the implications of Aristotle's perspective on the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world and the relationship between nature and arts in different contexts. The author suggests that Aristotle's use of craft analogies in this context is another indication that he considers artifacts to be more than mere aggregates, with a formal principle that gives them being and unity qua artifact.\n\nIn summary, Aristotle's philosophy of composition emphasizes the importance of form and organization in determining the nature and unity of a whole, while denying artifacts the status of substance due to their incomplete essence. This perspective has implications for understanding the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world and the relationship between nature and arts in different contexts.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nArtificial forms are subordinated to natural principles in many ways, the first\nand most commonly emphasized [151] Â being the dependence in formula; the\ndefinition of an artifact is derived and cannot be understood apart from that of\na natural substance whose self-actualization it serves or imitates.   "prompts": [
    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: In this article, Aristotle presents a top-down view of composition, where the compound (the whole) is more than the sum of its parts. He argues that the syllable and flesh are not just their phonetic elements, but also something else, which he refers to as a \"cause in fact\" or \"formal principle.\" This means that the whole has a unity and being that cannot be reduced to its individual parts alone. However, he denies artifacts the status of substance because their essence is somehow incomplete. This perspective has implications for understanding the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world and the relationship between nature and arts in different contexts. L et this be a sufficient account of the distinction\nbetween artifacts, natural substances, and heaps; a distinction which grounds\nthe possibility of distinguishing art and nature on the one hand; Â and natural\nand violent arts on the other.\n\n\n\n\nSUMMARY"

He argues that artifacts, like natural substances, exhibit features due to their material constituents and others due to their form, making them more than mere aggregates. However, he denies artifacts the status of substance because their essence is somehow incomplete. This perspective has implications for understanding the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world and the relationship between nature and arts in different contexts. Aristotle's use of craft analogies in this context highlights his view that artifacts have a formal principle that gives them being and unity qua artifact.\n\nIn summary, Aristotle's philosophy of composition emphasizes the importance of form and organization in determining the nature and unity of a whole, while denying artifacts the status of substance due to their incomplete essence. This perspective has implications for understanding the purposefulness of actions and events in the natural world and the relationship between nature and arts in different contexts.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nThis suggests that artificial forms are somehow less complete and less\nâ€˜powerfulâ€™ than natural forms because they do not enable artifacts to maintain\n(or reproduce) their form. In the case of the toy wagon for instance, if it was\nput in different circumstances (if it were on an inclined surface for instance)\nit simply could not function properly. Artificial forms are the source of what\nGill [152] Â calls a passive potency ( dunamis ), i.e. a capacity to be Â  moved\nin specific ways. [153] Â As a result, the self-actualization of artifacts\ndepends upon the intervention of an outside agent - in whom resides what Gill\nnames the active form. [154] Â Natural forms, by contrast, are active and thus\ngrant natural composites a different kind of dunamis . [155] Â A natural form\nmakes the body â€˜capableâ€™ in a fuller, more actual sense. Let us note that our\naccount of Â the distinction between natural and artificial forms does not reduce\nartifacts to mere heaps, for a passive (artificial) form is indeed more than a\nshape as it integrates the materials so as to make them into a this or a that\nÂ with properties over and above those of the material constituents, and in some\ncases can even account for some types of simple behavior e.g. Â the locomotion of\nautomata and toy wagons. L et this be a sufficient account of the distinction\nbetween artifacts, natural substances, and heaps; a distinction which grounds\nthe possibility of distinguishing art and nature on the one hand; Â and natural\nand violent arts on the other.\n\n\n\n\nSUMMARY\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"
  ]
}

[36m[llm/end][39m [[90m1:chain:RefineDocumentsChain > 76:chain:LLMChain > [1m77:llm:Ollama[22m[39m] [9.00s] Exiting LLM run with output: {
  "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have further refined the summary as follows:\n\nAristotle's philosophy of composition emphasizes the importance of form and organization in determining the nature and unity of a whole, while denying artifacts the status of substance due to their incomplete essence. Artificial forms are less complete and powerful than natural forms, as they do not enable artifacts to maintain or reproduce their form without intervention from an outside agent. Natural forms, on the other hand, grant composites a different kind of potency, making them capable in a fuller, more actual sense. While artifacts may exhibit simple behaviors such as locomotion, they are more than mere heaps due to their integration of materials and form. This distinction between artifacts, natural substances, and heaps grounds the possibility of distinguishing art and nature on one hand, and natural and violent arts on the other."
      }
    ]
  ]
}

We have highlighted the subordination of artificial\ngoal-directedness to natural teleology, and consequently have shown them to be\nintimately related. Rather, we argued his\nobjection has to do with their inversion of the order of priority between the\ntwo, which in turn results in a failure to identify the explanatory cause of\ngoal-directedness and to provide scientific accounts of teleological change.\nFinally , we have said that recognizing the secondary place of artificial\ngoal-directedness does not undermine the value of craft analogies, but in fact\nmakes these analogies all the more enlightening, both when it comes to"

        "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have further refined the summary as follows:\n\nAristotle's philosophy of composition emphasizes the importance of form and organization in determining the nature and unity of a whole, while denying artifacts the status of substance due to their incomplete essence. Artificial forms are less complete and powerful than natural forms, as they do not enable artifacts to maintain or reproduce their form without intervention from an outside agent. Natural forms, on the other hand, grant composites a different kind of potency, making them capable in a fuller, more actual sense. This distinction between artifacts, natural substances, and heaps grounds the possibility of distinguishing art and nature on one hand, and natural and violent arts on the other.\n\nIn this context, the author highlights that Aristotle's objection to his predecessor's teleological principles is not due to an analogy between natural and artificial goal-directedness, but rather due to their inversion of the order of priority between the two. This inversion results in a failure to identify the explanatory cause of goal-directedness and provide scientific accounts of teleological change.\n\nThe author also provides an alternative view of Aristotle's objection, which emphasizes the subordination of artificial goal-directedness to natural teleology. This view recognizes that while craft analogies can be enlightening, they must be understood in relation to the ontological priority of natural ends.\n\nIn summary, Aristotle's philosophy of composition emphasizes the importance of form and organization in determining the nature and unity of a whole, while denying artifacts the status of substance due to their incomplete essence. This distinction between artifacts, natural substances, and heaps grounds the possibility of distinguishing art and nature on one hand, and natural and violent arts on the other."

  "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have further refined the summary as follows:\n\nAristotle's philosophy of composition emphasizes the importance of form and organization in determining the nature and unity of a whole, while denying artifacts the status of substance due to their incomplete essence. Artificial forms are less complete and powerful than natural forms, as they do not enable artifacts to maintain or reproduce their form without intervention from an outside agent. Natural forms, on the other hand, grant composites a different kind of potency, making them capable in a fuller, more actual sense. This distinction between artifacts, natural substances, and heaps grounds the possibility of distinguishing art and nature on one hand, and natural and violent arts on the other.\n\nIn this context, the author highlights that Aristotle's objection to his predecessor's teleological principles is not due to an analogy between natural and artificial goal-directedness, but rather due to their inversion of the order of priority between the two. This inversion results in a failure to identify the explanatory cause of goal-directedness and provide scientific accounts of teleological change.\n\nThe author also provides an alternative view of Aristotle's objection, which emphasizes the subordination of artificial goal-directedness to natural teleology. This view recognizes that while craft analogies can be enlightening, they must be understood in relation to the ontological priority of natural ends.\n\nIn summary, Aristotle's philosophy of composition emphasizes the importance of form and organization in determining the nature and unity of a whole, while denying artifacts the status of substance due to their incomplete essence. This distinction between artifacts, natural substances, and heaps grounds the possibility of distinguishing art and nature on one hand, and natural and violent arts on the other."
}

Additionally, goal-directedness does not undermine the value of craft analogies, but rather makes these analogies all the more enlightening in understanding both nature and the arts. The result is a view of crafts that is not opposed to, but rather understood in relation to natural self-actualization processes, and consequently has its place within the scope of Aristotleâ€™s natural teleology.\n\nIn summary, Aristotle's philosophy of composition emphasizes the importance of form and organization in determining the nature and unity of a whole, while denying artifacts the status of substance due to their incomplete essence. We have challenged the first (a) claim above and shall now turn our\nattention to the realm of natural change, and attempt to provide an alternative\nto (b) the narrowly internalist perspective. [159] Â In short, we will show that\nAristotleâ€™s view of natural change extends to some Â instrumental relations, thus\nfurther developing our thesis that there does exist a middle-ground between\nself-actualiz ation and arbitrary use. We have said that Johnsonâ€™s strictly\nintrinsic Â view of natural change rests on the premise that the internal,\nintrinsic and explanatory characters of natural causes are equivalent. Simply,\nhis view presupposes that if a cause is not internal, it is unnatural and\nscientifically irrelevant. As a result, he must deny the possibility of natural\ninstrumental relations [160] Â because of the agent-patient differentiation they\nentail. Thus he establishes a sharp contrast between natural self-actualization\n(which is for the sake of an intrinsic end ) and artificial instrumentalization\n(which is for the sake of Â an extrinsic end) ; and claims that Aristotelian\nteleology is exclusively concerned with the former. Â  In this view, a substance\neither naturally strives for its intrinsic telos , or it is artificially (which\nis the same as to say arbitrarily) assigned an extrinsic and incidental end.\n[161]"

Additionally, goal-directedness does not undermine the value of craft analogies, but rather makes these analogies all the more enlightening in understanding both nature and the arts. The author suggests that Aristotle's teleology is concerned with both natural self-actualization (which is for the sake of an intrinsic end) and artificial instrumentalization (which is for the sake of an extrinsic end), and denies the possibility of natural instrumental relations.\n\nThe original summary remains unchanged:\n\nAristotle's philosophy of composition emphasizes the importance of form and organization in determining the nature and unity of a whole, while denying artifacts the status of substance due to their incomplete essence.         "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have further refined the summary as follows:\n\nAristotle's philosophy of composition emphasizes the importance of form and organization in determining the nature and unity of a whole, while denying artifacts the status of substance due to their incomplete essence. The distinction between artifacts, natural substances, and heaps grounds the possibility of distinguishing art and nature on one hand, and natural and violent arts on the other. Additionally, goal-directedness does not undermine the value of craft analogies, but rather makes these analogies all the more enlightening in understanding both nature and the arts. In chapter two, the author challenges a dichotomous view of nature and the arts by arguing that Aristotle's view of natural change extends to some instrumental relations, providing an alternative to a narrowly internalist perspective. The author suggests that Aristotle's teleology is concerned with both natural self-actualization (which is for the sake of an intrinsic end) and artificial instrumentalization (which is for the sake of an extrinsic end), and denies the possibility of natural instrumental relations.\n\nThe original summary remains unchanged:\n\nAristotle's philosophy of composition emphasizes the importance of form and organization in determining the nature and unity of a whole, while denying artifacts the status of substance due to their incomplete essence. The distinction between artifacts, natural substances, and heaps grounds the possibility of distinguishing art and nature on one hand, and natural and violent arts on the other. Additionally, goal-directedness does not undermine the value of craft analogies, but rather makes these analogies all the more enlightening in understanding both nature and the arts."
      }
    ]
  ]
}

  "text": "In what follows, we will argue that the main difficulty which faces this\nperspective is that it rests on an unbalanced view of composite substances.\n[162] Â Consider for instance Johnsonâ€™s account of the relation between a living\nbody and the elements which constitute it; in order to maintain his strictly\ninternalist view of natural change, Johnson has to claim that the elements are\ndestroyed or completely transformed when they become part of a higher level\nnatural entity. [163] Â  This is because the telos Â of the body does Â not belong\nto the elements intrinsically, and therefore if they retain their nature,\nJohnson thinks their contribution to the self-actualization of the body requires\nan extrinsic (thus artificial and incidental) teleological account. Once again,\nwe will argue that Johnsonâ€™s position is limited rather than wrong. He is right\nthat, fundamentally, Aristotleâ€™s view of natural change must be understood in\nterms of the self-actualization of a specific nature; and to insist that the\nexplanatory cause of natural change cannot be extrinsic on Aristotleâ€™s account.\nThe mistake, we will argue, is to conclude that all instrumental relations are\ntherefore unnatural and scientifically irrelevant. In short, we will argue that\nJohnson's view is too narrow because it ignores the possibility that some\nnatural relations are neither straightforwardly intrinsic or extrinsic. Let us\ninsist that we will not be defending a view of Aristotelian teleology which\nextends to strictly extrinsic instrumental relations. Rather, our aim is to\nexpand our understanding of intrinsic teleology in order to encompass some\nprocesses which are typically excluded because they are thought to require\nextrinsic and artificial teleological explanations. In what follows, we will be\nconcerned with three main questions; (1) does the Aristotelian view of nature\ninclude some instrumentalization processes, if so (2) what is their Â relation to\nself-actualization processes, and (3) are they teleologically explicable?"

  "text": "With regards to the first question, some scholars [164] Â have highlighted\ninstances of instrumental relations which are presupposed by Aristotleâ€™s\nintrinsic Â  teleological accounts such as the use of nutrients in digestion or\nthe way the body uses elements to constitute its tissues and organs, etc. [165]\nÂ  A plant is no more intrinsically inclined to contribute to the nutrition and\ngrowth of the animal which eats it than is the water in the eye inwardly\ndirected to the realization of sight. In these and similar cases, a natural\nsubstance instrumentalizes Â another, not for the sake of Â realizing an arbitrary\nfantasy, but in order to actualize its nature. This undermines the strictly\ninternalist view of nature because it means that at least some natural\nsubstances cannot actualize their nature â€˜on their ownâ€™. [166] Â  The fact that\nwe find accounts of instrumental relations in Aristotleâ€™s biological works\nsuggests that he considered that the externality entailed by such relations can\nbe reconciled with the internality which characterizes natural change. However,\nit remains for us to clarify the nature of this reconciliation. We have briefly\naddressed this topic in the introduction, [167] Â but will now provide a more\ncomprehensive analysis and address some questions raised by our preliminary\nanswer.\n\nFirst, it will be useful to delineate the scope of our present inquiry. Some of\nthe instrumentalization processes identified Â by the scholars Â mentioned above\nÂ raise questions regarding relations at higher levels of organization ( e.g. wi\nthin households, cities, animal communities, etc.) While these questions are\nworthy of consideration, given the purpose of the present chapter, it will be\nsufficient to restrict our attention to cases of instrumentalization involved in\nthe functioning of middle-sized organisms Â such as plants and animals. [168]\nÂ The following investigation will be centered on the relation between natural\nsubstances and their constitutive elements. We will argue that part-whole\nrelations within natural substances are not always strictly intrinsic on\nAristotleâ€™s account, and that consequently, his view of natural change does in\nfact involve instrumentalization.\n\n\n\n\nTHE APORIA"

  "prompts": [
    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: Based on the provided portion of the article, I have further refined the summary as follows:\n\nAristotle's philosophy of composition emphasizes the importance of form and organization in determining the nature and unity of a whole, while denying artifacts the status of substance due to their incomplete essence. The distinction between artifacts, natural substances, and heaps grounds the possibility of distinguishing art and nature on one hand, and natural and violent arts on the other. Additionally, goal-directedness does not undermine the value of craft analogies, but rather makes these analogies all the more enlightening in understanding both nature and the arts. The author challenges a dichotomous view of nature and the arts by arguing that Aristotle's view of natural change extends to some instrumental relations, providing an alternative to a narrowly internalist perspective. The author suggests that Aristotle's teleology is concerned with both natural self-actualization (which is for the sake of an intrinsic end) and artificial instrumentalization (which is for the sake of an extrinsic end), and denies the possibility of natural instrumental relations. The article questions whether the Aristotelian view of nature includes some instrumentalization processes, their relation to self-actualization processes, and whether they are teleologically explicable.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nWith regards to the first question, some scholars [164] Â have highlighted\ninstances of instrumental relations which are presupposed by Aristotleâ€™s\nintrinsic Â  teleological accounts such as the use of nutrients in digestion or\nthe way the body uses elements to constitute its tissues and organs, etc. [165]\nÂ  A plant is no more intrinsically inclined to contribute to the nutrition and\ngrowth of the animal which eats it than is the water in the eye inwardly\ndirected to the realization of sight. In these and similar cases, a natural\nsubstance instrumentalizes Â another, not for the sake of Â realizing an arbitrary\nfantasy, but in order to actualize its nature. This undermines the strictly\ninternalist view of nature because it means that at least some natural\nsubstances cannot actualize their nature â€˜on their ownâ€™. [166] Â  The fact that\nwe find accounts of instrumental relations in Aristotleâ€™s biological works\nsuggests that he considered that the externality entailed by such relations can\nbe reconciled with the internality which characterizes natural change. However,\nit remains for us to clarify the nature of this reconciliation. We have briefly\naddressed this topic in the introduction, [167] Â but will now provide a more\ncomprehensive analysis and address some questions raised by our preliminary\nanswer.\n\nFirst, it will be useful to delineate the scope of our present inquiry. Some of\nthe instrumentalization processes identified Â by the scholars Â mentioned above\nÂ raise questions regarding relations at higher levels of organization ( e.g. wi\nthin households, cities, animal communities, etc.) While these questions are\nworthy of consideration, given the purpose of the present chapter, it will be\nsufficient to restrict our attention to cases of instrumentalization involved in\nthe functioning of middle-sized organisms Â such as plants and animals. [168]\nÂ The following investigation will be centered on the relation between natural\nsubstances and their constitutive elements. We will argue that part-whole\nrelations within natural substances are not always strictly intrinsic on\nAristotleâ€™s account, and that consequently, his view of natural change does in\nfact involve instrumentalization.\n\n\n\n\nTHE APORIA\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"
  ]
}

  "text": "THE APORIA\n\nA Â distinction is commonly [169] Â made between compositional and functional\nparts. Functional parts are quasi-substances such as tissues and organs, whose\nformal and final principles are completely defined in relation to the whole they\nconstitute, whereas compositional parts are substances in their own right (e.g.\nthe material elements which constitute the tissues and organs), which can be\ndefined (and exist) apart from the whole they constitute. The homonymy\nÂ principle [170] Â thus applies to the former, but not the latter. The nature\n(formal and final cause) of functional parts is completely determined in\nrelation to that of the body, thus once the body loses its formal and final\ncause (through death), they can no longer perform their biological function and\nconsequently no longer â€˜have a natureâ€™; while they may still look the same\noutwardly, in truth they no longer are what it was for them to be a specific\nbody part. Compositional parts, on the other hand, are not defined in relation\nto the body they constitute, thus the homonymy principle does not apply to them,\nand they can survive the death of the organism. The water which constitutes eye\ntissues, for instance, does not cease to be water at the death of an animal.\n[171]"
}

[32m[chain/start][39m [[90m1:chain:RefineDocumentsChain > [1m90:chain:LLMChain[22m[39m] Entering Chain run with input: {
  "existing_answer": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have further refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe author argues that Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances can be reconciled with his theory of natural change through the concept of instrumental relations. The author provides examples from Aristotle's biological works, such as nutrients in digestion and elements used to constitute tissues and organs, which suggest that Aristotle considered that externality can be reconciled with internality in natural change. The author aims to clarify the nature of this reconciliation and investigate part-whole relations within natural substances, arguing that they are not always strictly intrinsic on Aristotle's account. The article questions whether Aristotle's teleology is concerned with both natural self-actualization and artificial instrumentalization, and whether these processes are teleologically explicable.\n\nThe author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works, with the former being defined in relation to the whole they constitute and the latter being quasi-substances with their own formal and final principles. The homonymy principle thus applies to compositional parts but not to functional parts. The author argues that compositional parts can survive the death of an organism, while functional parts cease to be what they were for them to be a specific body part.\n\nOverall, the article explores the reconciliation of Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances with his theory of natural change, and investigates the nature of part-whole relations within natural substances on his account.",
  "text": "Because functional parts are completely defined in relation to the organism, the\ntelos Â of the latter ( e.g. life, nutrition, reproduction) belongs Â to them\nintrinsically. Â Thus given the purpose of the present investigation, our focus\nwill be the relation of organized bodies to their compositional parts, for only\nthey may be said to exhibit a sufficient degree of independence so as to be\ninstrumentalized Â by the body. Some scholars adopt a strictly intrinsic view of\nthis relation and claim that constitutive elements, like tissues and organs, are\ncompletely defined by the formal cause of the organism they constitute. As a\nresult, they undermine the distinction between functional and compositional\nparts. Others emphasize the distinction and defend a strictly extrinsic view\nwhich takes compositional matter to be a distinct substance which is â€˜usedâ€™ by\nthe body in a similar fashion to how external objects are used. The surprising\ndiversity of approaches to this issue is born from a tension, inherent to the\nAristotelian view of substance, between the composite and individual nature of\nhylomorphic substances. [172] Â It is generally agreed that the resolution of\nthis difficulty lies in appealing to the notions of actuality and potentiality\nÂ which are developed in books VIII and IX of the Metaphysics . In short, the\nsolution is said to be that the elements which act as the material cause of\nnatural substances exist potentially . The controversy lies in how to understand\nthe potentiality ascribed to compositional matter. Are the elements which\ncompose tissues potential Â in the sense that they no longer possess the\nsubstantial form which made them a â€˜thisâ€™; or should we rather say that, insofar\nas they are part of a higher level structure, they are being prevented from\nfully actualizing their nature? For instance, is the water in the eye tissue\npotentially Â  water in the same way that earth is potentially water, namely in\nthe sense that, while it does not possess the substantial form of water, it\nremains the kind of thing which could Â acquire it; or does it retain its\nsubstantial form ( i.e. remain water) and is called potential simply because it\nis being prevented from fully actualizing its nature? While it is beyond the\nscope of this paper to resolve the difficulty, we shall attempt a preliminary\ndelineation of the main solutions developed by scholars in order to situate our\nown perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue. Three main ways to\napproach the difficulty are; (1) eliminativism; denying the status of substance\nto elements altogether, (2) neutralism; claiming that while the elements are\nsubstances when they exist in isolation, they lose that status upon becoming\npart of tissues because they are completely transformed (destroyed) as they gain\ntheir â€˜new identityâ€™ within the context of composition, and (3) dualism;\nÂ maintaining that the elements are altered, but not destroyed in the process of"
}

  "existing_answer": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have further refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe author argues that Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances can be reconciled with his theory of natural change through the concept of instrumental relations. The author provides examples from Aristotle's biological works, such as nutrients in digestion and elements used to constitute tissues and organs, which suggest that Aristotle considered that externality can be reconciled with internality in natural change. The author aims to clarify the nature of this reconciliation and investigate part-whole relations within natural substances, arguing that they are not always strictly intrinsic on Aristotle's account. The article questions whether Aristotle's teleology is concerned with both natural self-actualization and artificial instrumentalization, and whether these processes are teleologically explicable.\n\nThe author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works, with the former being defined in relation to the whole they constitute and the latter being quasi-substances with their own formal and final principles. The homonymy principle thus applies to compositional parts but not to functional parts. The author argues that compositional parts can survive the death of an organism, while functional parts cease to be what they were for them to be a specific body part.\n\nOverall, the article explores the reconciliation of Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances with his theory of natural change, and investigates the nature of part-whole relations within natural substances on his account.",
  "text": "Because functional parts are completely defined in relation to the organism, the\ntelos Â of the latter ( e.g. life, nutrition, reproduction) belongs Â to them\nintrinsically. Â Thus given the purpose of the present investigation, our focus\nwill be the relation of organized bodies to their compositional parts, for only\nthey may be said to exhibit a sufficient degree of independence so as to be\ninstrumentalized Â by the body. Some scholars adopt a strictly intrinsic view of\nthis relation and claim that constitutive elements, like tissues and organs, are\ncompletely defined by the formal cause of the organism they constitute. As a\nresult, they undermine the distinction between functional and compositional\nparts. Others emphasize the distinction and defend a strictly extrinsic view\nwhich takes compositional matter to be a distinct substance which is â€˜usedâ€™ by\nthe body in a similar fashion to how external objects are used. The surprising\ndiversity of approaches to this issue is born from a tension, inherent to the\nAristotelian view of substance, between the composite and individual nature of\nhylomorphic substances. [172] Â It is generally agreed that the resolution of\nthis difficulty lies in appealing to the notions of actuality and potentiality\nÂ which are developed in books VIII and IX of the Metaphysics . In short, the\nsolution is said to be that the elements which act as the material cause of\nnatural substances exist potentially . The controversy lies in how to understand\nthe potentiality ascribed to compositional matter. Are the elements which\ncompose tissues potential Â in the sense that they no longer possess the\nsubstantial form which made them a â€˜thisâ€™; or should we rather say that, insofar\nas they are part of a higher level structure, they are being prevented from\nfully actualizing their nature? For instance, is the water in the eye tissue\npotentially Â  water in the same way that earth is potentially water, namely in\nthe sense that, while it does not possess the substantial form of water, it\nremains the kind of thing which could Â acquire it; or does it retain its\nsubstantial form ( i.e. remain water) and is called potential simply because it\nis being prevented from fully actualizing its nature? While it is beyond the\nscope of this paper to resolve the difficulty, we shall attempt a preliminary\ndelineation of the main solutions developed by scholars in order to situate our\nown perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue. Three main ways to\napproach the difficulty are; (1) eliminativism; denying the status of substance\nto elements altogether, (2) neutralism; claiming that while the elements are\nsubstances when they exist in isolation, they lose that status upon becoming\npart of tissues because they are completely transformed (destroyed) as they gain\ntheir â€˜new identityâ€™ within the context of composition, and (3) dualism;\nÂ maintaining that the elements are altered, but not destroyed in the process of"

    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: Based on the provided portion of the article, I have further refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe author argues that Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances can be reconciled with his theory of natural change through the concept of instrumental relations. The author provides examples from Aristotle's biological works, such as nutrients in digestion and elements used to constitute tissues and organs, which suggest that Aristotle considered that externality can be reconciled with internality in natural change. The author aims to clarify the nature of this reconciliation and investigate part-whole relations within natural substances, arguing that they are not always strictly intrinsic on Aristotle's account. The article questions whether Aristotle's teleology is concerned with both natural self-actualization and artificial instrumentalization, and whether these processes are teleologically explicable.\n\nThe author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works, with the former being defined in relation to the whole they constitute and the latter being quasi-substances with their own formal and final principles. The homonymy principle thus applies to compositional parts but not to functional parts. The author argues that compositional parts can survive the death of an organism, while functional parts cease to be what they were for them to be a specific body part.\n\nOverall, the article explores the reconciliation of Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances with his theory of natural change, and investigates the nature of part-whole relations within natural substances on his account.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nBecause functional parts are completely defined in relation to the organism, the\ntelos Â of the latter ( e.g. life, nutrition, reproduction) belongs Â to them\nintrinsically. Â Thus given the purpose of the present investigation, our focus\nwill be the relation of organized bodies to their compositional parts, for only\nthey may be said to exhibit a sufficient degree of independence so as to be\ninstrumentalized Â by the body. Some scholars adopt a strictly intrinsic view of\nthis relation and claim that constitutive elements, like tissues and organs, are\ncompletely defined by the formal cause of the organism they constitute. As a\nresult, they undermine the distinction between functional and compositional\nparts. Others emphasize the distinction and defend a strictly extrinsic view\nwhich takes compositional matter to be a distinct substance which is â€˜usedâ€™ by\nthe body in a similar fashion to how external objects are used. The surprising\ndiversity of approaches to this issue is born from a tension, inherent to the\nAristotelian view of substance, between the composite and individual nature of\nhylomorphic substances. [172] Â It is generally agreed that the resolution of\nthis difficulty lies in appealing to the notions of actuality and potentiality\nÂ which are developed in books VIII and IX of the Metaphysics . In short, the\nsolution is said to be that the elements which act as the material cause of\nnatural substances exist potentially . The controversy lies in how to understand\nthe potentiality ascribed to compositional matter. Are the elements which\ncompose tissues potential Â in the sense that they no longer possess the\nsubstantial form which made them a â€˜thisâ€™; or should we rather say that, insofar\nas they are part of a higher level structure, they are being prevented from\nfully actualizing their nature? For instance, is the water in the eye tissue\npotentially Â  water in the same way that earth is potentially water, namely in\nthe sense that, while it does not possess the substantial form of water, it\nremains the kind of thing which could Â acquire it; or does it retain its\nsubstantial form ( i.e. remain water) and is called potential simply because it\nis being prevented from fully actualizing its nature?         "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe article explores Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances and their reconciliation with his theory of natural change, focusing on part-whole relations within natural substances. The author does not provide a definitive resolution but situates their perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue.\n\nHere is the original summary again for your reference:\n\nIn summary, the article examines the reconciliation of Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances with his theory of natural change, specifically focusing on part-whole relations within natural substances. The author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works and discusses the potentiality of compositional matter in relation to the homonymy principle. Three main ways to approach the difficulty of understanding the potentiality of compositional matter are presented: eliminativism, neutralism, and dualism. The author does not provide a definitive resolution but aims to situate their own perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue."
      }
    ]
  ]
}

The author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works and discusses the potentiality of compositional matter in relation to the homonymy principle. Three main approaches to resolve the difficulty of understanding the potentiality of compositional matter are presented: eliminativism, neutralism, and dualism. The author does not provide a definitive resolution but situates their perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue.\n\nHere is the original summary again for your reference:\n\nIn summary, the article examines the reconciliation of Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances with his theory of natural change, specifically focusing on part-whole relations within natural substances.   "existing_answer": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe article explores Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances and their reconciliation with his theory of natural change, focusing on part-whole relations within natural substances. The author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works and discusses the potentiality of compositional matter in relation to the homonymy principle. Three main approaches to resolve the difficulty of understanding the potentiality of compositional matter are presented: eliminativism, neutralism, and dualism. The author does not provide a definitive resolution but situates their perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue.\n\nHere is the original summary again for your reference:\n\nIn summary, the article examines the reconciliation of Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances with his theory of natural change, specifically focusing on part-whole relations within natural substances. The author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works and discusses the potentiality of compositional matter in relation to the homonymy principle. Three main ways to approach the difficulty of understanding the potentiality of compositional matter are presented: eliminativism, neutralism, and dualism. The author does not provide a definitive resolution but aims to situate their own perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue.",
  "text": "The first two approaches rest on a strictly intrinsic view of the relation of\nsubstances to their compositional matter, whereas the latter presupposes a\nstrictly extrinsic relation. In what follows, we will show the limitations of\nboth extremes and suggest that the relation between natural substances and their\ncompositional parts is best described as quasi-intrinsic.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTHE LIMITATIONS OF THE STRICTLY INTRINSIC VIEW\n\n\nELIMINATIVISM\n\nPeterson, [173] Â  in her Â article Unity, Plurality, and Hylomorphic Composition\nin Aristotleâ€™s Metaphysics, Â argues that being and unity are equivocal terms,\nmeaning that there is no such thing as being or unity tout Â court .\nConsequently, she argues that the alleged conflict between the unity of\nhylomorphic substances and the multiplicity of their constitutive elements can\nbe avoided once we recognize that they have being and unity in different ways.\nMore precisely, she relies on the opening lines of Metaph ysics VII 16 in order\nto argue that matter is not a substance, but â€œonly potentiality.â€ Â  Thus\nPeterson views potentiality as an inherent character of the â€˜kind of beingâ€™ that\nmatter is. [174] Â While her approach is interesting in many respects, Â it is\nlimited first in that it rests on a confusion of matter (a kind of being) and\nmaterial causes (a role played by determinate beings) [175] Â and second , in\nthat it creates a tension with the way in which Aristotle speaks of the elements\nin other contexts. Indeed, the opening passage of VII 16 reads â€œearth and fire\nand air; for none of them is a unity, but as it were Â a mere heap, till they are\nworked up and some unity is made of themâ€ , [176] Â  thus Â if Peterson is right\nthat, in this passage, Aristotle is teaching us about the â€˜kind of beingâ€™ that\nthe elements are, then it contradicts the accounts we find in the treatises on\nMeteorology and Physics for instance, where the elements are by no means\npresented as mere heaps. In what follows, we will suggest that potentiality\nshould be understood as a relational property rather than an intrinsic character\nof material causes. If we adopt this view, Aristotleâ€™s characterization of the\nelements in these different contexts entails no contradiction for the same\nreason that there is no contradiction involved in calling an object big and\nsmall, when considered from different perspectives. Simply, qua material\nprinciple (which is how they are treated in Metaph. VII 16), Aristotle considers\nthe elements to be akin to a heap in need to be unified, but qua Â substance,\nthey are unified and goal-directed beings. Thus it appears that the two\nlimitations of Petersonâ€™s perspective are intimately related, for the confusion\nof the relative indeterminacy of the elements qua Â material cause with their\ninherent nature rests on the failure to distinguish properly between matter and\nmaterial causes.\n\n\n\n\nNEUTRALISM"
}

Three main approaches to resolve the difficulty of understanding the potentiality of compositional matter are presented: eliminativism, neutralism, and dualism. The author does not provide a definitive resolution but situates their perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue.\n\nIn this portion of the article, the author argues that both the strictly intrinsic view and the strictly extrinsic view have limitations. The eliminativist approach, argued by Peterson, relies on a confusion between matter and material causes, creating a tension with Aristotle's characterization of the elements in other contexts. The neutralist approach, on the other hand, fails to distinguish properly between matter and material causes.\n\nThe author suggests that potentiality should be understood as a relational property rather than an intrinsic character of material causes. This view allows for the reconciliation of Aristotle's characterization of the elements in different contexts without contradicting each other. The two limitations of Peterson's perspective are intimately related, and refining the summary highlights the importance of distinguishing between matter and material causes in understanding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances."

[180] Â  Simply, the tension lies in the fact that the elements, while\nthey no longer remain specifically Â what they once were, can still be said to\ncontribute in specific ways to the compound.   "text": "NEUTRALISM\n\nAnother way to approach the difficulty of hylomorphic unity is to claim that,\nwhile the elements are indeed substances, when they are combined and form\nhomogeneous tissues they are transformed and no longer retain their substantial\nform. [177] Â Gill develops this view in her book Aristotle on Substance: The\nParadox of Unity. [178] Â Because she does recognize the relative nature of\nAristotleâ€™s notion of potentiality [179] Â  there Â remains a tension in her\naccount of the role played by Â compositional matter; while she claims the\nelements do not actually Â persist in tissue formation, she does note that they\ncontribute something to hylomorphic compounds; as she puts it â€œtheir presence is\nfeltâ€. [180] Â  Simply, the tension lies in the fact that the elements, while\nthey no longer remain specifically Â what they once were, can still be said to\ncontribute in specific ways to the compound. [181]"
}
