  "prompts": [
    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe article explores Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances and their reconciliation with his theory of natural change, focusing on part-whole relations within natural substances. The author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works and discusses the potentiality of compositional matter in relation to the homonymy principle. Three main approaches to resolve the difficulty of understanding the potentiality of compositional matter are presented: eliminativism, neutralism, and dualism. The author does not provide a definitive resolution but situates their perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue.\n\nIn this portion of the article, the author argues that both the strictly intrinsic view and the strictly extrinsic view have limitations. The eliminativist approach, argued by Peterson, relies on a confusion between matter and material causes, creating a tension with Aristotle's characterization of the elements in other contexts. The neutralist approach, on the other hand, fails to distinguish properly between matter and material causes.\n\nThe author suggests that potentiality should be understood as a relational property rather than an intrinsic character of material causes. This view allows for the reconciliation of Aristotle's characterization of the elements in different contexts without contradicting each other. The two limitations of Peterson's perspective are intimately related, and refining the summary highlights the importance of distinguishing between matter and material causes in understanding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nNEUTRALISM\n\nAnother way to approach the difficulty of hylomorphic unity is to claim that,\nwhile the elements are indeed substances, when they are combined and form\nhomogeneous tissues they are transformed and no longer retain their substantial\nform. [177] Â Gill develops this view in her book Aristotle on Substance: The\nParadox of Unity. [178] Â Because she does recognize the relative nature of\nAristotleâ€™s notion of potentiality [179] Â  there Â remains a tension in her\naccount of the role played by Â compositional matter; while she claims the\nelements do not actually Â persist in tissue formation, she does note that they\ncontribute something to hylomorphic compounds; as she puts it â€œtheir presence is\nfeltâ€.   "prompts": [
    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe article explores Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances and their reconciliation with his theory of natural change, focusing on part-whole relations within natural substances. The author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works and discusses the potentiality of compositional matter in relation to the homonymy principle. Three main approaches to resolve the difficulty of understanding the potentiality of compositional matter are presented: eliminativism, neutralism, and dualism. The author does not provide a definitive resolution but situates their perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue.\n\nIn this portion of the article, the author argues that both the strictly intrinsic view and the strictly extrinsic view have limitations. The eliminativist approach, argued by Peterson, relies on a confusion between matter and material causes, creating a tension with Aristotle's characterization of the elements in other contexts. The neutralist approach, on the other hand, fails to distinguish properly between matter and material causes.\n\nThe author suggests that potentiality should be understood as a relational property rather than an intrinsic character of material causes. This view allows for the reconciliation of Aristotle's characterization of the elements in different contexts without contradicting each other. The two limitations of Peterson's perspective are intimately related, and refining the summary highlights the importance of distinguishing between matter and material causes in understanding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nNEUTRALISM\n\nAnother way to approach the difficulty of hylomorphic unity is to claim that,\nwhile the elements are indeed substances, when they are combined and form\nhomogeneous tissues they are transformed and no longer retain their substantial\nform. [177] Â Gill develops this view in her book Aristotle on Substance: The\nParadox of Unity. [178] Â Because she does recognize the relative nature of\nAristotleâ€™s notion of potentiality [179] Â  there Â remains a tension in her\naccount of the role played by Â compositional matter; while she claims the\nelements do not actually Â persist in tissue formation, she does note that they\ncontribute something to hylomorphic compounds; as she puts it â€œtheir presence is\nfeltâ€. [180] Â  Simply, the tension lies in the fact that the elements, while\nthey no longer remain specifically Â what they once were, can still be said to\ncontribute in specific ways to the compound. [181]\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"
  ]

  "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "Based on the new context provided, here is a refined summary of the article:\n\nThe author discusses Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances and their reconciliation with his theory of natural change, focusing on part-whole relations within natural substances. The author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works and discusses the potentiality of compositional matter in relation to the homonymy principle. Three main approaches to resolve the difficulty of understanding the potentiality of compositional matter are presented: eliminativism, neutralism, and dualism. The author does not provide a definitive resolution but situates their perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue.\n\nThe author argues that both the strictly intrinsic view and the strictly extrinsic view have limitations. The eliminativist approach, argued by Peterson, relies on a confusion between matter and material causes, creating a tension with Aristotle's characterization of the elements in other contexts. The neutralist approach, on the other hand, fails to distinguish properly between matter and material causes.\n\nThe author suggests that potentiality should be understood as a relational property rather than an intrinsic character of material causes. This view allows for the reconciliation of Aristotle's characterization of the elements in different contexts without contradicting each other. The two limitations of Peterson's perspective are intimately related, and refining the summary highlights the importance of distinguishing between matter and material causes in understanding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances.\n\nIn the new context, the author discusses Gill's neutralist approach, which recognizes the relative nature of Aristotle's notion of potentiality but struggles to reconcile it with the persistence of compositional matter in hylomorphic compounds. The tension lies in the fact that while the elements no longer remain specifically what they once were, they can still contribute in specific ways to the compound.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the ongoing discussion and debate surrounding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances, and how different approaches grapple with the tension between matter and material causes."
      }
    ]
  ]
}

The author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works and discusses the potentiality of compositional matter in relation to the homonymy principle. Three main approaches to resolve the difficulty of understanding the potentiality of compositional matter are presented: eliminativism, neutralism, and dualism. The author does not provide a definitive resolution but situates their perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue.\n\nThe author argues that both the strictly intrinsic view and the strictly extrinsic view have limitations. The eliminativist approach, argued by Peterson, relies on a confusion between matter and material causes, creating a tension with Aristotle's characterization of the elements in other contexts. The neutralist approach, on the other hand, fails to distinguish properly between matter and material causes.\n\nThe author suggests that potentiality should be understood as a relational property rather than an intrinsic character of material causes. This view allows for the reconciliation of Aristotle's characterization of the elements in different contexts without contradicting each other. The two limitations of Peterson's perspective are intimately related, and refining the summary highlights the importance of distinguishing between matter and material causes in understanding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances.\n\nIn the new context, the author discusses Gill's neutralist approach, which recognizes the relative nature of Aristotle's notion of potentiality but struggles to reconcile it with the persistence of compositional matter in hylomorphic compounds. The tension lies in the fact that while the elements no longer remain specifically what they once were, they can still contribute in specific ways to the compound.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the ongoing discussion and debate surrounding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances, and how different approaches grapple with the tension between matter and material causes."

From this she concludes that Aristotle thinks that wood does not\nsurvive the generation of a box; [182] Â and that, while the production starts\nwith wood, which exists as a definite subject, once the box is crafted â€œthe\noriginal wood, although it survives as a constituent, has become indefiniteâ€.\n[183] Â The mystery of her view lies in what it means for the wood to be such an\nindefinite subject; especially given the fact that its essential properties\ncontinue to be exhibited by the box. In short, Gillâ€™s view is that the\nproperties survive, [184] Â  while the subject does not, although eventually, it\n(the material cause e.g. the wood) will be â€œrecreated as a separately existing\nentityâ€. [185] Â According to Gill, maintaining that the elements persist through\nthe generation of a higher-level compound leads to materialism. She presumes\nthat if the wood is present in the wooden box; then the box is nothing more than\nwood. [186] Â However, we contend it is not necessary to deny the composite\nnature of substances in order to escape materialism; one only needs to assert\nthat the material constituents are not a sufficient explanation of the nature of\nthe higher substance. [187] Â In fact, it is reasonable to suppose that the\npractice of calling a box â€˜woodenâ€™ rather than â€˜woodâ€™ simply indicates that the\nbox is considered to be something more than just wood. To say this, however, is\nnot the same as saying that the wood is not present in the box, and it is\nunclear why we should take Aristotle to make the latter â€“ much more radicalâ€“\nÂ claim. Gill herself [188] Â recognizes the fact that the persistence of material\ncauses is evident to perception; and grants that, perhaps in the case of an\nartifact such as the wooden box, Aristotle would agree that the wood is still\npresent and identifiable even when it has become a box."

[185] Â According to Gill, maintaining that the elements persist through\nthe generation of a higher-level compound leads to materialism. She presumes\nthat if the wood is present in the wooden box; then the box is nothing more than\nwood. [186] Â However, we contend it is not necessary to deny the composite\nnature of substances in order to escape materialism; one only needs to assert\nthat the material constituents are not a sufficient explanation of the nature of\nthe higher substance. [187] Â In fact, it is reasonable to suppose that the\npractice of calling a box â€˜woodenâ€™ rather than â€˜woodâ€™ simply indicates that the\nbox is considered to be something more than just wood. To say this, however, is\nnot the same as saying that the wood is not present in the box, and it is\nunclear why we should take Aristotle to make the latter â€“ much more radicalâ€“\nÂ claim. Gill herself [188] Â recognizes the fact that the persistence of material\ncauses is evident to perception; and grants that, perhaps in the case of an\nartifact such as the wooden box, Aristotle would agree that the wood is still\npresent and identifiable even when it has become a box.\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"
  ]
}
[36m[llm/end][39m [[90m1:chain:RefineDocumentsChain > 98:chain:LLMChain > [1m99:llm:Ollama[22m[39m] [20.55s] Exiting LLM run with output: {
  "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "Based on the new context provided, here is a refined summary of the article:\n\nThe author discusses Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances and their reconciliation with his theory of natural change, focusing on part-whole relations within natural substances. The author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works and discusses the potentiality of compositional matter in relation to the homonymy principle. Three main approaches to resolve the difficulty of understanding the potentiality of compositional matter are presented: eliminativism, neutralism, and dualism. The author does not provide a definitive resolution but situates their perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue.\n\nThe author argues that both the strictly intrinsic view and the strictly extrinsic view have limitations. The eliminativist approach, argued by Peterson, relies on a confusion between matter and material causes, creating a tension with Aristotle's characterization of the elements in other contexts. The neutralist approach, on the other hand, fails to distinguish properly between matter and material causes.\n\nThe author suggests that potentiality should be understood as a relational property rather than an intrinsic character of material causes. This view allows for the reconciliation of Aristotle's characterization of the elements in different contexts without contradicting each other. The two limitations of Peterson's perspective are intimately related, and refining the summary highlights the importance of distinguishing between matter and material causes in understanding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances.\n\nIn the new context, the author discusses Gill's neutralist approach, which recognizes the relative nature of Aristotle's notion of potentiality but struggles to reconcile it with the persistence of compositional matter in hylomorphic compounds. The tension lies in the fact that while the elements no longer remain specifically what they once were, they can still contribute in specific ways to the compound.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the ongoing discussion and debate surrounding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances, and how different approaches grapple with the tension between matter and material causes."
      }
    ]
  ]
}

The two limitations of Peterson's perspective are intimately related, and refining the summary highlights the importance of distinguishing between matter and material causes in understanding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances.\n\nIn the new context, the author discusses Gill's neutralist approach, which recognizes the relative nature of Aristotle's notion of potentiality but struggles to reconcile it with the persistence of compositional matter in hylomorphic compounds.   "text": "The term neutralism [189] Â  which we have used to describe Gillâ€™s view is\nborrowed from Michel Loux who, in his article Composition and Unity: An\nExamination of Metaphysics H.6, Â challenges Gillâ€™s account of the role played by\nmaterial causes in the composition of hylomorphic compounds. [190] Â He notes,\namongst other things, that her account of Aristotleâ€™s solution to the problem of\nunity raised Â in Metaphysics Â VIII 6 [191] Â â€“ namely to deny definitional\nindependence to the constituents of hylomorphic substances â€“ is unpersuasive for\nthe examples which Aristotle invokes in that context mostly do not involve\nfunctional matter (the central example under discussion in the passage being\nthat of the bronze sphere). Most significant for our present purpose, Loux notes\nthat Gillâ€™s own account of the solution to what she calls the problem of\nâ€˜horizontal unityâ€™ [192] Â is to posit an underlying substratum which persists\nthrough change. Thus, if she wants to maintain that the elements are potential\nin the sense that they will once again exist in actuality after the death of the\norganism, she must posit a substratum which persists through the destruction and\nre-generation of these elements. [193] Â This substratum, Loux rightly notes, is\na distinct entity which composes the organic body and actually Â persists\nthroughout its life. Thus she defers rather than overcomes the aporia of\nhylomorphic unity. [194] Â \n\n\n\n\nTHE GREATEST DIFFICULTY\n\nThe most serious objection which faces the strictly Â intrinsic view which\nunderlie the solution s explored above [195] Â is that it undermines a key\npremise of hylomorphism. Aristotle insists on many occasions [196] Â that the\nnature of a hylomorphic compound is not reducible to its form. Consider for\ninstance his discussion of this issue in Metaphysics VII 11; in this passage, he\nfirst identifies the definition with the formal principle, which he insists is\nnot the same as the concrete thing. [197] Â He then explains that it is easier to\ndefine artifacts, for the distinction between the material and formal principles\nis made apparent by the fact that artificial forms can be instantiated in\ndifferent materials. By contrast, the form of man is always found in flesh and\nbones and so â€œwe are unable to effect the severance â€ ( Metaph . VII, 11\n1036b5). [198] Â Aristotle Â then establishes that, even if it is difficult for us\nto distinguish those principles, nonetheless they are distinct, Â i.e. Â the\nmaterial principle does contribute something to the compound, whose nature is\nnot exhausted by stating the formulable essence. [199] Â Although the\ncontribution of the material cause to the nature of an artifact is more evident\nfor us, Aristotle is clear that in truth ( per se ) it is in natural substances\nthat the contribution of the material cause is most crucial:"
}

    [
      {
        "text": "Based on the new context provided, here is a refined summary of the article:\n\nThe author discusses Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances and their reconciliation with his theory of natural change, focusing on part-whole relations within natural substances. The author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works and discusses the potentiality of compositional matter in relation to the homonymy principle. Three main approaches to resolve the difficulty of understanding the potentiality of compositional matter are presented: eliminativism, neutralism, and dualism. The author does not provide a definitive resolution but situates their perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue.\n\nThe author argues that both the strictly intrinsic view and the strictly extrinsic view have limitations. The eliminativist approach, argued by Peterson, relies on a confusion between matter and material causes, creating a tension with Aristotle's characterization of the elements in other contexts. The neutralist approach, on the other hand, fails to distinguish properly between matter and material causes.\n\nThe author suggests that potentiality should be understood as a relational property rather than an intrinsic character of material causes. This view allows for the reconciliation of Aristotle's characterization of the elements in different contexts without contradicting each other. The two limitations of Peterson's perspective are intimately related, and refining the summary highlights the importance of distinguishing between matter and material causes in understanding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances.\n\nIn the new context, the author discusses Gill's neutralist approach, which recognizes the relative nature of Aristotle's notion of potentiality but struggles to reconcile it with the persistence of compositional matter in hylomorphic compounds. The tension lies in the fact that while the elements no longer remain specifically what they once were, they can still contribute in specific ways to the compound.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the ongoing discussion and debate surrounding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances, and how different approaches grapple with the tension between matter and material causes."
      }
    ]
  ]
}

  "text": "Based on the new context provided, here is a refined summary of the article:\n\nThe author discusses Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances and their reconciliation with his theory of natural change, focusing on part-whole relations within natural substances. The author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works and discusses the potentiality of compositional matter in relation to the homonymy principle. Three main approaches to resolve the difficulty of understanding the potentiality of compositional matter are presented: eliminativism, neutralism, and dualism. The author does not provide a definitive resolution but situates their perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue.\n\nThe author argues that both the strictly intrinsic view and the strictly extrinsic view have limitations. The eliminativist approach, argued by Peterson, relies on a confusion between matter and material causes, creating a tension with Aristotle's characterization of the elements in other contexts. The neutralist approach, on the other hand, fails to distinguish properly between matter and material causes.\n\nThe author suggests that potentiality should be understood as a relational property rather than an intrinsic character of material causes. This view allows for the reconciliation of Aristotle's characterization of the elements in different contexts without contradicting each other. The two limitations of Peterson's perspective are intimately related, and refining the summary highlights the importance of distinguishing between matter and material causes in understanding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances.\n\nIn the new context, the author discusses Gill's neutralist approach, which recognizes the relative nature of Aristotle's notion of potentiality but struggles to reconcile it with the persistence of compositional matter in hylomorphic compounds. The tension lies in the fact that while the elements no longer remain specifically what they once were, they can still contribute in specific ways to the compound.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the ongoing discussion and debate surrounding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances, and how different approaches grapple with the tension between matter and material causes."
}

The author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works and discusses the potentiality of compositional matter in relation to the homonymy principle. Three main approaches to resolve the difficulty of understanding the potentiality of compositional matter are presented: eliminativism, neutralism, and dualism. The author does not provide a definitive resolution but situates their perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue.\n\nThe author argues that both the strictly intrinsic view and the strictly extrinsic view have limitations. The eliminativist approach, argued by Peterson, relies on a confusion between matter and material causes, creating a tension with Aristotle's characterization of the elements in other contexts. The neutralist approach, on the other hand, fails to distinguish properly between matter and material causes.\n\nThe author suggests that potentiality should be understood as a relational property rather than an intrinsic character of material causes. This view allows for the reconciliation of Aristotle's characterization of the elements in different contexts without contradicting each other. The tension lies in the fact that while the elements no longer remain specifically what they once were, they can still contribute in specific ways to the compound.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the ongoing discussion and debate surrounding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances, and how different approaches grapple with the tension between matter and material causes."

Three main approaches to resolve the difficulty of understanding the potentiality of compositional matter are presented: eliminativism, neutralism, and dualism. The tension lies in the fact that while the elements no longer remain specifically what they once were, they can still contribute in specific ways to the compound.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the ongoing discussion and debate surrounding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances, and how different approaches grapple with the tension between matter and material causes.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nAnd the comparison which Socrates the younger used to make in the case of\nanimal Â is not good; for it leads away from the truth, and makes one suppose\nthat man can possibly exist without his parts, as the circle can without the\nbronze. The author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works and discusses the potentiality of compositional matter in relation to the homonymy principle. Three main approaches to resolve the difficulty of understanding the potentiality of compositional matter are presented: eliminativism, neutralism, and dualism. The author does not provide a definitive resolution but situates their perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue.\n\nThe author argues that both the strictly intrinsic view and the strictly extrinsic view have limitations. The eliminativist approach, argued by Peterson, relies on a confusion between matter and material causes, creating a tension with Aristotle's characterization of the elements in other contexts. The neutralist approach, on the other hand, fails to distinguish properly between matter and material causes.\n\nThe author suggests that potentiality should be understood as a relational property rather than an intrinsic character of material causes. This view allows for the reconciliation of Aristotle's characterization of the elements in different contexts without contradicting each other. The two limitations of Peterson's perspective are intimately related, and refining the summary highlights the importance of distinguishing between matter and material causes in understanding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances.\n\nIn the new context, the author discusses Gill's neutralist approach, which recognizes the relative nature of Aristotle's notion of potentiality but struggles to reconcile it with the persistence of compositional matter in hylomorphic compounds. The tension lies in the fact that while the elements no longer remain specifically what they once were, they can still contribute in specific ways to the compound.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the ongoing discussion and debate surrounding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances, and how different approaches grapple with the tension between matter and material causes.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nAnd the comparison which Socrates the younger used to make in the case of\nanimal Â is not good; for it leads away from the truth, and makes one suppose\nthat man can possibly exist without his parts, as the circle can without the\nbronze.         "text": "Based on the provided context, here is a refined summary of the article:\n\nThe author discusses Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances and their reconciliation with his theory of natural change, focusing on part-whole relations within natural substances. The author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works and discusses the potentiality of compositional matter in relation to the homonymy principle. Three main approaches to resolve the difficulty of understanding the potentiality of compositional matter are presented: eliminativism, neutralism, and dualism. The author does not provide a definitive resolution but situates their perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue.\n\nThe author argues that both the strictly intrinsic view and the strictly extrinsic view have limitations. The eliminativist approach, argued by Peterson, relies on a confusion between matter and material causes, creating a tension with Aristotle's characterization of the elements in other contexts. The neutralist approach, on the other hand, fails to distinguish properly between matter and material causes.\n\nThe author suggests that potentiality should be understood as a relational property rather than an intrinsic character of material causes. This view allows for the reconciliation of Aristotle's characterization of the elements in different contexts without contradicting each other. The two limitations of Peterson's perspective are intimately related, and refining the summary highlights the importance of distinguishing between matter and material causes in understanding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances.\n\nIn the new context, the author discusses Gill's neutralist approach, which recognizes the relative nature of Aristotle's notion of potentiality but struggles to reconcile it with the persistence of compositional matter in hylomorphic compounds. The tension lies in the fact that while the elements no longer remain specifically what they once were, they can still contribute in specific ways to the compound.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the ongoing discussion and debate surrounding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances, and how different approaches grapple with the tension between matter and material causes."

[36m[chain/end][39m [[90m[1m1:chain:LLMChain[22m[39m] [18.95s] Exiting Chain run with output: {
  "text": "Based on the provided context, here is a refined summary of the article:\n\nThe author discusses Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances and their reconciliation with his theory of natural change, focusing on part-whole relations within natural substances. The author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works and discusses the potentiality of compositional matter in relation to the homonymy principle. Three main approaches to resolve the difficulty of understanding the potentiality of compositional matter are presented: eliminativism, neutralism, and dualism. The author does not provide a definitive resolution but situates their perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue.\n\nThe author argues that both the strictly intrinsic view and the strictly extrinsic view have limitations. The eliminativist approach, argued by Peterson, relies on a confusion between matter and material causes, creating a tension with Aristotle's characterization of the elements in other contexts. The neutralist approach, on the other hand, fails to distinguish properly between matter and material causes.\n\nThe author suggests that potentiality should be understood as a relational property rather than an intrinsic character of material causes. This view allows for the reconciliation of Aristotle's characterization of the elements in different contexts without contradicting each other. The two limitations of Peterson's perspective are intimately related, and refining the summary highlights the importance of distinguishing between matter and material causes in understanding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances.\n\nIn the new context, the author discusses Gill's neutralist approach, which recognizes the relative nature of Aristotle's notion of potentiality but struggles to reconcile it with the persistence of compositional matter in hylomorphic compounds. The tension lies in the fact that while the elements no longer remain specifically what they once were, they can still contribute in specific ways to the compound.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the ongoing discussion and debate surrounding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances, and how different approaches grapple with the tension between matter and material causes."
}

  "existing_answer": "Based on the provided context, here is a refined summary of the article:\n\nThe author discusses Aristotle's view of artifacts as incomplete substances and their reconciliation with his theory of natural change, focusing on part-whole relations within natural substances. The author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works and discusses the potentiality of compositional matter in relation to the homonymy principle. Three main approaches to resolve the difficulty of understanding the potentiality of compositional matter are presented: eliminativism, neutralism, and dualism. The author does not provide a definitive resolution but situates their perspective within the ongoing discussion of the issue.\n\nThe author argues that both the strictly intrinsic view and the strictly extrinsic view have limitations. The eliminativist approach, argued by Peterson, relies on a confusion between matter and material causes, creating a tension with Aristotle's characterization of the elements in other contexts. The neutralist approach, on the other hand, fails to distinguish properly between matter and material causes.\n\nThe author suggests that potentiality should be understood as a relational property rather than an intrinsic character of material causes.   "text": "THE INDEPENDENCE OF MATERIAL CAUSES\n\nAccordingly, Byrne argues that Aristotleâ€™s account of the role played by\nmaterial causes entails that they preserve their integrity and independence,\nthus he challenges the traditional view which reduces material causes to â€˜pure\npotentialityâ€™. [206] Â In order to explain and overcome this (mis)understanding\nof Aristotleâ€™s perspective, Byrne first distinguishes between matter Â (physical\nstuff) and material causes (that out of which something is made), and clarifies\nin what sense the latter can be called â€˜potentialâ€™. [207] Â He explains that\nmaterial causes are not â€˜a kind of thingâ€™ with definite properties, i.e. Â being\na material cause does not Â  mean â€˜being materialâ€™ in the sense of being\nsomething physical. Rather, being a material cause means standing in a certain\nrelation to something else; it â€œdescribes a job, rather than the thing that\nperforms that job.â€ [208] Â  Broadly speaking, something is a material cause if\nsomething else can be made from it. Byrne notes that Aristotle does not always\nresort to physical examples for illustrating the role of material causes. He\ngives, for instance, the example of the letters of the alphabet out of which\nsyllables are made. By contrast, to be something material (to be matter, or made\nof matter) means to have definite properties â€œto be matter Â in the sense of\nphysical stuff is to possess certain intrinsic, non-relational properties, such\nas being extended, divisible, movable, and so forth.â€ [209] Â  Â \n\nHaving established this distinction, Byrne clarifies in what qualified Â sense\nmaterial causes may be called potential . He argues that although matter has a\nnature, and is in no sense â€˜pure potentialityâ€™, [210] Â material causes are\npotential Â  in one respect, namely in relation to Â a compound. He insists,\nhowever, that in order to be able to play the role it is assigned, the material\ncause of a hylomorphic compound must have definite properties in its own right.\nIn other words, although it is potential in one respect , considered Â in itself\nthe material cause must be something actual. For instance, although the bronze\nconsidered qua Â material cause is potentially a statue, qua bronze it is\nactually something determinate. In fact, Byrne argues, it is precisely because\nit is actually bronze, that it can act as the material cause of the statue; to\nbe potentially Â a statue means being actually Â hard, malleable, and a series of\nother things."
}

  "text": "In line with this, we contend that in fact, Aristotleâ€™s understanding of\npotentiality does not allow for the notion of â€˜pureâ€™ or â€˜unqualifiedâ€™\npotentiality. It is just as it is with being healed; not everything can\nbe healed by the medical art or by luck, but there is a certain kind of thing\nwhich is capable of it, and only this is potentially healthy. ( Metaph . IX 7,\n1049 a1-5) [213] Â \n\n\n\nEarth is not potentially a man because it lacks certain determinations in order\nto be â€˜the kind of thingâ€™ which is capable of receiving the form of man â€œ...\njust as earth is not yet potentially a statue (for it must first change in order\nto become brass).â€ ( Metaph . IX 7, 1049 a15) [214] Â  Thus, in order to talk\nabout a man existing potentially, both the formal and material principles must\nbe actual . The formal cause must exist actually Â in another substance of the\nsame kind, and the material cause must actually Â have the properties required to\nbe potentially Â a man. Potentiality then, is limited and determined by actuality\nâ€˜on both endsâ€™ on Aristotleâ€™s account, for to be potentially x Â means a) being\nactually Â something capable of embodying the form of x and b) being informed by\na substance which is actually x ."

IX 7, 1049 a15) [214] Â  Thus, in order to talk\nabout a man existing potentially, both the formal and material principles must\nbe actual . The formal cause must exist actually Â in another substance of the\nsame kind, and the material cause must actually Â have the properties required to\nbe potentially Â a man. Potentiality then, is limited and determined by actuality\nâ€˜on both endsâ€™ on Aristotleâ€™s account, for to be potentially x Â means a) being\nactually Â something capable of embodying the form of x and b) being informed by\na substance which is actually x ."
}

The author distinguishes between compositional and functional parts in Aristotle's biological works and discusses the potentiality of compositional matter in relation to the homonymy principle. Three main approaches to resolve the difficulty of understanding the potentiality of compositional matter are presented: eliminativism, neutralism, and dualism. The author argues that both the strictly intrinsic view and the strictly extrinsic view have limitations, and proposes a relational understanding of potentiality to reconcile Aristotle's characterization of the elements in different contexts without contradicting each other.\n\nIn the new context, the author discusses Gill's neutralist approach, which recognizes the relative nature of Aristotle's notion of potentiality but struggles to reconcile it with the persistence of compositional matter in hylomorphic compounds. The tension lies in the fact that while the elements no longer remain specifically what they once were, they can still contribute in specific ways to the compound.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the ongoing discussion and debate surrounding Aristotle's view of artifacts and natural substances, and how different approaches grapple with the tension between matter and material causes.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nIn line with this, we contend that in fact, Aristotleâ€™s understanding of\npotentiality does not allow for the notion of â€˜pureâ€™ or â€˜unqualifiedâ€™\npotentiality. IX 8, 1049b25). [212] Â This holds not only in the case of\nthe agent which produces the change, but also for the patient:\n\nIs earth potentially a man?     [
      {
        "text": "In this passage, Aristotle discusses the concept of potentiality and its relationship to actuality. He argues that potentiality is limited and determined by actuality in two ways: firstly, the formal cause of potentiality must exist actually in another substance of the same kind, and secondly, the material cause must actually have the properties required to be potentially a certain thing. This means that for something to be potentially x, it must be actually something capable of embodying the form of x, and it must also be informed by a substance that is actually x. The passage highlights the relational nature of potentiality, where it is determined by both formal and material causes."

[215]\nÂ In what follows, we will attempt to establish some nuances in order to preserve\nthe truth of Byrneâ€™s position while avoiding commitment to a view of natural\ninstrumentalization which requires (1) artificial and (2) incidental\n(non-explanatory) accounts. To achieve this, Â we will argue that, while Byrne is\nright to differentiate between functional and compositional parts and to insist\nthat the latter have a certain degree of independence, it is a mistake to\nconceive of their relation to the organized whole as strictly extrinsic.\n\n\n\n\nTHE LIMITATIONS OF THE STRICTLY EXTRINSIC VIEW\n\n\nUNITY"

        "text": "In this passage, Aristotle discusses the concept of potentiality and its relationship to actuality. He argues that potentiality is limited and determined by actuality in two ways: firstly, the formal cause of potentiality must exist actually in another substance of the same kind, and secondly, the material cause must actually have the properties required to be potentially a certain thing. This means that for something to be potentially x, it must be actually something capable of embodying the form of x, and it must also be informed by a substance that is actually x. The passage highlights the relational nature of potentiality, where it is determined by both formal and material causes.\n\nByrne's account of the relation of elements to an organized body is more plausible than the strictly intrinsic view, as it avoids undermining the dual nature of hylomorphic compounds. Byrne's view is easily reconciled with the idea that nature can be said in three irreducible ways, namely matter, form, and compound. However, some nuances need to be established to preserve the truth of Byrne's position while avoiding commitment to a view of natural instrumentalization that requires artificial and incidental accounts. It is not correct to conceive of the relation between functional and compositional parts as strictly extrinsic. Instead, their relation to the organized whole should be seen as having a certain degree of independence.\n\nThe author argues that while Byrne's position is correct in differentiating between functional and compositional parts, it is a mistake to conceive of their relation to the organized whole as strictly extrinsic. A more nuanced understanding of their relationship is needed to avoid committing to a view of natural instrumentalization that requires artificial and incidental accounts."

He argues that potentiality is limited and determined by actuality in two ways: firstly, the formal cause of potentiality must exist actually in another substance of the same kind, and secondly, the material cause must actually have the properties required to be potentially a certain thing. This means that for something to be potentially x, it must be actually something capable of embodying the form of x, and it must also be informed by a substance that is actually x. The passage highlights the relational nature of potentiality, where it is determined by both formal and material causes.\n\nByrne's account of the relation of elements to an organized body is more plausible than the strictly intrinsic view, as it avoids undermining the dual nature of hylomorphic compounds. Byrne's view is easily reconciled with the idea that nature can be said in three irreducible ways, namely matter, form, and compound. However, some nuances need to be established to preserve the truth of Byrne's position while avoiding commitment to a view of natural instrumentalization that requires artificial and incidental accounts. It is not correct to conceive of the relation between functional and compositional parts as strictly extrinsic. Instead, their relation to the organized whole should be seen as having a certain degree of independence.\n\nThe author argues that while Byrne's position is correct in differentiating between functional and compositional parts, it is a mistake to conceive of their relation to the organized whole as strictly extrinsic.   "text": "In this passage, Aristotle discusses the concept of potentiality and its relationship to actuality. He argues that potentiality is limited and determined by actuality in two ways: firstly, the formal cause of potentiality must exist actually in another substance of the same kind, and secondly, the material cause must actually have the properties required to be potentially a certain thing. This means that for something to be potentially x, it must be actually something capable of embodying the form of x, and it must also be informed by a substance that is actually x. The passage highlights the relational nature of potentiality, where it is determined by both formal and material causes.\n\nByrne's account of the relation of elements to an organized body is more plausible than the strictly intrinsic view, as it avoids undermining the dual nature of hylomorphic compounds. Byrne's view is easily reconciled with the idea that nature can be said in three irreducible ways, namely matter, form, and compound. However, some nuances need to be established to preserve the truth of Byrne's position while avoiding commitment to a view of natural instrumentalization that requires artificial and incidental accounts. It is not correct to conceive of the relation between functional and compositional parts as strictly extrinsic. Instead, their relation to the organized whole should be seen as having a certain degree of independence.\n\nThe author argues that while Byrne's position is correct in differentiating between functional and compositional parts, it is a mistake to conceive of their relation to the organized whole as strictly extrinsic. A more nuanced understanding of their relationship is needed to avoid committing to a view of natural instrumentalization that requires artificial and incidental accounts."

  "text": "In this passage, Aristotle discusses the concept of potentiality and its relationship to actuality. He argues that potentiality is limited and determined by actuality in two ways: firstly, the formal cause of potentiality must exist actually in another substance of the same kind, and secondly, the material cause must actually have the properties required to be potentially a certain thing. This means that for something to be potentially x, it must be actually something capable of embodying the form of x, and it must also be informed by a substance that is actually x. The passage highlights the relational nature of potentiality, where it is determined by both formal and material causes.\n\nByrne's account of the relation of elements to an organized body is more plausible than the strictly intrinsic view, as it avoids undermining the dual nature of hylomorphic compounds. Byrne's view is easily reconciled with the idea that nature can be said in three irreducible ways, namely matter, form, and compound. However, some nuances need to be established to preserve the truth of Byrne's position while avoiding commitment to a view of natural instrumentalization that requires artificial and incidental accounts. It is not correct to conceive of the relation between functional and compositional parts as strictly extrinsic. Instead, their relation to the organized whole should be seen as having a certain degree of independence.\n\nThe author argues that while Byrne's position is correct in differentiating between functional and compositional parts, it is a mistake to conceive of their relation to the organized whole as strictly extrinsic. A more nuanced understanding of their relationship is needed to avoid committing to a view of natural instrumentalization that requires artificial and incidental accounts."

[32m[chain/start][39m [[90m1:chain:RefineDocumentsChain > [1m110:chain:LLMChain[22m[39m] Entering Chain run with input: {
  "existing_answer": "In this passage, Aristotle discusses the concept of potentiality and its relationship to actuality. He argues that potentiality is limited and determined by actuality in two ways: firstly, the formal cause of potentiality must exist actually in another substance of the same kind, and secondly, the material cause must actually have the properties required to be potentially a certain thing. This means that for something to be potentially x, it must be actually something capable of embodying the form of x, and it must also be informed by a substance that is actually x. The passage highlights the relational nature of potentiality, where it is determined by both formal and material causes.\n\nByrne's account of the relation of elements to an organized body is more plausible than the strictly intrinsic view, as it avoids undermining the dual nature of hylomorphic compounds. Byrne's view is easily reconciled with the idea that nature can be said in three irreducible ways, namely matter, form, and compound. However, some nuances need to be established to preserve the truth of Byrne's position while avoiding commitment to a view of natural instrumentalization that requires artificial and incidental accounts. It is not correct to conceive of the relation between functional and compositional parts as strictly extrinsic. Instead, their relation to the organized whole should be seen as having a certain degree of independence.\n\nThe author argues that while Byrne's position is correct in differentiating between functional and compositional parts, it is a mistake to conceive of their relation to the organized whole as strictly extrinsic. A more nuanced understanding of their relationship is needed to avoid committing to a view of natural instrumentalization that requires artificial and incidental accounts.",
  "text": "THE LIMITATIONS OF THE STRICTLY EXTRINSIC VIEW\n\n\nUNITY\n\nB yrne denies that the potential existence of elements in homogeneous mixtures\nentails their destruction. In his view, it is precisely because the elements\npersist through the generation of the tissue that the latter exhibits the\nintermediary properties that it does. [216] Â The properties of clay, for\ninstance, are derived from the basic properties of the earth and water which\nconstitutes it, and the potentiality ascribed to both constituents follows from\nÂ the fact that they are not existing separately, but in combination. [217]\nÂ Byrne insists that Aristotle conceives of combination as a middle ground\nbetween simple aggregation (a process in which elements are simply superposed,\nnot changed in a significant way) and transmutation (a process in which the\nelements lose their substantial form). [218] Â The benefit of his view is that it\noffers clarity on how the elements can contribute in specific ways to the nature\nof the compound. The difficulty lies in grounding the unity of composite\nsubstances. On Byrneâ€™s account, there is no fundamental difference between the\nrelation of formal and material principles in natural substances and artifacts.\n[219] Â In his view, the material cause of a natural body is just as independent\nas that of an artifact; with the only difference that â€œthe formal causes of\nnatural substances impose greater demands on their material causes.â€ Â  [220]\nÂ The unity of natural substances only differs from that of artifacts in that the\nformal principle makes â€œgreater demandsâ€ Â  on the material principle, because\nunlike artificial forms, natural forms have to be instantiated in very precise\nmaterials, and the specific requirements apply at many levels of composition.\n[221] Â  The issue is that it is unclear why the mere fact that natural forms\nmake â€˜greater demandsâ€™ on their material cause can, in and of itself, ground the\nclaim that natural substances are more unified than artifacts. For one thing, it\nis conceivable that a special kind of artifact could only be instantiated in\nmaterials with very precise composition; nevertheless, we would want to say that\nsuch an object does not exhibit the same kind of unity as does a natural\nsubstance. Simply, Byrneâ€™s criteria for distinguishing natural and artificial\nunity does not capture the difference between using something as a tool and\nusing it as material. [222]\n\n\n\n\nINDIVIDUALITY"
}
[32m[chain/start][39m [[90m[1m1:chain:LLMChain[22m[39m] Entering Chain run with input: {
  "existing_answer": "In this passage, Aristotle discusses the concept of potentiality and its relationship to actuality. He argues that potentiality is limited and determined by actuality in two ways: firstly, the formal cause of potentiality must exist actually in another substance of the same kind, and secondly, the material cause must actually have the properties required to be potentially a certain thing. This means that for something to be potentially x, it must be actually something capable of embodying the form of x, and it must also be informed by a substance that is actually x. The passage highlights the relational nature of potentiality, where it is determined by both formal and material causes.\n\nByrne's account of the relation of elements to an organized body is more plausible than the strictly intrinsic view, as it avoids undermining the dual nature of hylomorphic compounds. Byrne's view is easily reconciled with the idea that nature can be said in three irreducible ways, namely matter, form, and compound. However, some nuances need to be established to preserve the truth of Byrne's position while avoiding commitment to a view of natural instrumentalization that requires artificial and incidental accounts. It is not correct to conceive of the relation between functional and compositional parts as strictly extrinsic. Instead, their relation to the organized whole should be seen as having a certain degree of independence.\n\nThe author argues that while Byrne's position is correct in differentiating between functional and compositional parts, it is a mistake to conceive of their relation to the organized whole as strictly extrinsic. A more nuanced understanding of their relationship is needed to avoid committing to a view of natural instrumentalization that requires artificial and incidental accounts.",
  "text": "THE LIMITATIONS OF THE STRICTLY EXTRINSIC VIEW\n\n\nUNITY\n\nB yrne denies that the potential existence of elements in homogeneous mixtures\nentails their destruction. In his view, it is precisely because the elements\npersist through the generation of the tissue that the latter exhibits the\nintermediary properties that it does. [216] Â The properties of clay, for\ninstance, are derived from the basic properties of the earth and water which\nconstitutes it, and the potentiality ascribed to both constituents follows from\nÂ the fact that they are not existing separately, but in combination. [217]\nÂ Byrne insists that Aristotle conceives of combination as a middle ground\nbetween simple aggregation (a process in which elements are simply superposed,\nnot changed in a significant way) and transmutation (a process in which the\nelements lose their substantial form). [218] Â The benefit of his view is that it\noffers clarity on how the elements can contribute in specific ways to the nature\nof the compound. The difficulty lies in grounding the unity of composite\nsubstances. On Byrneâ€™s account, there is no fundamental difference between the\nrelation of formal and material principles in natural substances and artifacts.\n[219] Â In his view, the material cause of a natural body is just as independent\nas that of an artifact; with the only difference that â€œthe formal causes of\nnatural substances impose greater demands on their material causes.â€ Â  [220]\nÂ The unity of natural substances only differs from that of artifacts in that the\nformal principle makes â€œgreater demandsâ€ Â  on the material principle, because\nunlike artificial forms, natural forms have to be instantiated in very precise\nmaterials, and the specific requirements apply at many levels of composition.\n[221] Â  The issue is that it is unclear why the mere fact that natural forms\nmake â€˜greater demandsâ€™ on their material cause can, in and of itself, ground the\nclaim that natural substances are more unified than artifacts. For one thing, it\nis conceivable that a special kind of artifact could only be instantiated in\nmaterials with very precise composition; nevertheless, we would want to say that\nsuch an object does not exhibit the same kind of unity as does a natural\nsubstance. Simply, Byrneâ€™s criteria for distinguishing natural and artificial\nunity does not capture the difference between using something as a tool and\nusing it as material. [222]\n\n\n\n\nINDIVIDUALITY"

        "text": "The author of the article argues that Byrne's view on the relation between functional and compositional parts in organized bodies is more nuanced than a strictly extrinsic view. While Byrne correctly distinguishes between these parts, it is a mistake to conceive of their relationship to the organized whole as strictly extrinsic. Instead, there should be a degree of independence in their relation. The author highlights that the unity of natural substances differs from that of artifacts, but it is unclear why the greater demands made by natural forms on their material causes necessarily ground the claim of greater unity. The author suggests that Byrne's criteria for distinguishing between natural and artificial unity do not capture the difference between using something as a tool and using it as material."

While Byrne correctly distinguishes between these parts, it is a mistake to conceive of their relationship to the organized whole as strictly extrinsic. Instead, there should be a degree of independence in their relation.       {
        "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe author challenges Byrne's view that the relation between functional and compositional parts in organized bodies is strictly extrinsic. The author argues that there should be a degree of independence in their relationship, differing from the unity of artificial substances. The author also addresses Aristotle's assertion that no substance is composed of substances, suggesting that this passage only applies to specific ways of composition and does not necessarily contradict Byrne's view. The author then discusses Peterson's insight on the polysemy of being and unity, which highlights that unity and multiplicity are only in tension if attributed to the same thing in the same respect. This leads the author to conclude that Aristotle's rejection of the Platonic view of composition does not a priori contradict Byrne's view that instrumentalization of material elements by higher-level organisms presupposes rather than destroys the nature of these lower-level substances.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the complexity of the relationship between functional and compositional parts in organized bodies, and the need to consider multiple perspectives to fully understand this issue."
      }
    ]
  ]
}

The author argues that there should be a degree of independence in their relationship, differing from the unity of artificial substances. The author also addresses Aristotle's assertion that no substance is composed of substances, suggesting that this passage only applies to specific ways of composition and does not necessarily contradict Byrne's view. The author then discusses Peterson's insight on the polysemy of being and unity, which highlights that unity and multiplicity are only in tension if attributed to the same thing in the same respect.   "text": "NATURAL USE\n\nA nother question raised by the extrinsic view is whether the contribution of\ncompositional matter to the self-actualization of organized bodies can be called\nnatural. We have established in our introduction that the distinction between\nnatural and artificial processes is that in nature, agent and patient are one ;\nwhereas in art, they are distinct . Consequently, it is legitimate to ask how\nthe instrumentalization of the elements by the body can be natural if they are\ndistinct entities. In other words, the question is how to avoid saying that the\nbody is â€˜practicing a craftâ€™ when, for instance, it uses water for the sake of\nÂ sight in tissue formation. Simply, if we are to adopt the view that the\nelements preserve their nature upon entering the constitution of the body, we\nmust come up with a way to differentiate between natural and artificial\ninstrumental relations. It is indeed, at first sight, unclear why for instance\nthe appropriation of matter through nutrition is a natural process, while the\nuse of materials in tool fabrication is artificial. In both cases, the patient\nis moved by a distinct entity, and made to serve an end which does not, strictly\nspeaking, belong to it in virtue of what it is. The common sense answer to our\nquestion is that natural and artificial use Â  may be distinguished with respect\nto the need for deliberation. Let us start our examination with this\nÂ preliminary answer, for Aristotleâ€™s view rarely (if ever) violates common\nsense."

The author addresses Aristotle's assertion that no substance is composed of substances, suggesting that this passage only applies to specific ways of composition and does not necessarily contradict Byrne's view. The author then discusses Peterson's insight on the polysemy of being and unity, which highlights that unity and multiplicity are only in tension if attributed to the same thing in the same respect. This leads the author to conclude that Aristotle's rejection of the Platonic view of composition does not a priori contradict Byrne's view that instrumentalization of material elements by higher-level organisms presupposes rather than destroys the nature of these lower-level substances. The author also explores the distinction between natural and artificial processes, and how the instrumentalization of elements by the body can be considered natural if it is done with deliberation.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the complexity of the relationship between functional and compositional parts in organized bodies, and the need to consider multiple perspectives to fully understand this issue."

  "text": "Distinguishing between artificial and natural instrumentalization processes with\nregards to the need for deliberation is not a complete answer, for we must then\nface a further question; what grounds the need for deliberation in the case of\nartificial processes? Â If water is no more intrinsically directed towards the\nformation of an eye than is the wood towards the formation of a boat, why is it\nthat eyes come into existence without craftsmen deliberating, but boats do not?\nIn book II of the Physics, Â Aristotle says that â€œIf the ship-building art were\nin the wood, it would produce the same result by nature.â€ Â  ( P h . II 8, 199\nb27) . [227] Â If the craft was â€˜in the woodâ€™, the generation of boats would not\nrequire the deliberation of an artist. But Â what would it mean for the craft to\nbe in the wood? In fact, let us notice that he does not say â€˜if the craftsman was in the\nwoodâ€™. II 8, 199\nb27) . [227] Â If the craft was â€˜in the woodâ€™, the generation of boats would not\nrequire the deliberation of an artist. But Â what would it mean for the craft to\nbe in the wood? We have said that Aristotle, when he describes nature as an\ninner principle of motion, does not only Â  mean a physical kind of internality,\nthus we should not understand him to mean â€˜if the craft was physically in the\nwoodâ€™. In fact, let us notice that he does not say â€˜if the craftsman was in the\nwoodâ€™. We can easily imagine what it would mean for the craftsman (the efficient\ncause) to be physically in the wood, but what does it mean for the craft to be\nin the wood? It is plausible to think that it means something like this: â€˜if the\nnature of the craft and that of the wood were more intimately relatedâ€™, i.e. if\nthe boat and its formal principle were Â one , as a living body and its soul are\none. Â This is the answer suggested by an analogous thought experiment found in\nbook II of De Anima:\n\nThe soul is a substance in accord with the account. And this is the essence of\nthis sort of body. It is just like this: if an instrument â€“ for example, an axe\nÂ â€“ were a natural body, its substance would be the being for the axe , and this\nwould be its soul. ( De An . II 1, 412 b12-14) [228] Â \n\n\n\nIt follows that, in natural instrumentalization processes, there is a sense in\nwhich agent and patient, although differentiated in some respect, are\nnonetheless one . Let us invoke once again the passage of the treatise on\nRespiration Â where Aristotle contrasts the way in which craft and nature use\nÂ fire: â€œ while the crafts use the fire merely as an instrument, nature uses it\nas a material as wellâ€ Â ( Resp. Â 485 a30-b5). [229] Â Although he does not\nelaborate on what this distinction entails, what he says afterwards suggests\nthat he means to say that the natural use of Â fire involves a certain â€˜fusionâ€™\n(combination) Â with the natural body ;\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"
  ]

The author addresses Aristotle's assertion that no substance is composed of substances, suggesting that this passage only applies to specific ways of composition and does not necessarily contradict Byrne's view. The author then discusses Peterson's insight on the polysemy of being and unity, which highlights that unity and multiplicity are only in tension if attributed to the same thing in the same respect. This leads the author to conclude that Aristotle's rejection of the Platonic view of composition does not a priori contradict Byrne's view that instrumentalization of material elements by higher-level organisms presupposes rather than destroys the nature of these lower-level substances. The author also explores the distinction between natural and artificial processes, and how the instrumentalization of elements by the body can be considered natural if it is done with deliberation.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the complexity of the relationship between functional and compositional parts in organized bodies, and the need to consider multiple perspectives to fully understand this issue.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nDistinguishing between artificial and natural instrumentalization processes with\nregards to the need for deliberation is not a complete answer, for we must then\nface a further question; what grounds the need for deliberation in the case of\nartificial processes? ( Resp . 485 b11-16 ) [230]\n\n\n\nThis suggests that the distinction between use â€˜as instrumentâ€™ and use â€˜as\nmaterialâ€™ is that in the first case, agent and patient remain distinct whereas\nin the second, the agent â€˜assimilatesâ€™ [231] Â the patient, and as a result Â  â€œ\nthere is some sense in referring to the same agentâ€ . Â  Thus , when a natural\nsubstance uses fire as material , although agent and patient can be\ndifferentiated in some respects, there is also a sense in which they are the\nsame. This, we suggest, means that the formal, final and efficient causes of the\nnatural substance (its soul) should not be called the extrinsic, nor even the\nquasi-extrinsic cause of the changes it imparts in fire. We suggest that in such\na case, the relation of agent and patient is best described as quasi-intrinsic.\nTo clarify what this means, it may be useful to consider the way in which\nindividual humans are said to be parts of a family; there is a sense in which\nthe individual members are Â the family â€“ the family is not a distinct substance\nexisting besides its members â€“ and for this reason, the relation of the\nindividual members to the family cannot be strictly extrinsic; yet they remain\nindividuals with an integrity, a nature, a purpose of their own, thus their\nrelation to the whole cannot be strictly intrinsic either.\n\nSimply, we suggest that, although compositional parts have a certain level of\nindependence, within the context of composition they do not exist as an entirely\ndistinct entity. This is because the fusion and integration of materials in\nnatural instrumentalization makes them an integral part of the natural\nsubstance. As a result, we can effectively distinguish between the way in which\nan artisant Â  uses Â materials and how a natural body uses Â compositional matter;\nin art, the relationship between the materials and the artisant is\nquasi-extrinsic, as they remain separate entities, while in nature, the relation\nis quasi-intrinsic, because the agent and patient are somewhat interwoven, in a\nsense becoming one and the same.\n\n\n\n\nEXTRINSIC ENDS"

    [
      {
        "text": "In this article, the author explores the relationship between functional and compositional parts in organized bodies, challenging the idea that these parts exist as entirely distinct entities. The author cites Aristotle's passage from the Physics, where he suggests that if the craft of shipbuilding were within the wood, the generation of boats would not require the deliberation of an artist. The author then asks what it means for the craft to be in the wood, and proposes that it may involve a degree of fusion or combination between the craft and the natural body.\n\nThe author distinguishes between natural and artificial processes, arguing that the instrumentalization of elements by the body can be considered natural if done with deliberation. The author suggests that there may be a degree of independence between functional and compositional parts, but also notes that the instrumentalization of elements by the body can be considered natural if done with deliberation.\n\nThe author uses the analogy of family members being parts of a whole to illustrate how compositional parts have a certain level of independence within the context of composition, but are not entirely distinct entities. The author argues that in natural instrumentalization, the agent and patient are somewhat interwoven, making their relation quasi-intrinsic rather than strictly extrinsic.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the complexity of the relationship between functional and compositional parts in organized bodies, and the need to consider multiple perspectives to fully understand this issue."

    ]
  ]

  "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "In this article, the author explores the relationship between functional and compositional parts in organized bodies, challenging the idea that these parts exist as entirely distinct entities. The author cites Aristotle's passage from the Physics, where he suggests that if the craft of shipbuilding were within the wood, the generation of boats would not require the deliberation of an artist. The author then asks what it means for the craft to be in the wood, and proposes that it may involve a degree of fusion or combination between the craft and the natural body.\n\nThe author distinguishes between natural and artificial processes, arguing that the instrumentalization of elements by the body can be considered natural if done with deliberation. The author suggests that there may be a degree of independence between functional and compositional parts, but also notes that the instrumentalization of elements by the body can be considered natural if done with deliberation.\n\nThe author uses the analogy of family members being parts of a whole to illustrate how compositional parts have a certain level of independence within the context of composition, but are not entirely distinct entities. The author argues that in natural instrumentalization, the agent and patient are somewhat interwoven, making their relation quasi-intrinsic rather than strictly extrinsic.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the complexity of the relationship between functional and compositional parts in organized bodies, and the need to consider multiple perspectives to fully understand this issue."
      }
    ]
  ]

The author cites Aristotle's passage from the Physics, where he suggests that if the craft of shipbuilding were within the wood, the generation of boats would not require the deliberation of an artist. The author then asks what it means for the craft to be in the wood, and proposes that it may involve a degree of fusion or combination between the craft and the natural body.\n\nThe author distinguishes between natural and artificial processes, arguing that the instrumentalization of elements by the body can be considered natural if done with deliberation.   "existing_answer": "In this article, the author explores the relationship between functional and compositional parts in organized bodies, challenging the idea that these parts exist as entirely distinct entities. The author argues that in natural instrumentalization, the agent and patient are somewhat interwoven, making their relation quasi-intrinsic rather than strictly extrinsic.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the complexity of the relationship between functional and compositional parts in organized bodies, and the need to consider multiple perspectives to fully understand this issue.",
  "text": "EXTRINSIC ENDS\n\nThe most significant difficulty for the extrinsic view arises from the fact that\nthe telos Â of natural substances does not belong to the elements in virtue of\nwhat they are, and thus may be said to constitute for them an incidental end.\nÂ Because Aristotelian science is not concerned with incidental causes, [232] Â it\nbecomes a question whether there can be a genuine teleological account of the\ncontribution of constitutive parts to the self-actualization of natural\nsubstances. The issue is that, for instance, if the water which constitutes the\neye tissues remains a distinct substance with its own formal and final\nprinciple, its contribution to sight is incidental to it, and a teleological\naccount of its contribution to such an extrinsic and incidental end would be as\nscientifically irrelevant as an account of the motion of a horse which is being\nmoved by a truck for the sake of Â a human end. [233]\n\nThis difficulty â€“ namely how the telos Â of the whole can explain something about\nthe changes which occur in its compositional parts â€“ echoes an ongoing\ndiscussion within the scholarship concerning the explanatory value of\nhypothetical necessity. While Johnson and like-minded scholars avoid the\ndifficulty by denying the independence of compositional parts i.e. Â treating\nÂ them as functional parts; others emphasize the contrast between functional and\ncompositional parts and treat the latter as completely distinct substances whose\nrelation to the whole is strictly extrinsic. As a result, they must diminish or\neven deny the explanatory value of hypothetical necessity. Byrne, for instance,\ninsists that it would be a mistake to explain the essential characters of the\nelements by appealing to the nature of the whole they constitute. [234] Â He\nnotes that while it is hypothetically necessary for eyes to be made out of\nsomething transparent, it is problematic to explain the transparency of water\nwith respect to the nature of the eye; for one thing, water can constitute many\nother hylomorphic compounds or even exist on its own; and in all these cases, it\nis transparent. In order to avoid the mistake of explaining everything Â about\ncompositional matter with reference to the nature of the composite, he\nemphasizes the formerâ€™s independence and deprives hypothetical Â necessity of\nexplanatory power. On his account, hypothetical necessity does not express a\nreal causal dependance of the matter on the formal and final causes that are\nbeing embodied; it is rather a description of the kind of material and efficient\ncauses which are required to produce a good result non-accidentally. In this\nview, â€œfinal causes are effects, not causesâ€ . [235] Â  Although we share the\nconcern regarding excessively broad teleological accounts which rob\ncompositional matter of its integrity, we consider this reduction of the scope\nof teleological accounts to be excessive and problematic.\n\n\n\n\n\nHYPOTHETICAL AND CONDITIONAL NECESSITY"
}

    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: In this article, the author explores the relationship between functional and compositional parts in organized bodies, challenging the idea that these parts exist as entirely distinct entities. The author cites Aristotle's passage from the Physics, where he suggests that if the craft of shipbuilding were within the wood, the generation of boats would not require the deliberation of an artist. [233]\n\nThis difficulty â€“ namely how the telos Â of the whole can explain something about\nthe changes which occur in its compositional parts â€“ echoes an ongoing\ndiscussion within the scholarship concerning the explanatory value of\nhypothetical necessity. While Johnson and like-minded scholars avoid the\ndifficulty by denying the independence of compositional parts i.e. Â treating\nÂ them as functional parts; others emphasize the contrast between functional and\ncompositional parts and treat the latter as completely distinct substances whose\nrelation to the whole is strictly extrinsic.
