        "text": "The author challenges the idea that functional and compositional parts in organized bodies exist as entirely distinct entities, instead proposing that there may be a degree of fusion or combination between them. The author distinguishes between natural and artificial processes, arguing that the instrumentalization of elements by the body can be considered natural if done with deliberation. However, the author acknowledges that there may be a degree of independence between functional and compositional parts, but notes that their relation is quasi-intrinsic rather than strictly extrinsic. The author cites Aristotle's passage from the Physics, where he suggests that if the craft of shipbuilding were within the wood, the generation of boats would not require the deliberation of an artist. The author also discusses the issue of teleological accounts, arguing that while hypothetical necessity may not express a real causal dependence of the matter on the formal and final causes that are being embodied, it is rather a description of the kind of material and efficient causes which are required to produce a good result non-accidentally. The author considers this reduction of the scope of teleological accounts to be excessive and problematic."

  "existing_answer": "The author challenges the idea that functional and compositional parts in organized bodies exist as entirely distinct entities, instead proposing that there may be a degree of fusion or combination between them. The author considers this reduction of the scope of teleological accounts to be excessive and problematic.",
  "text": "HYPOTHETICAL AND CONDITIONAL NECESSITY\n\nNathanael Steinâ€™s presentation of hypothetical necessity in his article Â \nExplanation and Hypothetical Necessity Â in Aristotle [236] Â  provides a\nrestricted account of the explanatory role of hypothetical necessity which can\nallow us to address Byrneâ€™s concern while avoiding the equally problematic\nconfusion of functional and compositional parts. He distinguishes between\nnecessary conditions and hypothetical necessity i.e. between acting for the sake\nof , and merely contributing to Â something. Simply while a number of conditions\ncontribute to the actualization of a given form, only those which actively\ncontribute to the process qua Â â€˜auxiliary causeâ€™ (ÏƒÏ…Î½Î±Î¯Ï„Î¹Î¿Î½) [237] Â are\nhypothetically necessary. This distinction allows him to maintain the\nexplanatory power of hypothetical necessity without making the nature of the\ncomposite whole responsible for explaining too much about the substances it\ninstrumentalizes . According to Stein, the tendency to undermine the explanatory\nvalue of hypothetical necessity arises from a failure to establish this\ndistinction. If one takes all the necessary conditions of realization of a given\ntelos Â to be hypothetically necessary, then the scope of a single teleological\nexplanation becomes outrageously broad. Indeed, the necessary conditions for the\nrealization of any natural form Â  can ultimately be traced back all the way to\nthe very structure of the cosmos. [238] Â Stein suggests that the relation of\nhypothetical necessity in fact expresses an explanatory relationship between the\nfinal and material principles of natural substances, and thus does not extend to\nall necessary conditions. [239]"
}

The author considers this reduction of the scope of teleological accounts to be excessive and problematic.",
  "text": "HYPOTHETICAL AND CONDITIONAL NECESSITY\n\nNathanael Steinâ€™s presentation of hypothetical necessity in his article Â \nExplanation and Hypothetical Necessity Â in Aristotle [236] Â  provides a\nrestricted account of the explanatory role of hypothetical necessity which can\nallow us to address Byrneâ€™s concern while avoiding the equally problematic\nconfusion of functional and compositional parts. He distinguishes between\nnecessary conditions and hypothetical necessity i.e. between acting for the sake\nof , and merely contributing to Â something. Simply while a number of conditions\ncontribute to the actualization of a given form, only those which actively\ncontribute to the process qua Â â€˜auxiliary causeâ€™ (ÏƒÏ…Î½Î±Î¯Ï„Î¹Î¿Î½) [237] Â are\nhypothetically necessary. This distinction allows him to maintain the\nexplanatory power of hypothetical necessity without making the nature of the\ncomposite whole responsible for explaining too much about the substances it\ninstrumentalizes . According to Stein, the tendency to undermine the explanatory\nvalue of hypothetical necessity arises from a failure to establish this\ndistinction. If one takes all the necessary conditions of realization of a given\ntelos Â to be hypothetically necessary, then the scope of a single teleological\nexplanation becomes outrageously broad. Indeed, the necessary conditions for the\nrealization of any natural form Â  can ultimately be traced back all the way to\nthe very structure of the cosmos. [238] Â Stein suggests that the relation of\nhypothetical necessity in fact expresses an explanatory relationship between the\nfinal and material principles of natural substances, and thus does not extend to\nall necessary conditions. [239]"
}

  "prompts": [
    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: The author challenges the idea that functional and compositional parts in organized bodies exist as entirely distinct entities, instead proposing that there may be a degree of fusion or combination between them. The author distinguishes between natural and artificial processes, arguing that the instrumentalization of elements by the body can be considered natural if done with deliberation. However, the author acknowledges that there may be a degree of independence between functional and compositional parts, but notes that their relation is quasi-intrinsic rather than strictly extrinsic. The author cites Aristotle's passage from the Physics, where he suggests that if the craft of shipbuilding were within the wood, the generation of boats would not require the deliberation of an artist. The author also discusses the issue of teleological accounts, arguing that while hypothetical necessity may not express a real causal dependence of the matter on the formal and final causes that are being embodied, it is rather a description of the kind of material and efficient causes which are required to produce a good result non-accidentally. The author considers this reduction of the scope of teleological accounts to be excessive and problematic.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nHYPOTHETICAL AND CONDITIONAL NECESSITY\n\nNathanael Steinâ€™s presentation of hypothetical necessity in his article Â \nExplanation and Hypothetical Necessity Â in Aristotle [236] Â  provides a\nrestricted account of the explanatory role of hypothetical necessity which can\nallow us to address Byrneâ€™s concern while avoiding the equally problematic\nconfusion of functional and compositional parts. He distinguishes between\nnecessary conditions and hypothetical necessity i.e. between acting for the sake\nof , and merely contributing to Â something. Simply while a number of conditions\ncontribute to the actualization of a given form, only those which actively\ncontribute to the process qua Â â€˜auxiliary causeâ€™ (ÏƒÏ…Î½Î±Î¯Ï„Î¹Î¿Î½) [237] Â are\nhypothetically necessary. This distinction allows him to maintain the\nexplanatory power of hypothetical necessity without making the nature of the\ncomposite whole responsible for explaining too much about the substances it\ninstrumentalizes .     [
      {
        "text": "The author of the article argues that the idea of functional and compositional parts in organized bodies existing as entirely distinct entities is challenged, instead proposing a degree of fusion or combination between them. The author distinguishes between natural and artificial processes, arguing that the instrumentalization of elements by the body can be considered natural if done with deliberation. However, the author notes that there may be a degree of independence between functional and compositional parts, but their relation is quasi-intrinsic rather than strictly extrinsic. The author cites Aristotle's passage from the Physics, where he suggests that if the craft of shipbuilding were within the wood, the generation of boats would not require the deliberation of an artist. The author also discusses the issue of teleological accounts, arguing that while hypothetical necessity may not express a real causal dependence of the matter on the formal and final causes that are being embodied, it is rather a description of the kind of material and efficient causes which are required to produce a good result non-accidentally. The author considers this reduction of the scope of teleological accounts to be excessive and problematic.\n\nIn the next section, the author discusses the distinction between necessary conditions and hypothetical necessity, arguing that only those conditions that actively contribute to the process qua 'auxiliary cause' are hypothetically necessary. This distinction allows the author to maintain the explanatory power of hypothetical necessity without making the nature of the composite whole responsible for explaining too much about the substances it instrumentalizes. The author suggests that if one takes all the necessary conditions of realization of a given telos to be hypothetically necessary, then the scope of a single teleological explanation becomes outrageously broad, ultimately tracing back to the very structure of the cosmos.\n\nOverall, the author's argument is focused on the idea that there is a degree of fusion or combination between functional and compositional parts in organized bodies, and that hypothetical necessity is an explanatory relationship between the final and material principles of natural substances."
      }
    ]
  ]

However, the author notes that there may be a degree of independence between functional and compositional parts, but their relation is quasi-intrinsic rather than strictly extrinsic. The author also discusses the issue of teleological accounts, arguing that while hypothetical necessity may not express a real causal dependence of the matter on the formal and final causes that are being embodied, it is rather a description of the kind of material and efficient causes which are required to produce a good result non-accidentally. The author considers this reduction of the scope of teleological accounts to be excessive and problematic.\n\nIn the next section, the author discusses the distinction between necessary conditions and hypothetical necessity, arguing that only those conditions that actively contribute to the process qua 'auxiliary cause' are hypothetically necessary. This distinction allows the author to maintain the explanatory power of hypothetical necessity without making the nature of the composite whole responsible for explaining too much about the substances it instrumentalizes.   "text": "The author of the article argues that the idea of functional and compositional parts in organized bodies existing as entirely distinct entities is challenged, instead proposing a degree of fusion or combination between them. The author distinguishes between natural and artificial processes, arguing that the instrumentalization of elements by the body can be considered natural if done with deliberation. However, the author notes that there may be a degree of independence between functional and compositional parts, but their relation is quasi-intrinsic rather than strictly extrinsic. The author cites Aristotle's passage from the Physics, where he suggests that if the craft of shipbuilding were within the wood, the generation of boats would not require the deliberation of an artist. The author also discusses the issue of teleological accounts, arguing that while hypothetical necessity may not express a real causal dependence of the matter on the formal and final causes that are being embodied, it is rather a description of the kind of material and efficient causes which are required to produce a good result non-accidentally. The author considers this reduction of the scope of teleological accounts to be excessive and problematic.\n\nIn the next section, the author discusses the distinction between necessary conditions and hypothetical necessity, arguing that only those conditions that actively contribute to the process qua 'auxiliary cause' are hypothetically necessary. This distinction allows the author to maintain the explanatory power of hypothetical necessity without making the nature of the composite whole responsible for explaining too much about the substances it instrumentalizes. The author suggests that if one takes all the necessary conditions of realization of a given telos to be hypothetically necessary, then the scope of a single teleological explanation becomes outrageously broad, ultimately tracing back to the very structure of the cosmos.\n\nOverall, the author's argument is focused on the idea that there is a degree of fusion or combination between functional and compositional parts in organized bodies, and that hypothetical necessity is an explanatory relationship between the final and material principles of natural substances."

  "text": "The author of the article argues that the idea of functional and compositional parts in organized bodies existing as entirely distinct entities is challenged, instead proposing a degree of fusion or combination between them. The author distinguishes between natural and artificial processes, arguing that the instrumentalization of elements by the body can be considered natural if done with deliberation. However, the author notes that there may be a degree of independence between functional and compositional parts, but their relation is quasi-intrinsic rather than strictly extrinsic. The author cites Aristotle's passage from the Physics, where he suggests that if the craft of shipbuilding were within the wood, the generation of boats would not require the deliberation of an artist. The author also discusses the issue of teleological accounts, arguing that while hypothetical necessity may not express a real causal dependence of the matter on the formal and final causes that are being embodied, it is rather a description of the kind of material and efficient causes which are required to produce a good result non-accidentally. The author considers this reduction of the scope of teleological accounts to be excessive and problematic.\n\nIn the next section, the author discusses the distinction between necessary conditions and hypothetical necessity, arguing that only those conditions that actively contribute to the process qua 'auxiliary cause' are hypothetically necessary. This distinction allows the author to maintain the explanatory power of hypothetical necessity without making the nature of the composite whole responsible for explaining too much about the substances it instrumentalizes. The author suggests that if one takes all the necessary conditions of realization of a given telos to be hypothetically necessary, then the scope of a single teleological explanation becomes outrageously broad, ultimately tracing back to the very structure of the cosmos.\n\nOverall, the author's argument is focused on the idea that there is a degree of fusion or combination between functional and compositional parts in organized bodies, and that hypothetical necessity is an explanatory relationship between the final and material principles of natural substances."

  "existing_answer": "The author of the article argues that the idea of functional and compositional parts in organized bodies existing as entirely distinct entities is challenged, instead proposing a degree of fusion or combination between them. The author distinguishes between natural and artificial processes, arguing that the instrumentalization of elements by the body can be considered natural if done with deliberation. However, the author notes that there may be a degree of independence between functional and compositional parts, but their relation is quasi-intrinsic rather than strictly extrinsic. The author also discusses the issue of teleological accounts, arguing that while hypothetical necessity may not express a real causal dependence of the matter on the formal and final causes that are being embodied, it is rather a description of the kind of material and efficient causes which are required to produce a good result non-accidentally. The author considers this reduction of the scope of teleological accounts to be excessive and problematic.\n\nIn the next section, the author discusses the distinction between necessary conditions and hypothetical necessity, arguing that only those conditions that actively contribute to the process qua 'auxiliary cause' are hypothetically necessary. This distinction allows the author to maintain the explanatory power of hypothetical necessity without making the nature of the composite whole responsible for explaining too much about the substances it instrumentalizes.   "text": "Part of his challenge to the common view ( the reduction of hypothetical\nnecessity to conditional necessity [240] ) is to deny that hypothetical\nnecessity expresses a temporal Â relation of priority. In his view, the temporal\nseparation of the explanans and explanandum, although it is frequent, is not a\nrequirement for the relation of hypothetical necessity to hold. He rightly notes\nthat the teleological relation holds not only in the generation process, but\nalso as the organism maintains its form and actively exercises its natural\nfunctions. [241] Â In other words, he argues the relationship between the telos\nÂ and the material properties is a synchronic one. Accordingly, he suggests that\nthe contrast with the kind of necessity which belongs to mathematics should not\nbe understood temporally, Â i.e. Â it is not a contrast between a hypothetical\nrelation that starts with â€˜what isâ€™, and one that starts with â€˜what will beâ€™.\nThe real contrast, he argues, has to be understood in terms of the nature of\npart-whole relations, for in mathematics, the inference is from the definition\nof simpler components, such as the nature of a straight line, to a necessary\nconclusion regarding a more complex object constructed from them, such as a\ntriangle. By contrast, hypothetical necessity starts with the definition of the\ncomplete and mature being, and infers something about its constitutive elements.\n[242] Â Stein insists that what is being hypothesized is not the temporal\nrealization of a given nature, but rather the essence. In the case of eye\nformation; it is not the generation of an eye at a given moment in time, but the\nnature of eyes which is hypothesized. Therefore, it is misleading to emphasize\nthe temporal dimension and describe the relation, as we often do, by saying that\nif an eye is to come into existence , then it must be made out of water.\nInstead, we should say that if this is the nature of the eye , then it must be\nmade out of water. The second formulation makes it clear that the material\ncomposition of the eye is explained by its nature, whereas the first formulation\nmakes it seem as if a future event in some way dictates the use of materials.\n[243] Â  It is clear, on Steinâ€™s account, that Â the nature of the good result\nwhich is hypothesized, although temporally last, can have explanatory power.\n[244] Â By contrast, the usual way of viewing the â€˜hypothesisâ€™, makes it hard to\nsee in what sense it could be explanatory, for the temporal realization of a\ngiven nature is indeed an effect rather than a cause."
}

Accordingly, he suggests that\nthe contrast with the kind of necessity which belongs to mathematics should not\nbe understood temporally, Â i.e. Â it is not a contrast between a hypothetical\nrelation that starts with â€˜what isâ€™, and one that starts with â€˜what will beâ€™.\nThe real contrast, he argues, has to be understood in terms of the nature of\npart-whole relations, for in mathematics, the inference is from the definition\nof simpler components, such as the nature of a straight line, to a necessary\nconclusion regarding a more complex object constructed from them, such as a\ntriangle. By contrast, hypothetical necessity starts with the definition of the\ncomplete and mature being, and infers something about its constitutive elements.\n[242] Â Stein insists that what is being hypothesized is not the temporal\nrealization of a given nature, but rather the essence. In the case of eye\nformation; it is not the generation of an eye at a given moment in time, but the\nnature of eyes which is hypothesized. Therefore, it is misleading to emphasize\nthe temporal dimension and describe the relation, as we often do, by saying that\nif an eye is to come into existence , then it must be made out of water.\nInstead, we should say that if this is the nature of the eye , then it must be\nmade out of water. The second formulation makes it clear that the material\ncomposition of the eye is explained by its nature, whereas the first formulation\nmakes it seem as if a future event in some way dictates the use of materials.\n[243] Â  It is clear, on Steinâ€™s account, that Â the nature of the good result\nwhich is hypothesized, although temporally last, can have explanatory power.\n[244] Â By contrast, the usual way of viewing the â€˜hypothesisâ€™, makes it hard to\nsee in what sense it could be explanatory, for the temporal realization of a\ngiven nature is indeed an effect rather than a cause.\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"
  ]
}

    [
      {
        "text": "The author challenges the common view of reducing hypothetical necessity to conditional necessity, arguing that the temporal relation of priority is not a requirement for the relationship to hold. Instead, the author suggests that the teleological relation holds synchronically, meaning that the relationship between the telos and the material properties is simultaneous. The author emphasizes that the nature of the good result which is hypothesized has explanatory power, despite being temporally last. Stein argues that the contrast with the kind of necessity which belongs to mathematics should not be understood temporally, but rather in terms of the nature of part-whole relations. The author suggests that what is being hypothesized is not the temporal realization of a given nature, but rather the essence of the complete and mature being.\n\nIn summary, Stein challenges the common reduction of hypothetical necessity to conditional necessity, arguing that the relationship holds synchronically and has explanatory power. The author emphasizes the importance of understanding the nature of part-whole relations in order to properly grasp the concept of hypothetical necessity."

        "text": "Thank you for providing me with the existing summary and the portion of the article you would like me to summarize further. Based on the provided information, here is my refined summary of the article:\n\nStein challenges the common reduction of hypothetical necessity to conditional necessity, arguing that the relationship holds synchronically and has explanatory power. He emphasizes the importance of understanding part-whole relations in order to properly grasp the concept of hypothetical necessity. Stein also notes that those who minimize the explanatory power of hypothetical necessity share a mistake with artificial teleologists, who view the relation of priority between explanans and explanandum temporally and consider it problematic to grant explanatory power to an end. Stein argues that a good efficient cause is not a final cause according to Aristotle, but rather the good is a cause in its own right, and teleological explanations are rooted in the nature of the good result.\n\nI hope this summary is helpful! [32m[llm/start][39m [[90m1:chain:LLMChain > [1m2:llm:Ollama[22m[39m] Entering LLM run with input: {
  "prompts": [
    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: Thank you for providing me with the existing summary and the portion of the article you would like me to summarize further. Based on the provided information, here is my refined summary of the article:\n\nStein challenges the common reduction of hypothetical necessity to conditional necessity, arguing that the relationship holds synchronically and has explanatory power. He emphasizes the importance of understanding part-whole relations in order to properly grasp the concept of hypothetical necessity. Stein also notes that those who minimize the explanatory power of hypothetical necessity share a mistake with artificial teleologists, who view the relation of priority between explanans and explanandum temporally and consider it problematic to grant explanatory power to an end. Stein argues that a good efficient cause is not a final cause according to Aristotle, but rather the good is a cause in its own right, and teleological explanations are rooted in the nature of the good result.\n\nI hope this summary is helpful! Let me know if you would like me to make any changes or if there's anything else I can help you with.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nSteinâ€™s account is easily reconciled with Aristotleâ€™s conception of final\ncauses, and has the added benefit of allowing us to grant explanatory power to\nhypothetical necessity while avoiding to make a natural kind responsible for too\nmuch; for rooting hypothetical relations in the essence Â of the substances that\nare being actualized naturally limits the scope of what a given telos Â can\nexplain. His view provides us with a clear way to distinguish hypothetical\nnecessities (auxiliary causes) from mere conditions of possibility. In short,\nsomething is hypothetically necessary when it is constitutive of a given\ncapacity e.g . being hard is more than a â€˜necessary conditionâ€™ of cutting, it is\nan integral part of the cutting capacity. [246] Â  This distinction in turn\nprovides us with the means to distinguish between a â€˜resultâ€™ and an end. [247]\nÂ A set of necessary conditions may lead to a given result, for instance if a\nbird steps in water, then his feet will be wet. Stepping in something watery is\na necessary condition of wet feet, yet the birdâ€™s wet feet are simply the result\nÂ of a given set of conditions, this state of affairs is not an â€˜endâ€™. Although\nit is true that if the bird is to have wet feet, then Â he must step in water, it\nis incorrect to say that the birdâ€™s wet feet have explanatory power, and that it\nâ€˜hypothetically necessitatesâ€™ stepping in water. By contrast, an end such as\nwalking in a marsh â€“ in the case of Â a marsh dweller bird â€“ Â is more than the\nresult of a set of necessary conditions. In the Aristotelian perspective, it is\nincorrect to say that the bird developed webbed feet, and then he could walk in\nthe marsh. [248] Â Rather we should say that since Â the bird is a marsh dweller,\nthen the developmental process of his feet is such. The end Â (â€˜marsh dwellingâ€™,\nor living a marsh dwellerâ€™s life) is not a mere result . The development of\nwebbed feet in marsh-dwellers is not just a â€˜necessary conditionâ€™, nor is\nwalking in the marsh a mere result Â of this developmental process , but rather\nthe end ( telos ) Â which renders the birdâ€™s developmental process hypothetically\nnecessary.\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"
  ]
}

He emphasizes the importance of understanding part-whole relations in order to properly grasp the concept of hypothetical necessity. Stein also distinguishes between a good efficient cause (which is not a final cause according to Aristotle) and teleological explanations rooted in the nature of the good result. He provides a clear way to distinguish between hypothetical necessities (auxiliary causes) and mere conditions of possibility, and demonstrates how this distinction can be used to distinguish between results and ends.\n\nIn particular, Stein argues that something is hypothetically necessary when it is constitutive of a given capacity, such as being hard being an integral part of the cutting capacity. He also distinguishes between a result (such as wet feet in the case of a bird stepping in water) and an end (such as walking in a marsh being more than just the result of developmental process).\n\nOverall, Stein's account is easily reconciled with Aristotle's conception of final causes, and provides a clear way to distinguish between different types of explanations."

[32m[chain/start][39m [[90m1:chain:RefineDocumentsChain > [1m132:chain:LLMChain[22m[39m] Entering Chain run with input: {
  "existing_answer": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined my summary as follows:\n\nThe author argues that Stein's account of hypothetical necessity provides a clearer way to distinguish between different types of explanations. Specifically, Stein's view allows for a nuanced understanding of the explanatory relation between a natural substance and its constitutive elements. The author relies on Stein's account to outline a more detailed approach that can reconcile Byrne's independence of compositional matter with a more intrinsic view of the explanatory relation between parts and the whole. This approach can help clarify the place of instrumentalization processes within a teleological account, where conditions of possibility are excluded from teleological explanations to ensure accounts of instrumentalization processes are rooted in the self-actualization of specific natural substances.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the importance of Stein's account in providing a more nuanced understanding of the explanatory relation between parts and the whole, and how this can help clarify the role of instrumentalization processes within a teleological framework.",
  "text": "SUMMARY\n\nThroughout this chapter we have attempted to show that the contribution of\ncompositional parts to the self-actualization of natural substances can be\ndescribed as an instrumentalization process because there is a sense in which\npart and whole are distinct. We have insisted that this distinction must be\nunderstood in a restricted sense, for conceiving of part-whole relations in\nextrinsic terms undermines the relation of hypothetical necessity as Aristotle\nunderstands it. Through showing the limitations of both the intrinsic and\nextrinsic views, we have attempted to highlight the need to adopt a balanced\nperspective which does justice to the integrity of compositional matter while\nalso recognizing its (relative) identity with the hylomorphic compound.\nConcretely, our view entails that the water which makes up the eye tissue is not\ndestroyed, and that insofar as it is ensouled Â (used as material) it Â  is the\neye tissue, it is not merely â€˜containedâ€™ by the eye, as is the water in wet\nwool. [250] Â We have tried to show that this view â€“ which we call\nquasi-intrinsic â€“ best aligns with Aristotleâ€™s balanced perspective on the unity\nof hylomorphic compounds; for the strictly intrinsic view overlooks the\nplurality of substance, whereas the extrinsic view overemphasizes it . [251] Â \n\n\n\n\nCONCLUSION"
}
[32m[chain/start][39m [[90m[1m1:chain:LLMChain[22m[39m] Entering Chain run with input: {
  "existing_answer": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined my summary as follows:\n\nThe author argues that Stein's account of hypothetical necessity provides a clearer way to distinguish between different types of explanations. Specifically, Stein's view allows for a nuanced understanding of the explanatory relation between a natural substance and its constitutive elements. The author relies on Stein's account to outline a more detailed approach that can reconcile Byrne's independence of compositional matter with a more intrinsic view of the explanatory relation between parts and the whole. This approach can help clarify the place of instrumentalization processes within a teleological account, where conditions of possibility are excluded from teleological explanations to ensure accounts of instrumentalization processes are rooted in the self-actualization of specific natural substances.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the importance of Stein's account in providing a more nuanced understanding of the explanatory relation between parts and the whole, and how this can help clarify the role of instrumentalization processes within a teleological framework.",
  "text": "SUMMARY\n\nThroughout this chapter we have attempted to show that the contribution of\ncompositional parts to the self-actualization of natural substances can be\ndescribed as an instrumentalization process because there is a sense in which\npart and whole are distinct. We have insisted that this distinction must be\nunderstood in a restricted sense, for conceiving of part-whole relations in\nextrinsic terms undermines the relation of hypothetical necessity as Aristotle\nunderstands it. Through showing the limitations of both the intrinsic and\nextrinsic views, we have attempted to highlight the need to adopt a balanced\nperspective which does justice to the integrity of compositional matter while\nalso recognizing its (relative) identity with the hylomorphic compound.\nConcretely, our view entails that the water which makes up the eye tissue is not\ndestroyed, and that insofar as it is ensouled Â (used as material) it Â  is the\neye tissue, it is not merely â€˜containedâ€™ by the eye, as is the water in wet\nwool. [250] Â We have tried to show that this view â€“ which we call\nquasi-intrinsic â€“ best aligns with Aristotleâ€™s balanced perspective on the unity\nof hylomorphic compounds; for the strictly intrinsic view overlooks the\nplurality of substance, whereas the extrinsic view overemphasizes it . [251] Â \n\n\n\n\nCONCLUSION"
}

        "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined my summary as follows:\n\nThe author seeks to reconcile Byrne's independence of compositional matter with a more intrinsic view of the explanatory relation between parts and the whole. They argue that Stein's account provides a clearer way to distinguish between different types of explanations, allowing for a nuanced understanding of the explanatory relation between natural substances and their constitutive elements. The author proposes a balanced perspective that recognizes the integrity of compositional matter while also acknowledging its relative identity with the hylomorphic compound. They argue that this view, called quasi-intrinsic, best aligns with Aristotle's perspective on the unity of hylomorphic compounds.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the importance of Stein's account in providing a more nuanced understanding of the explanatory relation between parts and the whole, and how this can help clarify the role of instrumentalization processes within a teleological framework."

  "text": "CONCLUSION\n\nÂ  As our inquiry draws to a close, it is fitting to reflect on the progress we\nhave made and to consider the implications of our work. Our contribution\nrepresents an initial step in the development of an interpretation of\nAristotleâ€™s teleology which, although it differs fundamentally from artificial\nand extrinsic views, also avoids confining its scope to strictly intrinsic and\nnatural self-actualization processes. In short, we have argued that Aristotle\nconsiders the self-actualization of natural substances to be the focal point\nrather than the exclusive subject of teleological accounts. Our first chapter\nhas argued that artificial goal-directedness should not be viewed in opposition\nto, but rather understood in light of natural teleology; and our second chapter\nhas established that natural instrumentalization processes have their place\nwithin the scope of Aristotelian teleology because they are constitutive of the\nbeing/becoming of specific substances. Through this, we have challenged the\nassumption that there exists no middle ground between self-actualization and\narbitrary instrumentalization. By developing a perspective which overcomes this\ndichotomy, we have been able to avoid the excessive narrowing of scope which we\nfind problematic in Johnsonâ€™s and like-minded scholarsâ€™ perspective. We have\nbeen careful to show that the twofold expansion of the teleological horizon that\nwe advocate does not entail an appeal to unnatural and extrinsic schemes of\nexplanation. In other words, our perspective does not entail an open-ended\nextension of the scope of teleology, for the inclusion of instrumentalization\nprocesses is grounded in their relation to a specific se lf-actualization\nprocess. The following schemes may help to illustrate the contrast between the\nnarrowly intrinsic view and our own.\n\n\n\n[images/image1.png]\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n[images/image2.png]\n\n\n\n\n\nThe narrow view\n\nCause\n\nAgent- patient relation\n\nTeleologically explicable?\n\nInstrumentalization\n\nArtificial / incidental\n\nExtrinsic\n\nNo\n\nSelf-actualisation Â \n\nNatural\n\nIntrinsic\n\nYes\n\n\n\nA broader view\n\nCause\n\nAgent- patient relation\n\nTeleologically explicable?\n\nViolent use\n\nAccidental(non-explanatory)\n\nExtrinsic\n\nNo\n\nArtificial use\n\nArtificial\n\nQuasi-extrinsic\n\nYes\n\nNatural use\n\nNatural\n\nQuasi-intrinsic\n\nYes\n\nNatural self-actualisation\n\nNatural\n\nIntrinsic\n\nYes"

This view aligns with Aristotle's perspective on the unity of hylomorphic compounds. This view aligns with Aristotle's perspective on the unity of hylomorphic compounds. The article highlights the importance of instrumentalization processes within a teleological framework, and how they can help clarify the role of these processes within a balanced perspective.\n\nOverall, the summary emphasizes the significance of Stein's account in providing a more nuanced understanding of the explanatory relation between parts and the whole, and how this can help reconcile opposing views in classical philosophy."
}
[36m[chain/end][39m [[90m[1m1:chain:LLMChain[22m[39m] [11.44s] Exiting Chain run with output: {
  "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined my summary as follows:\n\nThe author seeks to reconcile two opposing views in classical philosophy: Byrne's independence of compositional matter and a more intrinsic view of the explanatory relation between parts and the whole. The author proposes a balanced perspective, called quasi-intrinsic, that recognizes the integrity of compositional matter while also acknowledging its relative identity with the hylomorphic compound. This view aligns with Aristotle's perspective on the unity of hylomorphic compounds. The author argues that Stein's account provides a clearer way to distinguish between different types of explanations, allowing for a nuanced understanding of the explanatory relation between natural substances and their constitutive elements. The article highlights the importance of instrumentalization processes within a teleological framework, and how they can help clarify the role of these processes within a balanced perspective.\n\nOverall, the summary emphasizes the significance of Stein's account in providing a more nuanced understanding of the explanatory relation between parts and the whole, and how this can help reconcile opposing views in classical philosophy."
}

  "existing_answer": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined my summary as follows:\n\nThe author seeks to reconcile two opposing views in classical philosophy: Byrne's independence of compositional matter and a more intrinsic view of the explanatory relation between parts and the whole.   "text": "Accidental(non-explanatory)\n\nExtrinsic\n\nNo\n\nArtificial use\n\nArtificial\n\nQuasi-extrinsic\n\nYes\n\nNatural use\n\nNatural\n\nQuasi-intrinsic\n\nYes\n\nNatural self-actualisation\n\nNatural\n\nIntrinsic\n\nYes\n\n\n\nIn the narrow view, only the self-actualization of natural substances can be\nexplained teleologically. This is because â€˜naturalâ€™ and â€˜intrinsicâ€™ are thought\nto have a single meaning. In this view, a motion or change is either natural in\nthe strict sense that it results from an intrinsic principle of motion, or it is\nunnatural and scientifically irrelevant â€“ the result of an extrinsic and\nincidental cause. By contrast, the broader view which we defend entails that\ndifferent kinds of motions and changes can be classified according to the sense\nin which they are natural and intrinsic, for both these notions are polysemous.\nFor instance, while the growth of an organism is natural in the fullest sense,\nÂ natural arts are â€˜more naturalâ€™ than their violent counterparts because of\ntheir subordination to natural goal-directedness. The instrumentalization of\ncompositional matter by a living organism is even more natural than â€˜naturalâ€™\nartificial processes, for in addition to being subordinated to natural\ngoal-directedness, there is a sense in which it is caused by an inner principle\nof motion ( e.g. Â in the case of tissue formation, the motion of water qua Â part\nof the body, is self-caused - for there is a sense in which the water is Â the\nbody which moves it). Thus in our view, there is no such thing as the notion of\nâ€˜intrinsicâ€™ or â€˜naturalâ€™ tout court , although we can speak of a change being\nâ€˜intrinsicâ€™ or â€˜naturalâ€™ most of all . In short, these notions apply primarily\nto the self-actualization of substances, but can be said Â in different (derived)\nways in other cases. [252] Â \n\nSimply, viewing the self-actualization of natural substances as the focal point\nof Aristotelian teleology provides an ontological basis which allows us to\ndiscriminate and classify other types of motions and changes. We may gain\nclarity on what this means by invoking the semantic analogy which Plato develops\nin his discussion of composition in the Sophist. [253] Â In short, the analogy\nestablishes a relation between structure and meaning on the one hand, and\nstructure and being on the other. The way in which structure (syntax) produces\nmeaning (semantics) is compared to the way in which formal principles cause\nbeing. This is contrasted with mere addition or superposition which results in\nmeaningless strings of words, and heaps with no genuine being. Expanding on the\nanalogy, we may compare the way in which different subordinate entities derive\nmeaning/being from their relation to sentences and substances respectively (\ni.e. their relation to that which has meaning/being in the primary sense):\n\nMeaning\n\nBeing\n\nSentence\n\nSubstance\n\nParts of speech (verbs, nouns, etc.)\n\nFunctional parts (e.g. organs)\n\nSentence complement\n\nCrafts (e.g. housebuilding)\n\nModifiers\n\nArtifacts (e.g. eyeglasses)"
}

The author proposes a balanced perspective, called quasi-intrinsic, that recognizes the integrity of compositional matter while also acknowledging its relative identity with the hylomorphic compound. This view aligns with Aristotle's perspective on the unity of hylomorphic compounds. The article highlights the importance of instrumentalization processes within a teleological framework, and how they can help clarify the role of these processes within a balanced perspective.\n\nThe author argues that different types of motions and changes can be classified according to the sense in which they are natural and intrinsic, with the self-actualization of substances being the primary focus. It is\nclear, for instance, that granting meaning to sentence complements because of\ntheir contribution to sentences does not commit one to the view that made up\nwords have meaning. Similarly, granting being to objects of natural crafts does\nnot commit one to the view that vistemboirs Â are beings.   "text": "Meaning\n\nBeing\n\nSentence\n\nSubstance\n\nParts of speech (verbs, nouns, etc.)\n\nFunctional parts (e.g. organs)\n\nSentence complement\n\nCrafts (e.g. housebuilding)\n\nModifiers\n\nArtifacts (e.g. eyeglasses)\n\nSyllables/ words\n\nTissues\n\nLetters\n\nCompositional parts (e.g. e lements )\n\nString of words\n\nHeaps\n\nMade up words\n\nObjects of unnatural craft (e.g. a vistemboir )\n\n\n\nThe comparison can help to illustrate the fact that recognizing a certain\nmultiplicity of derivative notions does not entail arbitrary inclusions. It is\nclear, for instance, that granting meaning to sentence complements because of\ntheir contribution to sentences does not commit one to the view that made up\nwords have meaning. Similarly, granting being to objects of natural crafts does\nnot commit one to the view that vistemboirs Â are beings. In short the analogy\nhelps envision the kind of limited extension of scope which we put forward, one\nthat avoids binary classifications while remaining focused on the being Â of\nnatural substances.\n\n\n\n\nTHE TASK AHEAD"

    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined my summary as follows:\n\nThe author seeks to reconcile two opposing views in classical philosophy: Byrne's independence of compositional matter and a more intrinsic view of the explanatory relation between parts and the whole. The author proposes a balanced perspective, called quasi-intrinsic, that recognizes the integrity of compositional matter while also acknowledging its relative identity with the hylomorphic compound. This view aligns with Aristotle's perspective on the unity of hylomorphic compounds. The article highlights the importance of instrumentalization processes within a teleological framework, and how they can help clarify the role of these processes within a balanced perspective.\n\nThe author argues that different types of motions and changes can be classified according to the sense in which they are natural and intrinsic, with the self-actualization of substances being the primary focus. The article invokes the semantic analogy developed by Plato in his discussion of composition in the Sophist to establish an ontological basis for discriminating and classifying other types of motions and changes. This analogy compares the way in which structure (syntax) produces meaning (semantics) to the way in which formal principles cause being, and highlights the distinction between mere addition or superposition resulting in meaningless strings of words and heaps with no genuine being.\n\nOverall, the article emphasizes the significance of instrumentalization processes within a teleological framework for clarifying the role of these processes within a balanced perspective, and how this can help reconcile opposing views in classical philosophy.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nMeaning\n\nBeing\n\nSentence\n\nSubstance\n\nParts of speech (verbs, nouns, etc.)\n\nFunctional parts (e.g. organs)\n\nSentence complement\n\nCrafts (e.g. housebuilding)\n\nModifiers\n\nArtifacts (e.g. eyeglasses)\n\nSyllables/ words\n\nTissues\n\nLetters\n\nCompositional parts (e.g. e lements )\n\nString of words\n\nHeaps\n\nMade up words\n\nObjects of unnatural craft (e.g. a vistemboir )\n\n\n\nThe comparison can help to illustrate the fact that recognizing a certain\nmultiplicity of derivative notions does not entail arbitrary inclusions.         "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe author seeks to reconcile two opposing views in classical philosophy: Byrne's independence of compositional matter and a more intrinsic view of the explanatory relation between parts and the whole. The author proposes a balanced perspective, called quasi-intrinsic, that recognizes the integrity of compositional matter while also acknowledging its relative identity with the hylomorphic compound. This view aligns with Aristotle's perspective on the unity of hylomorphic compounds. The article emphasizes the significance of instrumentalization processes within a teleological framework for clarifying the role of these processes within a balanced perspective, and how this can help reconcile opposing views in classical philosophy.\n\nThe author invokes the semantic analogy developed by Plato to establish an ontological basis for discriminating and classifying different types of motions and changes. This analogy compares the way in which structure (syntax) produces meaning (semantics) to the way in which formal principles cause being, highlighting the distinction between mere addition or superposition resulting in meaningless strings of words and heaps with no genuine being. The author argues that recognizing a certain multiplicity of derivative notions does not entail arbitrary inclusions, and the analogy helps envision the limited extension of scope proposed, which avoids binary classifications while remaining focused on the being of natural substances.\n\nOverall, the article emphasizes the importance of a balanced perspective that recognizes the integrity of compositional matter while also acknowledging its relative identity with the hylomorphic compound, and how this can help reconcile opposing views in classical philosophy."

  "text": "THE TASK AHEAD\n\nIn our introduction, we outlined four stages essential to the development of a\ncomprehensive view of Aristotleâ€™s intrinsic teleology, and set out to undertake\nthe first. We shall now conclude by reflecting on the incidence of our work in\nshaping our approach to the forthcoming phase. The next step, let us recall,\nshould Â be to determine whether the scope of Aristotelian teleology is\nrestricted to the internal functioning of organisms. [254] Â The issue is often\nformulated in a way which suggests an alternative between strictly local and\nstrong global teleological perspectives, i.e. Â the question is whether natural\nsubstances are directed towards a species-specific intrinsic end, or exist and\nact primarily for the sake of some uniform and extrinsic purpose ( e.g .\npleasing God or serving humanity). An important limitation of Johnsonâ€™s approach\nto this difficulty is that he accepts the question as formulated by those who\nhold extrinsic and artificial views of the teleological organization of nature.\nMore precisely, he accepts the premise that the interdependence of natural\nsubstances can be explained teleologically only if we posit an extrinsic\norganizer whose intentions explain the functional arrangement of nature beyond\nthe level of middle-sized organisms. [255] Â This is because he thinks\ninstrumentalization belongs to the domain of (arbitrary) intentions and is\ndivorced from natural goal-directedness. By contrast, the perspective we have\ndeveloped, because it emphasizes the ontological basis of goal-directed\ninstrumentalization processes, can help to frame the question in a more fruitful\nway. Having established that all teleological accounts, even instrumental ones,\nmust be understood in relation to the development of a specific nature or form,\nthe question becomes an ontological one, namely whether there are beings at\nhigher levels of organization i.e. whether nature is organized functionally into\nwholes Â which have a nature (genuine being and unity [256] ) beyond the level of\nmiddle-sized Â substances. If we take for instance the notorious question of the\ninstrumental role of rain in plant growth, instead of asking whether the rain\ncycle exists directly and exclusively for the sake of plants, the question\nbecomes whether rain and plants are parts of a functional whole whose nature\naccounts for their mutually beneficial relations. [257] Â This way of formulating\nthe question in no way suggests that rain, if it plays an instrumental role in\nthe development of some other nature or form, is devoid of intrinsic value or\ninclination to realize its own nature, any more than the functional organization\nof elements into organic tissues entails that the former exist exclusively for\nthe latterâ€™s sake. [258]"
}

The author proposes a balanced perspective, called quasi-intrinsic, that recognizes the integrity of compositional matter while also acknowledging its relative identity with the hylomorphic compound. This view aligns with Aristotle's perspective on the unity of hylomorphic compounds. The article emphasizes the significance of instrumentalization processes within a teleological framework for clarifying the role of these processes within a balanced perspective, and how this can help reconcile opposing views in classical philosophy.\n\nThe author invokes the semantic analogy developed by Plato to establish an ontological basis for discriminating and classifying different types of motions and changes. This analogy compares the way in which structure (syntax) produces meaning (semantics) to the way in which formal principles cause being, highlighting the distinction between mere addition or superposition resulting in meaningless strings of words and heaps with no genuine being. The author argues that recognizing a certain multiplicity of derivative notions does not entail arbitrary inclusions, and the analogy helps envision the limited extension of scope proposed, which avoids binary classifications while remaining focused on the being of natural substances.\n\nThe article concludes by reflecting on the incidence of the author's work in shaping their approach to the forthcoming phase, specifically whether the scope of Aristotelian teleology is restricted to the internal functioning of organisms or extends to higher levels of organization. The author emphasizes the importance of framing the question ontologically, rather than accepting the extrinsic and artificial views of teleological organization posed by Johnson. By recognizing the ontological basis of goal-directed instrumentalization processes, the author's perspective can help reconcile opposing views in classical philosophy."
      }
    ]
  ]
}

  "text": "NATURE BEYOND ORGANISMS\n\nBecause Aristotle has not left us a treatise on ecology, the discussion requires\nsome level of speculation. [261] Â Aristotleâ€™s silence on this question has led\nmany to the conclusion that he was not interested in ecological studies, or even\nthat his views on nature are, by principle, incompatible with the\npresuppositions of ecology. [262] Â A first thing worth noting â€“ something which\neven advocates of the global interpretation often fail to acknowledge â€“ is that\ngiven the subject matter of Aristotleâ€™s biological treatises, [263] Â we should\nnot expect him to discuss the functions of animals and plants in the\nhigher-level organization of the natural world, even if he did consider nature\nto be organized higher up, for the same reason that an anatomy textbook written\nby a biologist today would not include discussions of the ecological niche of\nthe organisms under analysis. In both cases, it is the nature of the inquiry\nwhich explains the omission rather than a principled opposition to ecology on\nthe part of the author. [264] Â Thus we suggest it is a mistake to attempt to\nground an argument for the extension of teleology beyond living organisms in the\nâ€“ very few â€“ â€œecological remarksâ€ found in the works on nature such as those\nwhich mention the location of the mouths of dolphins, [265] Â or the relation of\nrain and crop growth. [266] Â We contend that this is not the best avenue first\nÂ because these passages are not meant to address this question [267] Â and second\nÂ because there are much more relevant texts in the Metaphysics , Nicomachean\nEthics, and most importantly in the Politics, Â where Aristotle does provide\nteleological accounts of the functional organization of nature at higher levels\nof organization.\n\n\n\n\nTHE FAMILY EXISTS BY NATURE"
}

This view aligns with Aristotle's perspective on the unity of hylomorphic compounds. The article concludes by reflecting on the incidence of the author's work in shaping their approach to the forthcoming phase, specifically whether the scope of Aristotelian teleology is restricted to the internal functioning of organisms or extends to higher levels of organization.\n\nThe author argues that recognizing a certain multiplicity of derivative notions does not entail arbitrary inclusions, and the analogy helps envision the limited extension of scope proposed, which avoids binary classifications while remaining focused on the being of natural substances. The article emphasizes the importance of framing the question ontologically, rather than accepting extrinsic and artificial views of teleological organization posed by Johnson.\n\nThe author's perspective can help reconcile opposing views in classical philosophy by recognizing the ontological basis of goal-directed instrumentalization processes, and how this can help frame the question of the scope of Aristotelian teleology in a meaningful way. The article highlights the exciting opportunity for a meaningful engagement with different branches of ecology, as it entails that individual organisms can be studied not only in isolation but also as parts of goal-directed wholes existing at higher levels of organization.",
  "text": "NATURE BEYOND ORGANISMS\n\nBecause Aristotle has not left us a treatise on ecology, the discussion requires\nsome level of speculation. [261] Â Aristotleâ€™s silence on this question has led\nmany to the conclusion that he was not interested in ecological studies, or even\nthat his views on nature are, by principle, incompatible with the\npresuppositions of ecology. [262] Â A first thing worth noting â€“ something which\neven advocates of the global interpretation often fail to acknowledge â€“ is that\ngiven the subject matter of Aristotleâ€™s biological treatises, [263] Â we should\nnot expect him to discuss the functions of animals and plants in the\nhigher-level organization of the natural world, even if he did consider nature\nto be organized higher up, for the same reason that an anatomy textbook written\nby a biologist today would not include discussions of the ecological niche of\nthe organisms under analysis. In both cases, it is the nature of the inquiry\nwhich explains the omission rather than a principled opposition to ecology on\nthe part of the author. [264] Â Thus we suggest it is a mistake to attempt to\nground an argument for the extension of teleology beyond living organisms in the\nâ€“ very few â€“ â€œecological remarksâ€ found in the works on nature such as those\nwhich mention the location of the mouths of dolphins, [265] Â or the relation of\nrain and crop growth. [266] Â We contend that this is not the best avenue first\nÂ because these passages are not meant to address this question [267] Â and second\nÂ because there are much more relevant texts in the Metaphysics , Nicomachean\nEthics, and most importantly in the Politics, Â where Aristotle does provide\nteleological accounts of the functional organization of nature at higher levels\nof organization.\n\n\n\n\nTHE FAMILY EXISTS BY NATURE"

(...)\nthe Â proof that the state is a creation of nature and prior to the individual is\nthat the individual, when isolated, is not self sufficing ; and therefore he is\nlike a part in relation to the whole. But he who is unable to live in society,\nor who has no need because he is sufficient for himself, must be either a beast\nor a god; he is no part Â of a state. ( Pol . I 2, 1253 a20-35) [271]"

  "prompts": [
    "You are an expert in summarizing classical philosophy articles.\nYour goal is to create a summary of an article.\nWe have provided an existing summary up to a certain point: Based on the provided portion of the article, I have refined the summary as follows:\n\nThe author argues that Aristotle's perspective on teleology can help reconcile opposing views in classical philosophy by recognizing the ontological basis of goal-directed instrumentalization processes. The author emphasizes the importance of framing the question of the scope of Aristotelian teleology in a meaningful way, rather than accepting extrinsic and artificial views of teleological organization posed by Johnson. The article highlights the exciting opportunity for a meaningful engagement with different branches of ecology, as it entails that individual organisms can be studied not only in isolation but also as parts of goal-directed wholes existing at higher levels of organization.\n\nThe author invokes Plato's semantic analogy to establish an ontological basis for discriminating and classifying different types of motions and changes, highlighting the distinction between meaningful strings of words and heaps with no genuine being. The article concludes by reflecting on the incidence of the author's work in shaping their approach to the forthcoming phase, specifically whether the scope of Aristotelian teleology is restricted to the internal functioning of organisms or extends to higher levels of organization.\n\nThe author suggests that Aristotle's works provide teleological accounts of the functional organization of nature at higher levels of organization, such as in the Metaphysics, Nicomachean Ethics, and Politics. The article highlights the importance of recognizing a certain multiplicity of derivative notions within Aristotle's perspective, which avoids binary classifications while remaining focused on the being of natural substances.\n\nOverall, the author's perspective can help reconcile opposing views in classical philosophy by recognizing the ontological basis of goal-directed instrumentalization processes and framing the question of the scope of Aristotelian teleology in a meaningful way. The article emphasizes the exciting opportunity for a meaningful engagement with different branches of ecology, which can provide insights into the nature of higher-level organizational structures beyond living organisms.\n\nBelow you find a portion of the article:\n--------\nTHE FAMILY EXISTS BY NATURE\n\nThe Politics Â opens with the remark that â€œ Every state is a community of some\nkind, and every community is established with a view to some goodâ€ ( Pol. I 1,\n1252a1). [268] Â The good, let us recall, is primarily ontological Â for\nAristotle, and can be an object of intentions only secondarily; thus the notion\nthat a community exists for the sake of some good means something more than the\nfact that some people have come together because they desire to achieve a good\nresult. To call the community goal-directed entails that it has a nature. [269]\nÂ In the first chapter of book I of the Politics , it is already apparent that\nAristotle considers the family and the state to have genuine being Â and unity ,\ni.e. Â to be something more than an aggregate of beings. [270] Â The next few\nchapters, which examine the relation of individuals to these higher level\nentities, reinforce and clarify this. Aristotleâ€™s discussion of the functional\nrole played by individual members of the family closely mirrors his views on\npart whole relations within the context of the composition of living organisms.\nHe explicitly establishes the priority of the state over both the family and the\nindividual , and makes the radical suggestion that the latter, if it exists\noutside the state, is a man only by name :\n\nThe state is by nature clearly prior to the family and to the individual, since\nthe whole is of necessity prior to the part; for example, if the whole body be\ndestroyed, there will be no foot or hand, except homonymously, as we might speak\nof a stone hand; for when destroyed the hand will be no better than that. (...)\nthe Â proof that the state is a creation of nature and prior to the individual is\nthat the individual, when isolated, is not self sufficing ; and therefore he is\nlike a part in relation to the whole. But he who is unable to live in society,\nor who has no need because he is sufficient for himself, must be either a beast\nor a god; he is no part Â of a state. ( Pol . I 2, 1253 a20-35) [271]\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"

  "text": "This is indeed quite radical, as it seems to suggest that man, like a hand, is\ndefined functionally with reference to a whole whose end precedes and determines\nthe purpose of its parts. [272] Â  The sense in which the function of individuals\nis determined by the end of the communities they constitute is specified\nthroughout the rest of the first book [273] Â where the nature, function, and\nrelation of the individual members of the family are examined. The main elements\nto take away from this investigation are (1) that the parts of the family are\nspecifically differentiated in a way that reflects the differentiation of organs\nwithin a body. Â There is no opposition between the respective ends of master and\nslave, or husband and wife on Aristotleâ€™s account because of a shared\ndirectedness towards the end of the family which is primary, much like the end\nof an organism precedes and determines that of its organs, thus grounding the\nharmony of their respective forms and functions. [274] Â (2) It is also worth\nnoting that the differentiation of family members is qualitative, not merely\nquantitative i.e. Â the woman is not simply an imperfect man, thus Â her function\nis distinct from that of her husband, again mirroring the specific\ndifferentiation of organs within a body. [275] Â  (3) Lastly, let us note that\nthe roles are not attributed arbitrarily according to Aristotle. T his is\nattested, for instance, by the distinction he establishes between legitimate\n(natural) and violent acts of enslavement in the 6th chapter. On Aristotleâ€™s\naccount, there exists a proportionality between the intrinsic character of\nindividual members and their role within the household. Again, there is a clear\ncorrespondence with the constitution of organisms, more precisely it reflects\nthe intimate relation of the anatomy and physiology of living things, for the\nspecific function parts is determined by its intrinsic character e.g. Â eye and\nliver tissues are not interchangeable; they are, in virtue of their intrinsic\ncharacters (transparency, permeability, etc.), specifically adapted to their\nrespective function."

[275] Â  (3) Lastly, let us note that\nthe roles are not attributed arbitrarily according to Aristotle. T his is\nattested, for instance, by the distinction he establishes between legitimate\n(natural) and violent acts of enslavement in the 6th chapter. On Aristotleâ€™s\naccount, there exists a proportionality between the intrinsic character of\nindividual members and their role within the household. Again, there is a clear\ncorrespondence with the constitution of organisms, more precisely it reflects\nthe intimate relation of the anatomy and physiology of living things, for the\nspecific function parts is determined by its intrinsic character e.g. Â eye and\nliver tissues are not interchangeable; they are, in virtue of their intrinsic\ncharacters (transparency, permeability, etc.), specifically adapted to their\nrespective function.\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"
  ]

        "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have further refined the summary as follows:\n\nAristotle's perspective on teleology provides a framework for reconciling opposing views in classical philosophy by recognizing the ontological basis of goal-directed instrumentalization processes. The author emphasizes the importance of framing the question of the scope of Aristotelian teleology in a meaningful way, rather than accepting extrinsic and artificial views of teleological organization posed by Johnson. By invoking Plato's semantic analogy, the author establishes an ontological basis for discriminating and classifying different types of motions and changes, highlighting the distinction between meaningful strings of words and heaps with no genuine being. The article concludes by reflecting on the incidence of the author's work in shaping their approach to the forthcoming phase, specifically whether the scope of Aristotelian teleology extends to higher levels of organization beyond living organisms.\n\nThe author highlights the significance of recognizing the ontological basis of goal-directed instrumentalization processes and framing the question of the scope of Aristotelian teleology in a meaningful way.   "text": "Apart from the â€˜acceptabilityâ€™ of the view defended by Aristotle in the Politics\n, Johnsonâ€™s concern is exactly what we would expect, namely that ascribing a\nfunction to the members of a community undermines their integrity as\nindividuals. [281] Â He claims that Aristotle shares his concern and that we can\nget a glimpse of this in his discussion of the Platonic view of the unity of the\ncity. [282] Â He suggests that Aristotleâ€™s comments in this passage indicate that\nhe, like Johnson, doubts that communities are truly one thing , i.e. Â that he\nÂ is aware that it is problematic to extend the logic of part-whole relations\nbeyond the realm of middle sized substances; [283] Â  but Aristotleâ€™s objective\nin this passage is in fact to clarify in what sense the city is one .\nAristotleâ€™s main point is that the kind of unity that belongs to the city allows\nfor (in fact presupposes) the heterogeneity of its parts. In other words, by\ncriticizing Platoâ€™s emphasis on homogeneity, Aristotle clarifies his own organic\nview of the part-whole structure of higher level entities; and emphasizes the\nintegrity and diversity of their constitutive elements. While we contend he goes\ntoo far in dismissing the teleological accounts found in the Politics , we\nrecognize that some of Johnsonâ€™s concerns are legitimate [284] Â and demand a\nmore exhaustive discussion than we can provide here. For now, let it be\nsufficient to note that individuals are considered by Aristotle to be parts of a\ncommunity which exists by nature and has Â a specific end which is distinct â€“\nalthough intimately related â€“ to that of its parts. The upshot is that, while\nman has a certain integrity qua Â individual substance, he is not complete in an\nabsolute sense. In short, the part-whole analysis which we find in the Politics\nÂ suggests the same kind of quasi-intrinsic relations which we described in\nconsidering part-whole relations within organisms in our second chapter. Thus\nfor reasons examined in that context, the organic view of the unity of natural\ncommunities defended by Aristotle need not be understood in a way that\nundermines the integrity of its parts. Simply, we should say that being part of\na community and contributing to the actualization of its telos Â presupposes\nrather than undermines the integrity of individuals just as the teleological\norganization of the living body presupposes rather than undermines the nature of\nits constitutive elements. To take up the semantic analogy, the first book of\nthe Politics seems to suggest that a sentence (which we compared to a\nsubstance), while it is meaningful and may be understood to some degree when\nread on its own, is not completely self-contained and should ultimately be\nunderstood in the context of a paragraph (family), which in turn exists within a\nchapter (city state). [285]\n\n\n\n\nNON-HUMAN NATURE"
}

        "text": "Based on the provided portion of the article, I have further refined the summary as follows:\n\nAristotle's perspective on teleology offers a framework for reconciling opposing views in classical philosophy by recognizing the ontological basis of goal-directed instrumentalization processes. Johnson's discussion of Aristotle's teleological accounts is problematic, as he accuses Aristotle of misusing his own principles without adequately addressing why higher-level entities may not have organic unity. The article highlights the significance of recognizing a proportionality between the intrinsic character of individual members and their role within the household, just as there is a clear correspondence between anatomy and physiology and functional organization in living beings. The author emphasizes the exciting opportunity for a meaningful engagement with different branches of ecology to provide insights into the nature of higher-level organizational structures beyond living organisms.\n\nIn this context, the author argues that Aristotle's view of teleology in the Politics is significant because it recognizes the ontological basis of goal-directed instrumentalization processes, which are essential for understanding the unity of higher-level entities. Johnson's concerns about Aristotle's use of teleology are valid, but they do not undermine the integrity of individuals within a community. Instead, the author suggests that individuals are considered by Aristotle to be parts of a community, which exists by nature and has a specific end that is distinct from, yet intimately related to, that of its parts. This perspective emphasizes the integrity and diversity of constitutive elements within a higher-level entity, such as a city-state.\n\nThe author also draws an analogy between the teleological organization of living beings and the organizational structure of natural communities, highlighting the significance of recognizing a proportionality between individual members and their role within the larger entity. This perspective provides an exciting opportunity for engaging with different branches of ecology to gain insights into the nature of higher-level organizational structures beyond living organisms.\n\nOverall, the summary highlights the significance of Aristotle's perspective on teleology in reconciling opposing views in classical philosophy and provides a new context for understanding the relationship between individual integrity and the unity of higher-level entities."

More\nprecisely, we must overcome our view of political communities as the arbitrary\ncreation of the mind if we are to grasp the significance of these passages for\nthinking about the teleological organization of non-human nature. If human\ncommunities are the result of arbitrary desires, then their teleological\norganization is of no interest to the natural philosopher, [286] Â but we have\nshown in our first chapter that manâ€™s goal-directed deliberative Â efforts are\nnever arbitrary according to Aristotle (for if they are, they are not genuinely\ngoal-directed); thus the formation of the state, even if it involves a component\nof deliberation, must be understood primarily as the expression of the specific\nnature or form of the community. Thus, we suggest that the kind of part-whole\nanalysis which we find in the Politics Â  could be applied to non-human nature.\nThis is attested by Aristotle's reliance on the household analogy for\nillustrating the way in which â€œthe nature of the universe contains the good â€\nÂ in Â  Metaphysics XII 10:\n\nAnd all things are ordered together somehow, but not all alike, â€”both fishes and\nfowls and plants; and the world is not such that one thing has nothing to do\nwith another, but they are connected. For all are ordered together to one end.\n(But it is as in a house, where the freemen are least at liberty to act as they\nwill, but all things or most things are already ordained for them, while the\nslaves and the beasts do little for the common good, and for the most part live\nat random; for this is the sort of principle that constitutes the nature of\neach.) [287] Â I mean, for instance, that all must at least come to be dissolved\ninto their elements, and there are other functions similarly in which all share\nfor the good of the whole. ( Metaph . XII 10, 1075 a10-25) [288]\n\n\n\nThe analogy re-emphasizes Aristotleâ€™s organic view of human communities, [289]\nÂ but most importantly, attests to his view of the organization of the cosmos as\na whole; namely, it makes it clear that it is indeed a whole, [290] Â and not\njust a collection of beings. In fact, let us note that the household analogy,\ni.e. Â the view that natural substances are more than â€œroommatesâ€ (completely\nself-sufficient entities which happen to share a living space), is the basic\npremise of the science of ecology which is in fact named after the household\nanalogy. For all are ordered together to one end.\n(But it is as in a house, where the freemen are least at liberty to act as they\nwill, but all things or most things are already ordained for them, while the\nslaves and the beasts do little for the common good, and for the most part live\nat random; for this is the sort of principle that constitutes the nature of\neach.) [287] Â I mean, for instance, that all must at least come to be dissolved\ninto their elements, and there are other functions similarly in which all share\nfor the good of the whole. ( Metaph . XII 10, 1075 a10-25) [288]\n\n\n\nThe analogy re-emphasizes Aristotleâ€™s organic view of human communities, [289]\nÂ but most importantly, attests to his view of the organization of the cosmos as\na whole; namely, it makes it clear that it is indeed a whole, [290] Â and not\njust a collection of beings. In fact, let us note that the household analogy,\ni.e. Â the view that natural substances are more than â€œroommatesâ€ (completely\nself-sufficient entities which happen to share a living space), is the basic\npremise of the science of ecology which is in fact named after the household\nanalogy. [291]"
}
