He argues that individual members of a larger entity contribute to its overall purpose, much like the parts of a machine contribute to its functioning. Aristotle's perspective reconciles opposing views in classical philosophy and has implications for understanding the unity of higher-level entities beyond living organisms. In any case, it is\nfrequent to compare unequal things in order to emphasize the contrast between\nnature and the arts. (p. 60-2, p.201-3)\n\n\n\n[161] Â Recall Johnsonâ€™s (2005) table of comparison of the horsesâ€™ intrinsic and\nincidental ends (p.203).\n\n[162] Â Again, Johnson (2005) is not alone to hold this view, for exhaustive\nreferences to scholarly works which defend the same view of the unity of natural\nsubstances see Byrne, 2012, p.389 â€“ footnote no.8.\n\n[163] Â Johnson, 2005, p. 144.\n\n[164] Â Byrne, 2018 ; Â Gelber, 2016 ; Â Cooper, 2004, p. 108 ; Â Nussbaum, 1978, p.\n115-118.\n\n[165] Â Gelber, 2016, p. 258 ; Byrne, 2018, p. 117 â€“footnote no.37.\n\n[166] Â Gelber, 2016, p. 286-287.\n\n[167] Â Namely in discussing the natural motion of elements ( Ph . The article highlights the importance of addressing limitations in Johnson's interpretation to fully understand Aristotle's perspective on teleology and provides textual references to support this claim. (1984). Physics Â (Hardie & Gaye, Trans.).\n\n[157] Â Sedley, 1991, p. 188.\n\n[158] Â  The close connection of nature and craft has been a leitmotif Â of this\nchapter. Similarly, we suggest an account of the\nfunctional organization of individual substances into higher-level functional\nwholes has the latter as its subject, not Â the individual substances.\n\n[259] Â The view, often attributed to Plato and Socrates, which affirms Â a more\ndirect and apparent unity of the purposiveness found in nature, one which\npresupposes uniformity , for it take all substances to have the exact same\npurpose Â ( e.g. Â to serve/please God or Humans), and thus undermines the\nspecific differentiation of natural ends.\n\n[260] Â Comparable, not identical.\n\n[261] Â  Let us note that those who wish to restrict teleological accounts to the\nrealm of middle-sized substances ( i.e. Â defend the view that Aristotelian\nteleology cannot, by principle, explain the relation between organisms) too must\nâ€˜break Aristotleâ€™s silenceâ€™.\n--------\n\nGiven the new context, refine the summary.\nIf the context isn't useful, return the original summary.\n\nTotal output will be a summary of the article.\n\nSUMMARY:"
  ]
}

The article provides additional context and references to support the author's claims, including the notion that higher-level entities beyond living organisms are made to serve a determinate form or nature, and the importance of addressing limitations in Johnson's interpretation to fully understand Aristotle's view.\n\nThe author notes that all approaches investigated above aspire to achieve a balance in understanding the functional organization of nature at different levels of organization, and recognizes that identifying the subject of a given teleological account is crucial to specify the right level of composition.   "text": "[262] Â For a discussion of the difficulties entailed by Aristotleâ€™s silence, see\nLeroi (2014, p. 310-325) and Nussbaum (1978). For the more radical view that\nAristotleâ€™s teleology is in fact by principle opposed to the presuppositions of\necology, see Johnson, 2005, p. 209.\n\n\n\n[263] Â The History of Animals Â is a work of zoology, Parts of Animals a work of\ncomparative anatomy, Generation of Animals a study of reproductive physiology,\nand Motion of Animals Â is concerned with biomechanics.\n\n\n\n[264] Â Some ( e.g. Â Gonzalez, 2020, p. 149) suggest that the rarity of\necological speculation in these treatises should puzzle us if we suppose that\nAristotle did consider nature to be organized beyond individuals. We contend\nthat given the topic of these works, it is nothing surprising. What is puzzling\nis Aristotleâ€™s choice not to write an ecological treatise. As Leroi notes Â â€œ\nAristotle has the ingredients of community ecology in his hands but does not use\nthemâ€. Â  (2014, p. 319) Let us note, however, that it is much more surprising\nthat a so-called local teleologist would write the Politics , than it is that a\nglobal teleologist would fail to produce an ecological treatise.\n\n\n\n[265] Â  HA VIII 2, 591 b23-30 ; PA Â IV 13, 696 b24 -34.\n\n[266] Â  Ph. II 8, 198 b16- 199 a9.\n\n[267] Â  The passage from Physics II 8 concerns the relation of mechanical and\nteleological accounts. Aristotle argues against those who claim that the\npossibility to explain rain in terms of material necessity entails that it is\nnot for the sake of Â an end. He suggests that the opposition of material and\nteleological accounts is a mistake and that in truth, to determine whether\nsomething is a result Â of chance or the end Â of a goal-directed process, we must\nconsider the regularity of the event. Whether the event is a result ( e.g. rain\nin winter) or an end (rain in summer), Aristotle argues, the mechanical account\nstill holds. Given the purpose of his argument in that context, he does not\nprovide a detailed account of the instrumental role of rain in crop growth, but\nsimply mentions it in passing. The passages from PA and Â HA Â appear within the\ncontext of an investigation of the way of life of a specific animal. While it is\ntrue that Aristotleâ€™s comments in these (and other similar) passages may serve\nas circumstantial evidence of his general sympathy towards the idea that nature\nis well ordered beyond the level of individuals, this is not the question at\nhand in those contexts, thus they constitute a weak and inadequate foundation\nfor establishing Aristotleâ€™s view on the application of teleology beyond the\nlevel of organisms.\n\n[268] Â  Aristotle. (1984). Politics Â (Jowett, Trans.)."

These passages are discussed in relation to the topic of ecological speculation and the rarity of ecological speculation in these treatises. The author argues that it is nothing surprising that Aristotle did not write an ecological treatise, given the topic of these works, but it is much more surprising that a so-called local teleologist would write the Politics than it is that a global teleologist would fail to produce an ecological treatise.\n\nThe article concludes by highlighting the significance of comprehensively understanding Aristotle's perspective on teleology to address contemporary philosophical debates.   "text": "Aristotle's view of teleology is examined in an article, with a focus on his silence on the issue of restricting teleological accounts to middle-sized substances. The author argues that Johnson's interpretation of Aristotle's view is limited and fails to address crucial limitations in Johnson's account. The author seeks to provide a more comprehensive understanding of Aristotle's perspective on teleology by highlighting these limitations and recognizing the significance of elements being made to serve the organism's purpose.\n\nThe article discusses how all approaches investigated aspire to achieve a balance in understanding the functional organization of nature at different levels of organization, and recognizes that identifying the subject of a given teleological account is crucial to specify the right level of composition. The author also notes that those who wish to restrict teleological accounts to the realm of middle-sized substances must address Aristotle's silence on this issue.\n\nThe article cites several passages from Aristotle's works, including the History of Animals, Parts of Animals, Generation of Animals, and Motion of Animals. These passages are discussed in relation to the topic of ecological speculation and the rarity of ecological speculation in these treatises. The author argues that it is nothing surprising that Aristotle did not write an ecological treatise, given the topic of these works, but it is much more surprising that a so-called local teleologist would write the Politics than it is that a global teleologist would fail to produce an ecological treatise.\n\nThe article concludes by highlighting the significance of comprehensively understanding Aristotle's perspective on teleology to address contemporary philosophical debates. Overall, the summary provides a concise overview of the article's main points and underscores the importance of addressing Aristotle's silence on the issue of restricting teleological accounts to middle-sized substances."
}

The author argues that Johnson's interpretation of Aristotle's view is limited and fails to address crucial limitations in Johnson's account. The author seeks to provide a more comprehensive understanding of Aristotle's perspective on teleology by highlighting these limitations and recognizing the significance of elements being made to serve the organism's purpose.\n\nThe article discusses how all approaches investigated aspire to achieve a balance in understanding the functional organization of nature at different levels of organization, and recognizes that identifying the subject of a given teleological account is crucial to specify the right level of composition. The author argues that Johnson's interpretation of Aristotle's view is limited and fails to address crucial limitations in Johnson's account. The author seeks to provide a more comprehensive understanding of Aristotle's perspective on teleology by highlighting these limitations and recognizing the significance of elements being made to serve the organism's purpose.\n\nThe article discusses how all approaches investigated aspire to achieve a balance in understanding the functional organization of nature at different levels of organization, and recognizes that identifying the subject of a given teleological account is crucial to specify the right level of composition. The author also notes that those who wish to restrict teleological accounts to the realm of middle-sized substances must address Aristotle's silence on this issue.\n\nThe article cites several passages from Aristotle's works, including the History of Animals, Parts of Animals, Generation of Animals, and Motion of Animals.         "text": "The article examines Aristotle's view of teleology and his silence on restricting teleological accounts to middle-sized substances. The author argues that Johnson's interpretation of Aristotle's view is limited and fails to address crucial limitations in Johnson's account. The author seeks to provide a more comprehensive understanding of Aristotle's perspective on teleology by highlighting these limitations and recognizing the significance of elements being made to serve the organism's purpose.\n\nThe article discusses how all approaches investigated aspire to achieve a balance in understanding the functional organization of nature at different levels of organization, and recognizes that identifying the subject of a given teleological account is crucial to specify the right level of composition. The author cites several passages from Aristotle's works, including the History of Animals, Parts of Animals, Generation of Animals, and Motion of Animals, in relation to the topic of ecological speculation and the rarity of ecological speculation in these treatises.\n\nThe author notes that Aristotle did not write an ecological treatise, given the topic of these works, but it is much more surprising that a so-called local teleologist would write the Politics than it is that a global teleologist would fail to produce an ecological treatise. The article concludes by highlighting the significance of comprehensively understanding Aristotle's perspective on teleology to address contemporary philosophical debates.\n\nIn the new context, the summary is refined to focus more specifically on Aristotle's view of teleology and his silence on restricting teleological accounts to middle-sized substances. The author's argument that Johnson's interpretation of Aristotle's view is limited and fails to address crucial limitations in Johnson's account is emphasized, as well as the significance of comprehensively understanding Aristotle's perspective on teleology to address contemporary philosophical debates."

For a helpful discussion of this passage, see Narbonne\n(2020).\n\n[283] Â Johnson, 2005, p.245.\n\n[284] Â For instance, he is right to note that presenting individual humans as\nfunctional rather than compositional parts of the family seems to undermine\ntheir status as a substance. (Johnson, 2005, p.241). Wardy expresses the same,\nand other related concerns (1993, p. 25-26).\n\n[285] Â  In other words, we suggest that in Aristotle's view, we can find being\nin different â€“ but reconcilable â€“ ways at different levels of organization. By\ncontrast, Johnsonâ€™s perspective entails a â€˜horizontalâ€™ ontology, in the sense\nthat everything exists at the same level of composition, i.e. according to him,\nnatural substances are â€˜besidesâ€™ one another, so to speak, and may never be in\npart-whole relations, which means that everything above (and below) the level of\nnatural substances is a useful but arbitrary abstraction at best.\n\n\n\n[286] Â This is the view implied by Johnsonâ€™s reading of the passage from Pol . I\n8 (2005, p. 231). In order to reconcile Aristotleâ€™s comments about the\ninstrumental role played by plants in animal development with his narrowly\nintrinsic view, Johnson has to create a gap between practical and theoretical\nknowledge and say that Aristotleâ€™s discussion of instrumental relations in the\nPolitics Â is true from the perspective of prudence, but false from the\nperspective of science. Along the same line, see Wardy, 1993, p. 23.\n\n[287] Â Along the same line, see Mete. IV 12, 390a3-15.\n\n[288] Â  Aristotle. (1984). [32m[chain/start][39m [[90m[1m1:chain:LLMChain[22m[39m] Entering Chain run with input: {
  "existing_answer": "The article examines Aristotle's view of teleology and his silence on restricting teleological accounts to middle-sized substances. The author argues that Johnson's interpretation of Aristotle's view is limited and fails to address crucial limitations in Johnson's account. The author seeks to provide a more comprehensive understanding of Aristotle's perspective on teleology by highlighting these limitations and recognizing the significance of elements being made to serve the organism's purpose.\n\nThe article discusses how all approaches investigated aspire to achieve a balance in understanding the functional organization of nature at different levels of organization, and recognizes that identifying the subject of a given teleological account is crucial to specify the right level of composition. The author cites several passages from Aristotle's works, including the History of Animals, Parts of Animals, Generation of Animals, and Motion of Animals, in relation to the topic of ecological speculation and the rarity of ecological speculation in these treatises.\n\nThe author notes that Aristotle did not write an ecological treatise, given the topic of these works, but it is much more surprising that a so-called local teleologist would write the Politics than it is that a global teleologist would fail to produce an ecological treatise. The article concludes by highlighting the significance of comprehensively understanding Aristotle's perspective on teleology to address contemporary philosophical debates.\n\nIn the new context, the summary is refined to focus more specifically on Aristotle's view of teleology and his silence on restricting teleological accounts to middle-sized substances. The author's argument that Johnson's interpretation of Aristotle's view is limited and fails to address crucial limitations in Johnson's account is emphasized, as well as the significance of comprehensively understanding Aristotle's perspective on teleology to address contemporary philosophical debates.",

The article concludes by highlighting the significance of comprehensively understanding Aristotle's perspective on teleology to address contemporary philosophical debates.\n\nIn the new context, the summary is refined to focus more specifically on Aristotle's view of teleology and his silence on restricting teleological accounts to middle-sized substances.   "generations": [
    [
      {
        "text": "In this article, the author examines Aristotle's view of teleology and his silence on restricting teleological accounts to middle-sized substances. The author argues that Johnson's interpretation of Aristotle's view is limited and fails to address crucial limitations in Johnson's account. The author highlights the significance of comprehensively understanding Aristotle's perspective on teleology to address contemporary philosophical debates.\n\nThe author notes that Aristotle did not write an ecological treatise, but it is surprising that a local teleologist would write the Politics than it is that a global teleologist would fail to produce an ecological treatise. The article cites several passages from Aristotle's works, including the History of Animals, Parts of Animals, Generation of Animals, and Motion of Animals, in relation to the topic of ecological speculation and the rarity of ecological speculation in these treatises.\n\nThe author argues that in Aristotle's view, being can be found in different ways at different levels of organization. Johnson's perspective entails a 'horizontal' ontology, where everything exists at the same level of composition, and may never be in part-whole relations. The author suggests that Aristotle's comments about the instrumental role played by plants in animal development can be reconciled with his narrowly intrinsic view by creating a gap between practical and theoretical knowledge.\n\nThe author also notes that if the teleological organization of the family was the result of arbitrary intentions, it would be irrelevant to natural science. Seeing as how Aristotle compared living organisms to a well-ordered city, the author argues that the appropriate use of passages dealing with teleology beyond middle-sized substances is to complement an interpretation grounded in passages that deal more directly with the issue of teleology.\n\nThe article concludes by highlighting the significance of comprehensively understanding Aristotle's perspective on teleology to address contemporary philosophical debates. The author emphasizes the importance of recognizing the limitations of Johnson's account and providing a more comprehensive understanding of Aristotle's view of teleology."
      }
    ]
  ]
}

The article cites several passages from Aristotle's works, including the History of Animals, Parts of Animals, Generation of Animals, and Motion of Animals, in relation to the topic of ecological speculation and the rarity of ecological speculation in these treatises.\n\nThe author argues that in Aristotle's view, being can be found in different ways at different levels of organization. Johnson's perspective entails a 'horizontal' ontology, where everything exists at the same level of composition, and may never be in part-whole relations.   "text": "In this article, the author examines Aristotle's view of teleology and his silence on restricting teleological accounts to middle-sized substances. The author argues that Johnson's interpretation of Aristotle's view is limited and fails to address crucial limitations in Johnson's account. The author highlights the significance of comprehensively understanding Aristotle's perspective on teleology to address contemporary philosophical debates.\n\nThe author notes that Aristotle did not write an ecological treatise, but it is surprising that a local teleologist would write the Politics than it is that a global teleologist would fail to produce an ecological treatise. The article cites several passages from Aristotle's works, including the History of Animals, Parts of Animals, Generation of Animals, and Motion of Animals, in relation to the topic of ecological speculation and the rarity of ecological speculation in these treatises.\n\nThe author argues that in Aristotle's view, being can be found in different ways at different levels of organization. Johnson's perspective entails a 'horizontal' ontology, where everything exists at the same level of composition, and may never be in part-whole relations. The author suggests that Aristotle's comments about the instrumental role played by plants in animal development can be reconciled with his narrowly intrinsic view by creating a gap between practical and theoretical knowledge.\n\nThe author also notes that if the teleological organization of the family was the result of arbitrary intentions, it would be irrelevant to natural science. Seeing as how Aristotle compared living organisms to a well-ordered city, the author argues that the appropriate use of passages dealing with teleology beyond middle-sized substances is to complement an interpretation grounded in passages that deal more directly with the issue of teleology.\n\nThe article concludes by highlighting the significance of comprehensively understanding Aristotle's perspective on teleology to address contemporary philosophical debates. The author emphasizes the importance of recognizing the limitations of Johnson's account and providing a more comprehensive understanding of Aristotle's view of teleology."
}

  "text": "In this article, the author examines Aristotle's view of teleology and his silence on restricting teleological accounts to middle-sized substances. The author argues that Johnson's interpretation of Aristotle's view is limited and fails to address crucial limitations in Johnson's account. The author highlights the significance of comprehensively understanding Aristotle's perspective on teleology to address contemporary philosophical debates.\n\nThe author notes that Aristotle did not write an ecological treatise, but it is surprising that a local teleologist would write the Politics than it is that a global teleologist would fail to produce an ecological treatise. The article cites several passages from Aristotle's works, including the History of Animals, Parts of Animals, Generation of Animals, and Motion of Animals, in relation to the topic of ecological speculation and the rarity of ecological speculation in these treatises.\n\nThe author argues that in Aristotle's view, being can be found in different ways at different levels of organization. Johnson's perspective entails a 'horizontal' ontology, where everything exists at the same level of composition, and may never be in part-whole relations. The author suggests that Aristotle's comments about the instrumental role played by plants in animal development can be reconciled with his narrowly intrinsic view by creating a gap between practical and theoretical knowledge.\n\nThe author also notes that if the teleological organization of the family was the result of arbitrary intentions, it would be irrelevant to natural science. Seeing as how Aristotle compared living organisms to a well-ordered city, the author argues that the appropriate use of passages dealing with teleology beyond middle-sized substances is to complement an interpretation grounded in passages that deal more directly with the issue of teleology.\n\nThe article concludes by highlighting the significance of comprehensively understanding Aristotle's perspective on teleology to address contemporary philosophical debates. The author emphasizes the importance of recognizing the limitations of Johnson's account and providing a more comprehensive understanding of Aristotle's view of teleology."

  "existing_answer": "In this article, the author examines Aristotle's view of teleology and his silence on restricting teleological accounts to middle-sized substances. The author argues that Johnson's interpretation of Aristotle's view is limited and fails to address crucial limitations in Johnson's account. The author highlights the significance of comprehensively understanding Aristotle's perspective on teleology to address contemporary philosophical debates.\n\nThe author notes that Aristotle did not write an ecological treatise, but it is surprising that a local teleologist would write the Politics than it is that a global teleologist would fail to produce an ecological treatise. The article cites several passages from Aristotle's works, including the History of Animals, Parts of Animals, Generation of Animals, and Motion of Animals, in relation to the topic of ecological speculation and the rarity of ecological speculation in these treatises.\n\nThe author argues that in Aristotle's view, being can be found in different ways at different levels of organization. Johnson's perspective entails a 'horizontal' ontology, where everything exists at the same level of composition, and may never be in part-whole relations. The author suggests that Aristotle's comments about the instrumental role played by plants in animal development can be reconciled with his narrowly intrinsic view by creating a gap between practical and theoretical knowledge.\n\nThe author also notes that if the teleological organization of the family was the result of arbitrary intentions, it would be irrelevant to natural science. Seeing as how Aristotle compared living organisms to a well-ordered city, the author argues that the appropriate use of passages dealing with teleology beyond middle-sized substances is to complement an interpretation grounded in passages that deal more directly with the issue of teleology.\n\nThe article concludes by highlighting the significance of comprehensively understanding Aristotle's perspective on teleology to address contemporary philosophical debates. The author emphasizes the importance of recognizing the limitations of Johnson's account and providing a more comprehensive understanding of Aristotle's view of teleology.",
  "text": "[293] Â PA Â IV 13, 696 b24 -34.\n\n[294] Â HA VIII 2, 591 b23 -30.\n\n[295] Â  Pol. Â I 8, 1256b10-25 ; see also De Plantis I 2, 817b25.\n\n\n\n[296] Â He says for instance that â€œ livelihood seems to be given by nature\nherself to all, both when they are first born, and when they are grown up.â€ (\nPol. Â I 8, 1256 b12) Â  Â  Aristotle. (1984). Politics Â (Jowett, Trans.). Â  The\nreference to â€˜nature herselfâ€™ suggests an organization of feeding relations\nwhich is more than the accidental result of the respective activities of living\nthings (for in the latter case, it would have been more appropriate to speak of\nspecific organisms providing food for themselves and their young).\n\n[297] Â  HA VI 37, 580b15\n\n[298] Â In other words, Aristotleâ€™s principle of causal adequacy (by virtue of\nwhich he rejects Empedoclesâ€™ explanation of living things) should also prevent\nhim from considering something as orderly as the food chain for instance, to be\nthe result of chance. By contrast Johnson (2005) attributes to Aristotle a\nperspective which entails that order and harmony at higher levels of\norganization can be nothing more than a happy coincidence.\n\n[299] Â See for instance the notorious passage from Ph. II 8 (198 b16 - 199 a9);\nas well as in HA Â VIII 19, 601b25 Â which discuss the relation of plants and\nanimals to rain cycles. The author argues that Johnson's interpretation of Aristotle's view is limited and fails to address crucial limitations in Johnson's account. The author highlights the significance of comprehensively understanding Aristotle's perspective on teleology to address contemporary philosophical debates.\n\nThe author notes that Aristotle did not write an ecological treatise, but it is surprising that a local teleologist would write the Politics than it is that a global teleologist would fail to produce an ecological treatise. The article cites several passages from Aristotle's works, including the History of Animals, Parts of Animals, Generation of Animals, and Motion of Animals, in relation to the topic of ecological speculation and the rarity of ecological speculation in these treatises.\n\nThe author argues that in Aristotle's view, being can be found in different ways at different levels of organization. Johnson's perspective entails a 'horizontal' ontology, where everything exists at the same level of composition, and may never be in part-whole relations. The author suggests that Aristotle's comments about the instrumental role played by plants in animal development can be reconciled with his narrowly intrinsic view by creating a gap between practical and theoretical knowledge.\n\nThe author also notes that if the teleological organization of the family was the result of arbitrary intentions, it would be irrelevant to natural science. ## 3- Final Summary and Questions for These Laurence - Aristotleâ€™s Intrinsic Teleology (epub)

The article examines Aristotle's view of teleology and his silence on restricting teleological accounts to middle-sized substances. The author argues that Johnson's interpretation of Aristotle's view is limited and fails to address crucial limitations in Johnson's account. The author highlights the significance of comprehensively understanding Aristotle's perspective on teleology to address contemporary philosophical debates.

The author notes that Aristotle did not write an ecological treatise, but it is surprising that a local teleologist would write the Politics than it is that a global teleologist would fail to produce an ecological treatise. The article cites several passages from Aristotle's works, including the History of Animals, Parts of Animals, Generation of Animals, and Motion of Animals, in relation to the topic of ecological speculation and the rarity of ecological speculation in these treatises.

The author argues that in Aristotle's view, being can be found in different ways at different levels of organization. Johnson's perspective entails a 'horizontal' ontology, where everything exists at the same level of composition, and may never be in part-whole relations. The author suggests that Aristotle's comments about the instrumental role played by plants in animal development can be reconciled with his narrowly intrinsic view by creating a gap between practical and theoretical knowledge.

The author also notes that if the teleological organization of the family was the result of arbitrary intentions, it would be irrelevant to natural science. Seeing as how Aristotle compared living organisms to a well-ordered city, the author argues that the appropriate use of passages dealing with teleology beyond middle-sized substances is to complement an interpretation grounded in passages that deal more directly with the issue of teleology.

The article concludes by highlighting the significance of comprehensively understanding Aristotle's perspective on teleology to address contemporary philosophical debates. The author emphasizes the importance of recognizing the limitations of Johnson's account and providing a more comprehensive understanding of Aristotle's view of teleology.

Refinement:
The article examines Aristotle's view of teleology and his silence on restricting teleological accounts to middle-sized substances, challenging Johnson's interpretation. The author highlights the significance of comprehensively understanding Aristotle's perspective on teleology to address contemporary philosophical debates, citing passages from various works, including the History of Animals, Parts of Animals, Generation of Animals, and Motion of Animals.

The author notes that in Aristotle's view, being can be found in different ways at different levels of organization, and argues that Johnson's perspective entails a 'horizontal' ontology. The author suggests that Aristotle's comments about the instrumental role played by plants in animal development can be reconciled with his narrowly intrinsic view by creating a gap between practical and theoretical knowledge.

The article concludes by emphasizing the importance of recognizing the limitations of Johnson's account and providing a more comprehensive understanding of Aristotle's view of teleology.
